Solution to Question 1:
Cervix is not a part of the vulva. The vulva includes:
Mons veneris
Labia majora
Labia minora
Clitoris
Vestibule
Vestibular bulb
Greater vestibular glands.
The vulva is posteriorly related to the perineum.
The triangular space bounded by clitoris, labia minora and fourchette is the vestibule. It is present between the labia minora anteriorly and the introitus posteriorly. The posterior part of the vestibule between the fourchette and the vaginal introitus is called fossa navicularis. The vestibule has 4 openings:
Urethral opening
Vaginal orifice opening
Bartholin’s duct on either side
Ducts of paraurethral glands

Solution to Question 2:
The round ligament terminates at the anterior end of the labia majora.
The labia majora lie on either side of the vulva and join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure. The inner side is hairless. Labia majora are homologous to the scrotum in males. The labia majora and the mons veneris contain:
Hair follicles
Sebaceous glands
Modified sweat glands, known as apocrine glands
The labia minora are two cutaneous folds between the labia major. Anteriorly they enclose the clitoris and unite with each other in front and behind the clitoris to form prepuce and frenulum respectively. The labia minora are homologous to the ventral aspect of the penis.
The clitoris is a small erectile body lying in the anterior-most part of the vulva. The clitoris is homologous to glans penis.

Solution to Question 3:
The given image shows a Bartholin's cyst, which involves the Bartholin's glands. These glands are homologous to the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.
The ducts of Bartholin's glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They are stimulated by sexual arousal. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions.
Bartholin's cyst occurs due to obstruction of the ducts of the Bartholin's glands by proteinaceous material, or due to infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision. An infected Bartholin's cyst can lead to an Bartholin's abscess. This requires surgical drainage.

Solution to Question 4:
The pH of the vagina before puberty is 7. In adult females, the pH is acidic.
Doderlein's bacilli (Lactobacillus sp.) are part of the normal vaginal flora. They produce lactic acid from glycogen in the vaginal epithelium and make the vaginal pH acidic. They are present in newborns and disappear in 10-14 days. They reappear at puberty and disappear after menopause. Vaginal flora also includes microbes such as Clostridium welchii.
Vaginal defence mechanisms are influenced by estrogen. In newborns, maternal estrogens maintain the defence mechanisms for 10-14 days. After that, the levels wane. During puberty, the circulating estrogen maintains the defence mechanism.
Note: The pH is higher in the upper part of the vagina due to mixing with alkaline cervical mucus.

The urogenital diaphragm is also known as the triangular ligament.
The urogenital diaphragm extends from the pubic arch anteriorly to the central point of the perineum posteriorly and consists of two layers of fascia through which pass the vagina and the urethra. The central point of the female perineum lies between the vagina and the rectum.

The uterine cavity is lined by a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. The wall of the uterus consists of 3 layers:
Perimetrium is the serous coat adherent to the underlying muscle.
Myometrium - it consists of thick bundles of muscles that form 3 distinct layers during pregnancy:
Outer longitudina
Inner circular
Middle interlacing called living ligature
Endometrium - It is the mucous lining of the cavity. It consists of lamina propria and surface epithelium which is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium.

Solution to Question 13:
The uterus is innervated by the fibers of the uterovaginal plexus, also known as the Frankenhauser ganglion.
Option A: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery which represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery.
Option B: The cardinal ligaments are also called transverse cervical ligaments or Mackenrodt ligaments. They consist primarily of perivascular connective tissue. They attach to the posterolateral pelvic walls near the origin of the internal iliac artery and surround the vessels supplying the uterus and vagina.
Option D: Lymphatic drainage of the uterus is primarily to the obturator and internal and external iliac nodes. One theory of endometriosis, states lymphatic spread as cause for seeding in the pelvis.
Solution to Question 14:
The uterine artery above and uterine venous plexus below are likely to be damaged here, as the ureter is present between these vessels.
The ureter pierces the Mackenrodt's ligament, forming the ureteric canal. In this canal, the ureter is crossed by the uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below, thus being present in between the uterine vessels.
The ureteric canal provides the necessary room for normal peristalsis, without pressure from the surrounding structures. After leaving the ureteric canal, the ureter passes forwards and medially to reach the bladder. It is 1-2 cm away from the cervix.

Solution to Question 15:
Portio vaginalis or exocervix is the other name for the vaginal part of the cervix.
Cervix is the lowermost part of the uterus extending from the histological internal os to the external os. It is cylindrical in shape measuring 2.5 cm in length and diameter.
Cervix is made up of 10% muscle and the rest is collagen, elastin, and proteoglycan. The lining of the cervix has the following parts:
Exocervix - also known as portio vaginalis. It is lined by non keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
Endocervix - it is lined by high columnar, ciliated epithelium.
Endocervical glands - secrete alkaline mucus. When enlarged, they form swellings called Nabothian follicles/cysts.
Transformation zone - the epithelium gradually changes from columnar to squamous in this region.

Solution to Question 17:
The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the Wolffian ducts in women. These are located in the broad ligament and the vagina.
The Gartner's duct is an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. It runs parallel to, but below, the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus to the level of the internal os where it passes into the tissues of the cervix. It then runs forwards to reach the anterolateral aspect of the vaginal wall and may reach as far down as the hymen.
The duct can sometimes form a cyst in the broad ligament or in the vagina. It is called Gartner’s cyst. It is a benign condition and can be treated with marsupialization.

Solution to Question 18:
The ovarian ligaments are contained in the posterior fold of the broad ligament. The broad ligament contains the following parts:
Mesosalpinx - it lies between the fallopian tube and ovarian ligament. It contains the pelvic vessels - anastomoses between uterine and ovarian arteries. The ovary is attached via ovarian igament through the posterior folds to the mesovarium.
Mesometrium - it contains the ovarian vessels within the infundibulopelvic ligament.
The ureter is present in the inferomedial part of the broad ligament. It is related to the uterine artery here and may be damaged during hysterectomy.
Note: Broad ligament is not a support of the uterus.
Solution to Question 19:
Peg cells are seen in the fallopian tubes.
A peg cell is a non-ciliated epithelial cell within the fallopian tube. These cells are also known as intercalated or intercalary cells whose function is not yet known.
The image below shows pale ciliated cells (arrows) and narrow, dark, non-ciliated peg cells
(arrowheads).

Solution to Question 20:
The longest and widest part of the fallopian tube is the ampulla (5 cm).
Solution to Question 21:
Tunica albuginea of the adult ovary is derived from the sub-epithelial connective tissue layer. Structure of the ovary:
Surface epithelium - a single layer of cuboidal cells is present, which later gives rise to the surface epithelium of the adult ovary. It is morphologically continuous with the mesothelium of the peritoneum.
The subepithelial connective tissue layer - gives rise to the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary and the basement membrane beneath the surface epithelium.
The parenchymatous zone - becomes the cortex and contains the egg nests and ovarian follicles.
Zona vasculosa - becomes the medulla and contains the blood vessels. Hilar cells present here are homologous to interstitial cells of testes. They can rarely produce hilar cell tumors of the ovary.

Solution to Question 22:
Call-Exner bodies are formed by granulosa cells present within the granulosa cell layer of the ovary.
They are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with acidophilic material, resembling immature follicles. They are characteristically seen in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.
The image below shows Call-Exner bodies (circled in black).

Graafian follicle:
The mature Graafian follicle is spheroidal or ovoid in shape. It contains pent-up secretion known as the liquor folliculi. The lining consists of:
Theca externa
Theca interna - contain the theca cells
Granulosa cell layer
Cumulus oophorus - projection of granulosa cells into the cavity of the Graafian follicle. It is also called the discus proligerus.

Solution to Question 23:
The efferent preganglionic sympathetic fibres to the ovary are derived from the T10-T11 spinal levels.
These fibres travel to the prevertebral ganglia, where they synapse. The postganglionic sympathetic fibres arising from these ganglia contribute to the ovarian plexus, which innervates the ovary.
The ovarian plexus is a network of nerves comprising:
Postganglionic sympathetic fibres
Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres from the sacral outflow (S2-S4)
Visceral afferent fibres (responsible for transmitting sensory signals) The ovarian plexus has two parts based on its connections:
Upper part: Derived from branches of the renal plexus and aortic plexus
Lower part: Derived from the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses.
Solution to Question 24:
Rupture of the spiral arteries causes bleeding during normal menstruation. This is a branch of the uterine artery.
The blood supply of the uterus is as follows:
Uterine arteryArcuate arteryRadial arteryBasal arterySpiral artery

Solution to Question 25:
In the given case scenario, blood flow in the vaginal artery will not be affected, as it is not a branch of the uterine artery. The vaginal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal
iliac artery.
It is homologous to the inferior vesical artery in males. It supplies the vagina and the base of the bladder in women. It should not be confused with vaginal branches of the uterine artery.
Branches of the uterine artery:
Ureteric branch
Vaginal branches (descending) - these unite to form the anterior and posterior azygos arteries of the vagina
Circular cervical branch
Sampson's artery - it runs in under the round ligament. It represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery.
Arcuate--> Radial--> Basal--> Spiral and straight arterioles of the functional layer of the endometrium

Solution to Question 26:
The space of Retzius is the other name for prevesical or retropubic space.
Burch colposuspension is a procedure done to relieve stress urinary incontinence. If an extraperitoneal approach is selected, the retropubic space is entered by perforating the transversalis fascia layer of the anterior abdominal wall.
Once the retropubic space is dissected, the bladder neck and the vaginal fascia underneath are identified. The bladder is mobilized to the opposite side. At each side of the bladder neck, two to four, preferably non■absorbable sutures are placed in the space of Retzius.
Note:The presacral space is a retroperitoneal space that lies between the peritoneum of the posterior abdominal wall and the sacrum. It contains the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses. The sacral sympathetic trunk lies against the sacrum’s ventral surface.

Germ cells appear in the yolk sac in the 3rd week.

Solution to Question 2:
The ovary contains the maximum number of oogonia at the 5th month of intrauterine life. The number of oogonia is estimated to be 7 million.
Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. At the initiation of puberty, the follicle count is less than 400,000, of which less than 500 are destined to ovulate. Every month, 15–20 follicles are released, out of which one matures to form the ovum.
Solution to Question 3:
The sperm count is tested 80-90 days after hormonal treatment, as the average time is taken for spermatogenesis is 74 days, and approximately 14 days to reach the ejaculatory ducts.
The effect of hormonal therapy on the early phase of spermatogenesis is reflected in the ejaculated sperm concentration after three months.
Spermatogenesis is the process of the formation of sperms from spermatogonia. Approximately 100 million sperms are produced daily.
In patients diagnosed with oligospermia, hormonal treatment is carried out using FSH, hCG, or testosterone. Improvements in sperm count can take a few months, hence the course is usually for 3-6 months. Normal spermatogenesis occurs after this time period.
Spermiogenesis refers to the series of changes that occur in the formation of spermatozoa from spermatids. These are:
Acrosome formation
Condensation of the nucleus
Formation of the neck, middle piece, and tail
Shedding of cytoplasm as residual bodies Complete motility is obtained in the epididymis.

Solution to Question 4:
The time taken for the capacitation of sperms is 6-8 hours (approximately 7 hours).
Sperms have to undergo two changes in the female reproductive tract to be able to fertilise the ovum:
Capacitation
It is the functional maturation of the spermatozoa.
It occurs in the fallopian tube and involves epithelial interactions between the sperm and the ucosal surface of the tube.
The glycoprotein coat and seminal plasma proteins are removed.
Only capacitated sperms can pass through the corona cells and undergo the acrosomal reaction.
Acrosomal reaction
It occurs after binding to zona pellucida, induced by zona proteins.
Enzymes such as acrosin and trypsin-like protein are released to penetrate the zona pellucida
Ca2+ plays an important role.

Solution to Question 5:
Meiosis-I in the primary oocyte is resumed after LH surge.

Solution to Question 6:
Meiosis I or reductional division occurs in the transition from primary spermatocyte to secondary spermatocyte.
Meiosis takes place in germ cells to generate male and female gametes. Meiosis involves two stages of cell division, namely, meiosis I and II.
Meiosis I produces two haploid cells. Because the ploidy is reduced from diploid to haploid, meiosis I is referred to as a reductional division. Meiosis II is an equational division analogous to mitosis, resulting in the creation of four haploid daughter cells.

Solution to Question 7:
The secondary oocyte is formed after meiosis I.
Primordial germ cells divide by mitosis to form oogonia. The majority of the oogonia divide by mitosis, however, some enter meiosis I and are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase and are now called primary oocytes. Primary oocytes have not yet completed meiosis, hence they are diploid. The primary oocyte along with surrounding epithelial cells forms the primordial follicle.
Meiosis I is completed after LH surge during puberty. Hence at the completetion of meiosis I, secondary oocyte is produced.

Solution to Question 8:
Zona hatching occurs at around 5 days after fertilization. Fertilization is divided into the following phases:
Penetration of the corona radiata
Penetration of the zona pellucida
Fusion of the oocyte and sperm cell membranes
After fertilisation, the zygote differentiates to form the morula and then the blastocyst. The zona pellucida disappears at this stage, which is called zona hatching. The trophoblasts (outer cell mass) are now able to associate with the endometrium during implantation.
Solution to Question 9:
The fertilized ovum implants by 6–10 days in the uterine cavity. Implantation involves:
Apposition: Initial contact of the blastocyst to the uterine wall
Adhesion: Increased physical contact between the blastocyst and uterine epitheliu
Invasion: Penetration and invasion of syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblasts into the endometriu
A successful implantation requires receptive endometrium primed with estrogen and progesterone released by the corpus luteum.

Solution to Question 10:
In the given image, the decidua basalis is marked as A. This part of the decidua forms the placenta.

Implantation occurs 6 to 7 days after fertilization. After implantation, the endometrium is called the decidua. It is of the following types:
Decidua basalis - present over chorion frondosum. Decidua basalis and chorion frondosum for the placenta.
Decidua capsularis - present over abembryonic pole.
Decidua parietalis - present on the opposite side of the uterus.
The villi cover the entire surface of the chorion during the early weeks. As the fetus grows, the villi on the embryonic pole continue to grow, giving rise to the chorion frondosum. At
the abembryonic pole, the villi degenerate. By the third month, this side of the chorion becomes smooth, and is called the chorion laeve.

As the fetus grows, the chorion laeve comes into contact with the decidua parietalis on the opposite side of the uterus, and fusion occurs. Thus, the uterine lumen is obliterated. The amnion and chorion fuse, to form the amniochorionic membrane. Rupture of the amniochorionic membrane during labor is called 'breaking of waters'.
Note: Superfetation can theoretically occur till the time the uterine lumen is not obliterated.

Solution to Question 11:
Langhans cells form the cytotrophoblast.
The cells of the blastocyst differentiate into an outer trophectoderm and an inner cell mass. The trophectoderm is further differentiated into:
An inner mononuclear cellular layer called cytotrophoblast or Langhans layer made of Langhans cells.
An outer layer of multinucleated syncytium called syncytiotrophoblast. The blastomere further divides to form the morula.

Solution to Question 12:
The structure marked A is primary oocyte. Primary oocytes are the germ cells seen in the medullary region of the ovary. These enlarge at the beginning of the growth phase.
During this cell growth period, many oocytes undergo degeneration, both before and after birth. A single layer of flattened follicular cells that were derived originally from the germinal epithelium soon surrounds the primary oocytes. The structure that is formed is now called a primordial follicle. These are seen first in the medulla and later in the cortex.


Solution to Question 13:
Fertilization usually occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.
During ovulation, the ovum is released and it enters the fallopian tube. It is propelled towards the uterine cavity by the peristaltic action of the fallopian tubes, prostaglandins in the male seminal fluid and oxytocin. It can only be fertilized within 24 hours of ovulation. If coitus takes place during this period, the spermatozoa swimming up into the tubes meet the ovum in the ampulla.
Solution to Question 14:
The given image shows an oropharygeal teratoma, which contains derivatives from all three germ layers.
The tumor may include gut, bone, skin, and teeth. These tumors arise from pluripotent stem cells that differentiate into any of three germ layers forming tissues of all three germ layers.
Solution to Question 15:
The structure marked A is the allantois.
The posterior wall of the yolk sac forms the allantois on the 16th day of development. Its distal portion forms the urachus which forms the median umbilical ligament.
The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week.

Solution to Question 4:
Face to pubis delivery is most commonly associated with anthropoid pelvis.
As the anthropoid pelvis is wider posteriorly, the fetal occiput occupies the posterior segment of the pelvis. Thus, the fetus is present in the occipitoposterior position which leads to a high chance of face-to-pubis delivery.


Solution to Question 5:
The interspinous diameter is the smallest transverse pelvic diameter.
The interspinous diameter or bispinous diameter is measured in the mid pelvis. It is the distance between the tips of two ischial spines. Normally, it is 10-10.5 cm.
It is useful in predicting obstructed labor. If the interspinous diameter is too small, the baby's head may get stuck at a higher station.
Note: The obstetric conjugate is the smallest anteroposterior pelvic diameter measuring 10 cm.

Solution to Question 6:
The obstetric conjugate is X-2cm where X is the diagonal conjugate. Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvis:
True conjugate or the anteroposterior diameter, extends from the upper most margin of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. It is normally 11 cm.
Obstetrical conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis. It is normally 10 cm. It is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.
Diagonal conjugate is determined by measuring the distance from the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. It is normally 12cm. It is measured clinically.

Solution to Question 7:
In the given case scenario, a trial of labor or vaginal delivery can be allowed if the obstetric conjugate is 10cm or more.
The obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis. Normally, it is 10 cm or more.
The diagonal conjugate measures 12cm and the true conjugate measures 11cm.
Clinically, only the diagonal conjugate is assessed by measuring the distance between the base of the examiner's fingers and the fingertip touching the sacral promontory. This determines
the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. The obstetric conjugate is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.
Note: Overt diabetes can cause fetal macrosomia during pregnancy. Thus, it may lead to cephalopelvic disproportion.

The bispinous diameter can be viewed in the anteroposterior view and not the lateral plate pelvimetry.
X-ray pelvimetry is done using 3 views:
Anteroposterior - Transverse diameter and bispinous diameter is determined.
Lateral - Obstetric conjugate, sacral curve and pelvic inclination are seen.
Outlet - Outlet diameters are determined.
Note: CT pelvimetry is preferred over X-ray pelvimetry due to the lower dose of radiation delivered.

Solution to Question 9:
The type of pelvis seen here is Robert's pelvis. In it, the pelvis is transversely contracted and the ala on both sides are absent and the sacrum is fused with the innominate bones.
Option A: In Naegele's pelvis, there is arrested development of one ala of the sacrum.
Option C: Kyphotic pelvis occurs secondary to the kyphotic changes of the vertebral column either following tuberculosis or rickets.
Option D: In rachitic pelvis, due to softening of bones, flattening of the pelvis occurs.
Solution to Question 10:
To make a diagnosis of contracted pelvis, the transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet should be 10cm.
The pelvic inlet is considered to be contracted if:
the greatest transverse diameter is < 12 cm or
the shortest anteroposterior diameter is < 10 cm.
The anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet are the true conjugate, diagonal conjugate and obstetric conjugate. These extend between the sacral promontory and symphysis pubis. The obstetric conjugate is the shortest diameter, normally measuring 10 cm.
The transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet is at a right angle to the obstetric conjugate. It extends between the linea terminalis on either side. Normally, the transverse diameter is about 13 cm.


Solution to Question 11:
Among the given options, the bitemporal diameter is the smallest. It is the distance between the anteroinferior ends of the coronal suture and usually measures 8 cm. This is the smallest engaging diameter.
Option A: The biparietal diameter is a transverse diameter between two parietal eminences, measuring 9.5cm.
Option B: The suboccipitofrontal diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 10 cm. Option C: The suboccipitobregmatic diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 9.5 cm.
Note: The bimastoid diameter is a transverse diameter. It is the smallest diameter in the fetal skull at about 7.5 cm. However it is not clinically relevant as it does not engage.
Solution to Question 12:
In brow presentation, the mentovertical diameter is engaged which is the longest diameter of the fetal skull. Normally, it measures 14 cm.
The mentovertical diameter extends from the midpoint of the chin to the highest point on the sagittal suture.

Solution to Question 14:
Newborns have a total of 6 fontanelles. These are fibrous, membrane-covered gaps between cranial bones.
The fontanelles seen in newborns are:
Anterior fontanelle:
It is also called bregma.
Diameter ranges from 0.6-3.6 cm, with a mean of 2.1 cm.
It completely closes by 24 months of age.
Posterior fontanelle:
It is also called lambda.
Diameter ranges from 0.5-0.7 cm.
It completely closes by 2 months of age.

Solution to Question 15:
In the given clinical picture, the swelling over the infant's head is likely to be a cephalhematoma. Infants with cephalohematomas are at a heightened risk of developing jaundice because as the blood breaks down, the levels of bilirubin increase.
Cephalohematoma is a collection of blood in between the pericranium and the flat bone (subperiosteal) of the skull, usually unilateral and over a parietal bone.It is never present at birth but gradually develops after 12–24 h. The swelling is limited by the suture lines of the skull as the pericranium is fixed to the margins of the bone
Option A: Tension in the swelling varies with crying in meningocele. Option C: Edematous fluid collects in caput succedaneum.
Option D: Caput succedaneum may be present at birth.

Solution to Question 16:
The given case scenario is suggestive of caput succedaneum which disappears within 2-3 days.
In vertex presentation, labor forces alter the shape of the fetal head. In prolonged labor, before complete cervical dilatation, the portion of the fetal scalp immediately over the cervical os becomes edematous. A swelling is formed is due to the stagnation of fluid in the layers of the scalp beneath the girdle of contact. This is known as caput succedaneum.
The swelling is diffuse, boggy, and not limited by the suture lines. It resolves spontaneously within 2-3 days after birth. It is a result of the static position of the head for a long period of time.
Chignon is a type of artificial caput succedaneum, which is a swelling produced on the fetal head because of the scalp getting sucked into the cup during vacuum extraction.

Solution to Question 1:
The normal human placenta is discoid, deciduate, and hemochorial.
The term deciduate means that the placenta is shed at the time of parturition. Hemochorial means that the maternal blood directly comes in contact with the fetal trophoblasts.
The image given below shows a normal human placenta.

Solution to Question 2:
A placental cotyledon is comprised of portions of the basal plate divided by clefts. It is the functional unit of the placenta.
A placental cotyledon or placental lobule constitutes one truncal or main stem villi and its ramifications (rami). Each lobule is supplied by a single truncal branch of the chorionic artery. Each lobule also has a single vein. The lobules constitute functional units of placental architecture.
The fetal surface is the chorionic plate. The umbilical cord inserts in the center of the chorionic plate.
Note: The entire placenta is supplied by chorionic villi while each cotyledon is only supplied by a single main stem villus with its branches.


Solution to Question 3:
Maternal leucopenia is not seen in pregnancy, instead leucocytosis is seen. This plays no part in the prevention of rejection of fetus.
The fetus is a semiallogenic graft inside the maternal body as half of its genes are from the father. Uterine transplantation immunity contributes to the survival of the fetus in spite of it being semiallogenic. This occurs due to the following factors:
Decidual natural killer cells are inefficient, and therefore are unable to attack the 'foreign' fetal cells.
Decidual stromal cells work with natural killer cells to allow trophoblastic invasion.
Villous trophoblastic cells don't express HLA antigens and therefore, they are non-immunogenic.
Solution to Question 4:
At 17 weeks, the weights of the fetus and placenta are equal.
In the first trimester, the placental growth is more rapid than that of the fetus. By approximately 17 weeks, the placental weight and fetal weight are almost equal. And by term, placental weight is approximately 1/6th of the fetal weight.
Solution to Question 5:
The uteroplacental blood flow at term is 500-750 ml/min.
Solution to Question 6:
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) does not cause involution of the corpus luteum, but it maintains corpus luteum function.
hCG is produced by the syncitiotrophoblasts of the placenta. It is a glycoprotein hormone with two subunits. The alpha-subunit is similar to LH, FSH and TSH. The beta-subunit is specific and is measured by pregnancy tests.
hCG can be detected in maternal blood 8 days after fertilisation. Thus, it can help in diagnosis of pregnancy even before the period is missed. Its levels nearly doubles every 48 hours in early pregnancy reaching a maximum of 50000 - 100000 IU/L by 60-70 days of gestation. Then the level starts falling reaching a minimum at 16 weeks, which continues throughout pregnancy.

GnRH, TRH, GHRH, Growth hormone variant (hGH-V)

Solution to Question 8:
The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion.
Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:
Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage.
Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are:
Preterm delivery
Abortions
IUGR
Antepartum hemorrhage
Retained placenta and membranes


Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins.
Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.
Solution to Question 9:
The given image shows a placenta with a small, accessory lobe. This condition is known as placenta succenturiata.
A succenturiate placenta contains single or multiple accessory lobes. Accessory lobes are attached to the main lobe by a membrane that has a leash of blood vessels.
Option A: Bilobate placenta - it consists of two placental lobes. The cord inserts between the two lobes.
Option C: Placenta membranacea - entire surface of the fetal membranes are covered by functioning villi and the placenta develops as a thin membranous structure occupying the entire periphery of the chorion.
Option D: Placenta marginata - chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate, and a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario of the presence of an accessory placental lobe is suggestive of placenta succenturiata. Preterm delivery is not a complication seen in this condition.
Complications of placenta succenturiata include:
Retained placenta
Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)
Subinvolution of uterus
Sepsis
Placental polyp formatio
Vasa previa - vessels overlying the accessory lobes can cross the cervix. Their rupture can lead to hemorrhage from the fetus
Note: Preterm delivery is a complication associated with circumvallate placenta.
Solution to Question 11:
The given image shows placenta increta.
Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types:
Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be:
Total - involving all lobules of the placenta
Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta
Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

Solution to Question 12:
Ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma contributes to the formation of amniotic fluid during early pregnancy.
Amniotic fluid is formed by:
Early pregnancy - ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma.
Second trimester - the extracellular fluid that diffuses through the fetal skin and thus reflects the composition of fetal plasma.
After 20 weeks - keratinization of fetal skin prevents diffusion across the skin. Hence, fetal urine forms amniotic fluid.
Note: Fetal kidneys start producing urine at 12 weeks (8–11 weeks), and by 18 weeks, they produce 7 to 14 mL per day.
Solution to Question 13:
The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is a measure of the amniotic volume which is maximum at 34 weeks of gestation.
The volume of amniotic fluid at each week is variable. The volume gradually increases till 32-34 weeks of gestation. At 34 weeks, it is maximum and thereafter there is a gradual reduction till term.
Amniotic fluid volume is a passive reflector of the fetal condition. Its volume is determined by the following:
Any alteration in fetal homeostasis, caused by fetal and maternal conditions, affects the amniotic fluid volume. Thus, AFI is measured as a part of the biophysical score.

Solution to Question 14:
The nutritive value of amniotic fluid is negligible because amniotic fluid is predominantly water. It contains the following:
Water - 98–99%
Solids 1–2% - Organic, inorganic, suspended particles Functions of amniotic fluid during pregnancy:
It acts as a shock absorber and prevents trauma to the fetus
Temperature regulation of the uterine environment
It distends the amniotic sac and thereby allows for growth and free movement of the fetus.
It has no nutritive function, as it is mostly formed by water.
Bacteriostatic property
Functions of amniotic fluid during labor:
The amnion and chorion are combined to form a hydrostatic wedge which helps in dilatation of the cervix.
During uterine contraction, it prevents any interference in placental circulation so long as the membranes remain intact.
It protects the umbilical cord by providing a cushion between the fetus and the umbilical cord during contractio
It flushes the birth canal at the end of the first stage of labor and by its aseptic action protects the fetus and prevents ascending infection to the uterine cavity.
Solution to Question 15:
Keratinization of fetal skin occurs at 22–25 weeks. Therefore, diffusion across fetal skin does not occur after this period. So fetal plasma does not contribute to amniotic fluid formation after this time period.
Solution to Question 16:
The composition of amniotic fluid is not the same throughout pregnancy but changes later in pregnancy due to contamination by fetal urinary metabolites.
In early pregnancy, it is identical to plasma in composition as it is mainly composed of a transudate of plasma. In late pregnancy, as amniotic fluid is primarily formed by fetal urination, the composition is altered. Disorders of the fetal kidney can lead to oligohydramnios.
Fetal swallowing is the primary method of resorption of amniotic fluid. Disorders of swallowing in the fetus can cause polyhydramnios.
Amniotic fluid is alkaline in nature and this helps in differentiating it from vaginal secretions which are acidic. This forms the basis of the nitrazine paper test used for the diagnosis
of premature rupture of membranes.
Solution to Question 17:
Golden-colored amniotic fluid is seen in Rh incompatibility. This appearance is due to presence of excess bilirubin in the amniotic fluid due to hemolysis of fetal RBCs.

Solution to Question 18:
Among the given options, an AFI of 4.5cm (<5cm) or an SDP of 1.8cm (<2cm) indicate oligohydramnios.
Oligohydramnios means an abnormally decreased amount of amniotic fluid (liquor volume is
<200ml). It is diagnosed using ultrasound parameters such as:
Single deepest pocket (SDP) - The largest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid identified in the sagittal plane on ultrasound is the SDP. The normal range of SDP is between 2 to
8cm. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed if SDP < 2cm.
Amniotic fluid index (AFI) - It is the sum of the deepest pocket of amniotic fluid from each quadrant of the abdomen. The normal range of AFI is between 5 to 25 cm. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed if AFI < 5cm.

Polyhydramnios is an abnormal increase in amniotic fluid. It is defined as the presence of amniotic fluid volume >2000ml. Ultrasound parameters used to diagnose polyhydramnios are:
AFI > 25 cm
SDP > 8 cm
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of polyhydramnios. It can be seen with a fetus having a cleft palate as fetal swallowing is impaired by this anomaly.
Polyhydramnios has the following features:
Fundal height greater than period of gestatio
Fetal parts are not well palpable
AFI >25cm

The given case scenario is suggestive of polyhydramnios. Preeclampsia is a cause for oligohydramnios, and not polyhydramnios.
Solution to Question 23:
The given case scenario is suggestive of polyhydramnios associated with respiratory distress. In such cases, therapeutic amniocentesis termed amnioreduction is done.
Amnioreduction helps in polyhydramnios by:
Relieving respiratory distress by reducing mechanical pressure on the diaphragm
May improve obstructive uropathy
May lower the preterm delivery risk if the patient has preterm labor or premature rupture of membranes
Option A: Diuretics have no role in this condition.
Option B: Indomethacin therapy used to be given earlier as it reduced amnionic fluid volume. However, it is not given anymore due to the risk of premature closure of ductus arteriosus.
Option D: Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is avoided as:
It cannot be employed in a patient with an unfavourable cervix.
Once ARM is done, delivery needs to be performed. In this case, preterm delivery would occur, hence ARM is avoided.
ARM should be used with caution in patients with chronic polyhydramnios. It can lead to sudden decompression of the uterus causing placental abruption. Thus, controlled ARM is done i these patients.
Solution to Question 24:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fetal compromise. The management in this patient is immediate termination of pregnancy. Since this pregnancy has crossed 34 weeks, it can
be terminated by cesarean section.
Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:
Reduced end-diastolic flow indicates uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)
Absent end-diastolic flow suggests fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >34 weeks.
Reverse end-diastolic flow suggests impending doom of death, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

Solution to Question 25:
The umbilical cord normally has two arteries and one vein. The presence of a single umbilical artery is the most common vascular anomaly of the cord. It is associated with congenital anomalies such as genitourinary and cardiac anomalies.
The umbilical cord is a tube that connects the fetus to the placenta. It contains umbilical vessels and an obliterated allantois duct, all surrounded by Wharton's jelly and contained within an outer layer of amnion. Maternal blood enters the fetus through the umbilical vein, and blood exits the fetus via the two umbilical arteries. Wharton's jelly is a gelatinous mucopolysaccharide that protects the umbilical vessels. Local collections of Wharton's jelly produce false knots in the cord.
The average length of the umbilical cord is between 40-70 cm at term. A long cord can form a loop around the fetus' neck and can cause asphyxia. A short cord can result in cord rupture during labor.
Solution to Question 26:
A single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. It indicates an increased risk of congenital malformations in the fetus.
A single umbilical artery is seen in the following conditions:
Twin pregnancy
Gestational diabetes/Overt diabetes
Epilepsy
Oligohydramnios
Polyhydramnios
Preeclampsia
Antepartum hemorrhage
It is frequently associated with congenital malformations of the fetus (20–25%) such as:
Cardiovascular anomalies
Genitourinary anomalies
Trisomy 18
It increases the risks of adverse obstetric outcomes like:
Abortio
Fetal aneuploidy
Prematurity
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Perinatal mortality

Solution to Question 1:
The sex of the fetus is determined by Yp11, which is a region present on the short arm of the Y chromosome.
It contains the SRY gene, which produces the protein called the testis determining factor. This causes the gonads to develop into the testes. The target gene for SRY which favours testis differentiation is SOX9.
If SRY gene or Y chromosome are absent, the gonads develop as ovaries. The genes that favor this are:
WnT4
Rspo
DAX1
Solution to Question 2:
Sexual differentiation of the fetus occurs only after the 7th week of development.
The chromosomal and genetic sex of an embryo is determined at fertilization by the kind of sperm that fertilizes the ovum (X or Y). However, male and female morphological characteristics begin developing after the 7th week. At the end of the 6th week of development, it is impossible to distinguish between the two sexes.
Solution to Question 3:
The lower part of the vagina is derived from the urogenital sinus. Option A: The ovary and the testis are derived from the genital ridge.
Option C: The upper part of the vagina is derived from the paramesonephric duct or Mullerian duct. The uterus develops from the fusion of the right and left paramesonephric ducts in the midline.
Option D: The labia minora and the ventral aspect of the penis are derived from the urogenita folds.

Solution to Question 4:
The vaginal epithelium is derived from the epithelium of the urogenital sinus. The epithelium of urogenital sinus is formed by the endoderm.
›ote: Urogenital sinus epithelium stains positive for FOXA1, and Mullerian duct epithelium stains positive for PAXè. In è017, immunohistochemical testing done on embryos revealed vagina epithelium showed positive immunostaining for both FOXA1 and PAXè.
Solution to Question 5:
The round ligament in women is homologous to gubernaculum testis in men. Homologous structures are those that have the same embryological origin.
Solution to Question 6:
The Gartner's duct is not derived from the paramesonephric duct. It is a remnant of the mesonephric/ Wolffian duct.
Solution to Question 7:
The most common developmental abnormality of the uterus is septate uterus, followed by bicornuate uterus.
Solution to Question 8:
In a hysterosalpingogram, the uterine anomaly cannot be determined as the external contour of the uterus cannot be seen.
Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity. However, it doesn't show the external contour, so it cannot distinguish between uterine anomalies such as didelphys, bicornuate, septate or arcuate uteruses.
Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV-US) is very accurate for the diagnosis and differentiation of uterine anomalies. It is the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.
Pelvic MRI without contrast provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV-US is not possible.
Solution to Question 9:
Ultrasonography (USG) is performed to confirm a diagnosis of uterus didelphys.
Uterine didelphis is a congenital condition that occurs when the incomplete fusion of Mullerian ducts that form the uterus during embryonic development leads to the development of two separate uterine cavities and two cervices, each with its own set of endometrial lining.
It is commonly associated with renal anomalies such as unilateral renal agenesis, severe renal hypoplasia, etc, and is often associated with recurrent pregnancy loss, preterm labour, malpresentation, and prematurity.

Hysterosalpingography (Option C) shows only the internal contour, making it unable to distinguish between conditions like didelphys, bicornuate, septate, or arcuate uterus.

The USG findings in didelphys uterus are two widely separated uterine horns and a deep fundal indentation.
çaparoscopy and hysteroscopy, being invasive diagnostic procedures, should be reserved for cases where simultaneous surgical treatment is planned following a comprehensive non-invasive assessment of a Mullerian anomaly. (Option A)
Intravenous pyelography is used to diagnose congenital renal anomalies. (Option B)

Solution to Question 10:
Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving obstetric outcomes.
Metroplasty is the surgical resection of the intrauterine septum. This is done by approaching the uterus transabdominally via 3 methods:
‘ones metroplasty
Strassmann metroplasty
Tompkins metroplasty
All of these methods are not preferred nowadays as they cause uterine scarring.
Solution to Question 11:
The sequence of pubertal changes in girls is thelarche  pubarche  menarche.
Puberty marks the normal physiologic transition from childhood to sexual and reproductive maturity. The order of changes in puberty are:
Thelarche - It refers to breast budding, and is the first visible sign. It indicates the competency of the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis. It appears between the age of 9-11 years, and is described using Tanner staging.
Adrenarche - It refers to the generation of androgens (estrogen and testosterone) from the adrenal gland.
Pubarche - It refers to the development of pubic hair, and occurs usually 6 months after thelarche. It is also described using Tanner staging.
Menarche - It refers to the first occurrence of menstruation. Growth spurt usually occurs between ages 10.5 to 13.5 years.
Solution to Question 12:
Pubarche or the development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes. Around 50% of testosterone comes from the ovaries and the rest from the adrenal gland.
Puberty in girls involves breast development (thelarche), an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche), and the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche).
Estrogen has the following actions during puberty:
Breast development
Development of the reproductive tract
Starting of menstruation (option D)
Increased fat in the hips
Regulation of pubertal growth spurt
Vaginal cornification (option C)
Cervical mucus production (option B)
Epiphyseal closure
Maintenance of bone formation - acts against parathyroid hormone.

The growth spurt in girls overtakes that of boys for 1-è years and reaches a plateau. In boys, the growth spurt starts later and continues for a longer duration. As a result, boys grow taller than girls in terms of final height.

Since the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis is maturing, initial cycles are
anovulatory. Therefore, the pattern of bleeding is irregular. Also, as the endometrium is under the prolonged influence of estrogen, it gets thickened more than normal. Shedding of this thickened endometrium leads to prolonged bleeding.

Precocious puberty is considered if breast development or onset of puberty occurs in children less than 8 years of age.

Solution to Question 22:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.
The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.
The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:
Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.
Management:
Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.
Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.
Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. çarger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.
Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexa masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

Gonadal dysgenesis is the most frequent cause of premature ovarian failure. In this disorder, a normal complement of germ cells is present in the early fetal ovary. However, oocytes undergo accelerated atresia, and the ovary is replaced by a fibrous streak. This is called a streak gonad.

Solution to Question 6:
The maternal plasma prolactin level is highest at term and reduces after delivery. Despite this high level, milk secretion does not occur during pregnancy due to the action of estrogen and
progesterone.
Prolactin secretion returns to the nonpregnant level a few weeks after delivery. The levels of estrogen and progesterone fall and hence, prolactin can promote milk secretion even at a lesser concentration.
Solution to Question 7:
In the first two months of pregnancy, estrogen and progesterone are produced by the corpus luteum.
It functions maximally during the second month of pregnancy and thereafter contributes relatively little. Estrogen is synthesized in the placenta from the 7th week and progesterone from the 8th week.
Solution to Question 8:
Total T3 levels are altered throughout pregnancy.
Total T3 and total T4 increase due to stimulation of thyroid tissue by hCG during the early period of gestation. However, there is no change in free T3 and T4 due to an increase in thyroid-binding globulin (TBG).
This leads to a transient fall in TSH during the early weeks of gestation. The level of TSH becomes normal during the second and third trimester.

Solution to Question 9:
Relaxin is not synthesised by the fetal adrenal gland in a pregnant woman. It is synthesised by corpus luteum, decidua and placenta.
Relaxin is a placental protein hormone. Plasma levels peak between 8 and 12 weeks of gestation and decline thereafter to lower levels that persist until term.
Functions of relaxin are:
Relaxation of myometrium and quiescence of early pregnancy
Enhancement of the glomerular filtration rate
Endometrial vascular remodelling by inducing secretion of VEGF
Solution to Question 10:
Among the given features hypothyroidism is not a major physiological change in pregnancy.
The  -subunits of hCG and TSH are identical. An increase in hCG during pregnancy stimulates thyroid and leads to a decrease in TSH levels. The thyroid undergoes enlargement and boosts the production of hormones. This is accompanied by increased production of thyroid-binding globulin(TBG). All these changes increase total T4 and T3 in the first trimester. But the physiologically important free T4 and T3 levels remain unchanged. Hence, physiologically pregnant women remain euthyroid.
Option A: Normal pregnancy is characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Human placental lactogen(hPL) secreted during pregnancy, helps in adaptation to fetal energy requirements. Insulin resistance causes prolonged hyperglycemia and glucose flow to the fetus. It also favours protein synthesis. To counterbalance the increased insulin resistance and prevent maternal hyperglycemia, maternal insulin levels are increased.
Option B: By the 3rd trimester, there is an increase in the maternal basal metabolic rate by 10 to 20% in comparison to a nonpregnant woman.
Option D: During normal pregnancy, mean arterial pressure and vascular resistance decrease, while blood volume and cardiac output rate increase. This helps in meeting metabolic demands of the enlarged uterus, provide nutrients to rapidly growing placenta and fetus, safeguard mother against the effects of parturition-associated blood loss.
Solution to Question 11:
hCG is not implicated in insulin resistance during pregnancy.
As the fetus is dependant on maternal glucose for sustenance, the blood glucose levels are maintained at a high level in the mother. In response to this, the insulin level in the mother increases, which reduces the maternal blood glucose. To counteract this, the placenta secretes certain hormones which increase insulin resistance in the mother. This resistance is maximal between 24 to 28 weeks.
Hormones increasing insulin resistance include:
Human placental lactogen - Increases lipolysis and liberation of free fatty acids
Progesterone and estrogen
Placental growth hormone - Major determinant of maternal insulin resistance after mid-pregnancy
Cortiso
Prolactin

Solution to Question 13:
The total oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood increases during pregnancy.
During pregnancy, there is an increase in total haemoglobin (Hb) resulting in increased total oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. However, there is a relative decrease in Hb concentration (hematocrit) due to a greater increase in plasma volume. This decreases oxygen-carrying capacity per unit volume of blood.
Maternal iron stores are not sufficient to meet the increased demand during pregnancy and hence the serum iron and ferritin concentration falls.
The plasma volume expansion also lowers serum potassium.

Decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is a physiological change seen in pregnancy. Cardiovascular parameters that increase in pregnancy are:
Cardiac output
Stroke volume
Heart rate
Cardiovascular parameters that decrease in pregnancy are:
Peripheral vascular resistance (due to smooth muscle relaxation by progesterone)
Both diastolic BP and systolic BP (decrease in DBP > SBP)
Mean arterial BP
Artery venous O2 gradient
Solution to Question 15:
The clinical features are suggestive of physiological edema during pregnancy for which the most appropriate treatment is bed rest.
It occurs due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac veins.
Features of physiological edema in pregnancy are:
Slight degree of ankle edema
Usually confined to one leg, more commonly the right leg
Not associated with any other features of preeclampsia (like BP>140/90mm Hg, proteinuria)
Disappears with rest
Other cardiac, renal and hematological pathologies are absent
Solution to Question 16:
The blood flow to the skin and mucous membranes increases during pregnancy to a maximum of 500 mL/min by the 36th week. Symptoms experienced during pregnancy such as increased heat sensation, sweating or having a stuffy nose can be explained by the increased blood flow.
Regional distribution of blood flow during pregnancy:
Uterine blood flow - increased from 50 mL/min in the non-pregnant state to about 750 mL near term.
Pulmonary blood flow - increased by 2,500 mL/min.
Renal blood flow - increases by 400 mL/min at 16th week and remains at this level till term.
Solution to Question 17:
S3 is normally heard during pregnancy.
The third heart sound (S3) occurs due to rapid diastolic filling in hypervolemic states such as pregnancy, anemia or thyrotoxicosis. Hypervolemia is a normal physiological change during pregnancy.
The auscultation of a fixed split S2, fourth heart sound (S4) or a pericardial knock are suggestive of cardiac pathology.
Solution to Question 18:
All clotting factors increase in pregnancy except factors XI and XIII. Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state with physiological changes such as:
All clotting factors are increased (except factors XI and XIII)
Fibrinogen levels are also increased
The viscosity of blood decreases due to hemodilution
Clotting time and bleeding time is unaffected
The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and the women are generally asymptomatic.
Solution to Question 19:
The clinical features are suggestive of supine hypotension syndrome due to inferior vena caval compression.
During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava (IVC) when the patient is in the supine position. To compensate, there will be an opening up of the collaterals of paravertebral and azygous veins.
When collaterals fail to open, venous return of the heart is reduced leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position.
Solution to Question 20:
The sensitivity of uterine musculature is enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone.
Estrogen stimulates the synthesis of myometrial contractile proteins through cAMP. This increases the excitability of uterine muscles and the frequency of action potentials.
Progesterone decreases the frequency and intensity of uterine contractions. This helps to prevent the expulsion of the implanted ovum. However, it increases the amplitude of contraction.
Solution to Question 21:
Extension at the knee joint and dorsiflexion at the ankle joint helps in stretching the calf muscles which relieves the pain.
Leg cramps are minor ailments during pregnancy mostly due to a deficiency of diffusible serum calcium or elevation of serum phosphorus. Management includes massaging the leg, stretching exercises, application of local heat, and supplementation of vitamin B1 and calcium.
Solution to Question 22:
Theca lutein cysts are not seen in hyperprolactinemia.
Theca-lutein cysts are benign ovarian lesions resulting from exaggerated physiological follicle stimulation. They are usually associated with markedly elevated serum levels of hCG.
Theca lutein cysts are found in association with:
Large placenta
Diabetes
Anti-D alloimmunization
Multifetal gestations
Fetal hydrops
Gestational trophoblastic disease - Molar pregnancy
Reduced hCG clearance - Chronic renal failure
They may also be found in normal pregnancy due to an exaggerated response of the ovaries to normal circulating levels of hCG.
Solution to Question 23:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) occurs most commonly in the third trimester or early postpartum period.
Risk factors include Pre-eclampsia/HELLP syndrome, male fetus, previous history of AFLP, and multiple gestations.
AFLP (acute yellow atrophy or acute fatty metamorphosis) is the most common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in
the third trimester. It occurs due to fetal deficiency of long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (LCHAD) or poor placental mitochondrial function.
The patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice, and epigastric pain. Features like acute hemolysis, hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, thrombocytopenia, and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.
Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. Hypofibrinogenemia, hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting time can be seen. An elevated d-dimer is
seen. Microscopy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.
The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. A trial of labor by induction or delivery by Cesarean is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood transfusion should be provided.
The clinical and laboratory findings of acute liver diseases in pregnancy are as follows:
The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. Appropriate management is immediate termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestational age by induction or delivery by Cesarean (for obstetric reasons) is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood transfusion should be provided.

Solution to Question 1:
The duration of the fourth trimester is 12 weeks postpartum.
The concept of fourth trimester was introduced to address common concerns raised by women in puerperium such as post-partum pain, breastfeeding related problems, stress and postpartum depression, and lack of awareness of newborn care. The components of postpartum care for the 4th trimester include:
Dedicated care team
Lactation support
Infant feeding plan
Reproductive life plan
Contraception
Addressing complications of pregnancy
Assessment of cardiovascular risk
Mental health assessment
Chronic health conditions
ACOG recommendation for postpartum visits:
Initial visit: 3 weeks postpartum
Final visit: 12 weeks postpartum
Government of India recommendation for postpartum visits.
First visit: 1st day after delivery
Second visit: 3rd day after delivery
Third visit: 7th day after delivery
Fourth visit: 6 weeks after delivery
Solution to Question 2:
The ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14.
The antenatal visits should ideally be: monthly once up to 28 weeks, once in two weeks between 28-36 weeks, and once weekly visits from 36 weeks onwards.
This translates to a total of 12-15 visits.
The WHO increased the minimum number of antenatal visits from 4 to 8 visits to reduce perinatal mortality.
In the Indian scenario, the earlier minimum of 4 visits were implemented as follows:
subject: OBGYN

Solution to Question 3:
If a female has stillbirth, her parity does not decrease.
Parity is determined by the number of previous pregnancies reaching a period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India.
Multifetal pregnancies, such as twins or triplets, count as one for the purpose of this notation. The current pregnancy is not included in this count.
Multipara refers to a woman who has completed two or more pregnancies past the period of viability. When the pregnancy is preceded by five or more previous viable pregnancies, the woman is called a grand multipara.
Note: Gravida indicates the number of times the mother has been pregnant, regardless of whether these pregnancies were carried to term. The current pregnancy is included in this count.
Solution to Question 4:
The obstetric score is G4 P1 A2 L1.
The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows:
G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability
This includes both live births and stillbirths
The current pregnancy is not included
A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages.
L - Living children
Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers twins will be expressed as primipara.
The GTPAL system includes the following:
Gravida
Term (>37 weeks)
Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
Abortions (<20 weeks)
Number of living children
Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.
Solution to Question 5:
The woman has had two pregnancies in total - the previous twin pregnancy and the current pregnancy, hence the gravida score is 2. The first pregnancy resulted in delivery at term (crossed viable period), hence her para score is 1 (parity doesn't include current pregnancy). Hence, her obstetric score would be G2P1 (Gravida - 2, Para - 1).
Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers twins for the first time is expressed as primipara.
The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows:
G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability. This includes both live births and stillbirths. The current pregnancy is not included.
A - Abortion is the termination of pregnancy, either spontaneous or induced, before fetal viability.
L - Living children.
The GTPAL system includes the following:
Gravida
Term (>37 weeks)
Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
Abortions (<20 weeks)
Number of living children
Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.
Solution to Question 6:
As per Naegele’s rule, the EDD (expected date of delivery) of this woman is October 16, 2017.
Naegele’s rule states that EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the LMP (the 1st day of the last menstrual period). Another method is adding 9 months and 7
days to LMP. Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule.
It is based on a 28-day regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated as follows:
For a 35-day cycle, add another 7 (35-28=7) days to the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.
For a 25-day cycle, subtract 3 (28-25=3) days from the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.
Naegele’s rule cannot be followed in IVF pregnancies. Considering the human embryo takes 266 days to develop, EDD is calculated in IVF pregnancies by the following method:
Same day as fertilization (day 0): EDD = date of transfer + 266 days

The recommended calorie intake for a pregnant woman in the second trimester would increase by

Solution to Question 8:
The pregnant lady can continue the same diet since there are no additional calorie requirements in the first trimester.
Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 kcal, mostly during the last 20 weeks. To meet this demand, a caloric increase of 100 to 300 kcal/d is recommended during pregnancy. This greater intake, however, should not be divided equally during the course of pregnancy. The Institute of Medicine (2006) recommends adding 0, 340, and 452 kcal/d to the estimated nonpregnant energy requirements in the first, second, and third trimesters respectively.
Whenever caloric intake is inadequate, protein is metabolized rather than being spared for its vital role in fetal growth and development.
Solution to Question 9:
In the given clinical case, the patient should be advised to continue the pregnancy.
The radiation dose to the fetus during the declared term of pregnancy should be less than 1 mSv. In chest X-ray PA view, the absorbed dose of radiation by the fetus is less than 0.1 mSv. Hence, pregnancy can be continued.
An X-ray has a very limited role in obstetric imaging. There are very few indications where an X-ray will be useful:
Fetal: congenital malformation of the fetus and neonates, skeletal malformations, birth injuries like fractures or dislocations.
Maternal: Patients having cardiopulmonary disease may require an X-ray chest during pregnancy and that should be done beyond 12 weeks.
Radiation can cause fetal morbidity (FGR, genetic mutations, neurologic abnormalities, mental retardation, childhood leukemia) and mortality. The risks are high with radiation after the first 2 weeks postconception and within the first trimester (period of organogenesis).
Radiation during pregnancy can damage the early phase of the embryo but the risk can be minimized by using the ‘10-day rule’. This rule states that no woman should be exposed to an X-ray for a nonurgent indication outside 10 days from her last period during the reproductive period unless the pregnancy is excluded.

Solution to Question 10:
Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's manoeuvres:
Fundal grip (first Leopold):
Assesses the uterine fundus.
Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass.
The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.
Lateral grip (second Leopold):
Assesses the fetal orientation.
The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.
Pawlik's grip / 1st pelvic grip (third Leopold):
Assesses the presenting part in respect to the true pelvis.
The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.
Deep pelvic grip / 2nd pelvic grip (fourth Leopold):
Assesses the engagement, attitude of the fetal head and determine the degree of descent.
The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part.
They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.
If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by the neck may be differentiated readily from the head.
It is the only grip performed facing the feet.

Solution to Question 14:
+1 station of the fetal head refers to it being just below the ischial spine.
The station of the head is expressed in relation to ischial spines as they are the most prominent bony projections felt on internal examination. The level of ischial spines is halfway between the pelvic inlet and outlet. This level is known as station zero (0).
The station is stated in minus figures if it is above the spines (–1 cm, –2 cm, –3 cm, –4 cm and –5 cm) and in plus figures if it is below the spines (+1 cm, +2 cm, +3 cm, +4 cm and +5 cm).

Preconceptional intake of vitamin B9 (folic acid) results in decreased incidence of neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.
All women of reproductive age should be given 400 µg of folic acid daily. Women, who had fetal neural tube defects in the previous pregnancy, should be given 4 mg of folic acid daily beginning 1 month before conception to about 12 weeks of pregnancy.

Decreased levels of beta-hCG are found in:

Solution to Question 1:
Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is used for the screening of trisomy 13, 18 and 21 and Turner's syndrome. It is not a diagnostic test.
It is a novel genetic test that uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum for screening of chromosomal anomalies.
DNA from the fetus is found circulating in the maternal blood in two forms - either inside the intact fetal cells or as cell-free DNA from the breakdown of placental fetal cells. In NIPT, the cell-free chromosome fragments are measured and the quantitative differences from normal fetuses are noted.
NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation and is recommended after the routine
first-trimester ultrasound assessment in high-risk pregnancies or if either 1st or 2nd-trimester screening becomes positive. Its disadvantage is that it is very expensive and it can be used for screening of only a few chromosomal anomalies such as trisomy 13, 18, and 21 and it doesn't analyse the entire karyotype.
Solution to Question 2:
The triple test findings in pregnancies with fetal Down’s syndrome are characterized by:
Low MSAFP (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein) levels, approximately 0.7 MoM (multiples of median).
Low unconjugated estriol levels, approximately 0.8 MoM.
High hCG levels, approximately 2.0 MoM.
The triple test is done between 15-18 weeks for the diagnosis of Down's syndrome.
Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:
First-trimester screening with biochemical analytes () PAPP-A and () hCG and USG measurement of NT () can improve the detection rate (87%) of Down’s syndrome. For confirmation, a prenatal genetic study (CVS, amniocentesis or cordo■centesis) has to be performed.
Second-trimester screening (quad screening) at 15–18 weeks: () MSAFP, () uE3, () inhibin A and () hCG can detect trisomy 21 in 85% of cases with a false-positive rate of 0.9%. When it is combined with first-trimester screening, the detection rate is increased to 95%.

Solution to Question 7:
The next best step is targeted sonography. Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels are only used as a screening test and must be followed by a diagnostic test.
Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for amniotic fluid AFP measurement. It was once considered the standard for the diagnosis of open neural tube disorders but has been replaced in most centers by targeted sonography.
Defects in fetal integuments, such as ventral wall and neural tube defects, permit fetal AFP to leak into the amnionic fluid. This results in increased MSAFP levels. This is detected on screening performed from 15 to 20 weeks of gestation.
Conditions with elevated MSAFP:
Wrong gestational age
Neural tube defects
Multiple pregnancies
Renal anomalies
Conditions with decreased MSAFP:
Trisomies (Down's syndrome)
Gestational trophoblastic disease.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the major serum protein in the embryo and fetus. It is produced by the yolk sac and fetal liver.
Option B: Diabetic patients have low levels of AFP.
Option C: Gestational age influences the MSAFP levels. The maternal serum concentration increases by approximately 15% per week during the second trimester.
Option D: At about 13 weeks of gestation, the AFP concentration in the fetal serum and amniotic fluid are highest, after which it declines. Conversely, AFP is found in steadily increasing quantities in maternal serum after 12 weeks.

Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario is suggestive of fetal hypoxia. Late decelerations are seen on an NST in this condition.
Deceleration is a decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15 seconds. Absent variability of FHR with late decelerations is an indication for immediate Cesarean section.

Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario along with the NST showing a sinusoidal pattern point towards a diagnosis of vasa previa.
Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture.
Fetal mortality is high due to fetal exsanguination. When bleeding is present in vasa previa, an emergency cesarean section is indicated.
Causes of sinusoidal pattern on NST include:
Severe fetal anemia - Rh isoimmunisation, vasa previa, fetomaternal hemorrhage, or twin to twin transfusion
Opioids - meperidine, morphine, alphaprodine, butorphano
Amnionitis
Fetal distress
Umbilical cord occlusion.

Solution to Question 1:
Amniotic fluid volume is assessed on ultrasound in the second and third trimesters. Ultrasonographic evaluation during the first trimester includes:
Gestational sac size, location, and number
Embryo and/or yolk sac identification
Crown-rump length
Fetal number, including amnionicity and chorionicity of multifetal gestations
Embryonic/fetal cardiac activity
Maternal uterus, adnexa, and cul-de-sac
Fetal nuchal translucency.
Solution to Question 2:
In the second trimester, the parameter to assess gestational age most accurately is the biparietal diameter (BPD). Accuracy varies from 7 to 10 days.
BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner edge of the skull in the far field.
Trimes ter
Parameter

Second

Third
