Solution to Question 3:
The red arrowhead represents the yolk sac. The yellow arrowhead shows the double ring - outer decidua parietalis and inner decidua capsularis.
It is referred to as the double decidua sign and is seen in the first trimester transvaginal sonogram. It is useful to confirm an early intrauterine location for the pregnancy.

Solution to Question 4:
Head circumference (HC) is measured from the transthalamic view by placing an ellipse around the outer edge of the skull
HC can also be calculated from the biparietal diameter (BPD) and occipital-frontal diameter
(OFD).

Solution to Question 5:
The normal range for the femoral length (FL) to abdominal circumference (AC) ratio is 20-24 percent.
Low FL/AC (< 16) ratio suggests a lethal skeletal dysplasia, particularly if other skeletal abnormalities are present.
Solution to Question 6:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts reversal of end-diastolic flow or REDF (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. As the period of gestation has exceeded 32 weeks, the pregnancy can be terminated.
In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but don't appear below it. This suggests a fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >34 weeks.
Reversed end-diastolic flow (REDF) suggests impending fetal death, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

Solution to Question 7:
The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound is the highest in the first trimester and decreases afterwards.
Option A: Gestational sac is reliably seen at 5 weeks of gestation on transvaginal sonography(TVS).
Option C: The first sign of pregnancy seen on sonography is the gestational sac. Visualisation of the yolk sac within the gestational sac confirms an intrauterine location for pregnancy.
Option D: A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium, whereas a pseudosac is seen in the midline of the endometrial cavity.
Solution to Question 8:
Nuchal translucency evaluation, a component of first-trimester aneuploidy screening, is done between 11-14 weeks.
It represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue, overlying the fetal spine, at the back of the neck. When the nuchal translucency is increased, the risk of fetal aneuploidy and structural anomalies such as heart defects is significantly elevated.
First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes and a sonographic measurement:
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)
Nuchal translucency (NT)
It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum-free -hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.
Note: Nuchal fold is a normal fold of skin seen at the back of the fetal neck during the second trimester of pregnancy. Increased nuchal fold thickness is associated with fetal aneuploidy.

Solution to Question 9:
Ultrasound markers for Down's syndrome:
First trimester
Nuchal translucency >3 mm
Second trimester
Echogenic intracardiac focus
Ventriculomegaly
Nuchal thickness >6 mm
Echogenic bowe
Hypoplastic/absent nasal bone
Shortened humerus, femur
Mild pylectasis
Aberrant subclavian artery.
Solution to Question 10:
The given image shows banana sign.
An abnormal anterior curvature of cerebellum along with effacement of cisterna magna produces this appearance. It is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation.

Lemon sign: Axial USG image of the fetal head at the level of the biparietal diameter shows inward concavity of both frontal bones instead of the normally seen convexity. This gives the head the appearance of a lemon. It has a strong association with spina bifida and is very useful for detecting this condition.

Solution to Question 11:
The given ultrasound image shows an open defect in the calvaria and skin leading to the exposure of the cranial neural tube. This is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly.
Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly.
Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog.
Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facia appearance.
Neural-tube defects can be prevented with pre-conceptional supplementation of folic acid. A dose of 4 mg daily is recommended in subsequent pregnancies.
The frog eye and showercap signs are shown below:

Option B: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. The images below show the MRI and USG appearance of cystic hygroma, respectively:


Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone.
The image shows a newborn with encephalocele.

Solution to Question 12:
Robert's sign is a gas shadow in the fetal heart. It is seen in fetal demise in utero and may appear as early as 12 hours.
Other sonographic signs seen in fetal demise in utero are:
Absent fetal heartbeat
Absent fetal movements
Occasional findings
Overlapping of skull bones - Spalding's sign
Gross distortion of fetal anatomy (maceration)
Soft tissue edema - skin >5 mm
Echogenic amniotic fluid (fetal demise fragments)
Uncommon findings
Thrombus in fetal heart
Gas shadow in the fetal heart - Robert's sign.

The frequency of trans abdominal transducer is 4-6 megahertz (MHz) since a lower frequency penetrates better.
On the other hand, a vaginal transducer has a frequency of 5-10 megahertz since a higher frequency yields a better image with minimal penetration.

Solution to Question 17:
Absent end diastolic flow indicates fetal compromise in Doppler. Umbilical artery vessels:
They are characterized by forward low-resistance flow.
As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases.
S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases. Abnormal flow patterns in umbilical artery:
Reduced end-diastolic flow - Uteroplacental insufficiency (systolic/diastolic ratio increases)
Absent end-diastolic flow - Fetal compromise (hence pregnancy is terminated by cesarean section if >34 weeks)
Reverse end-diastolic flow - Impending death (pregnancy is terminated irrespective of gestational age)
Doppler of the middle cerebral artery helps in detecting fetal anemia. Increased fetal diastolic flow in the middle cerebral artery with absent diastolic flow in the aorta implies fetal acidemia.

Fetal ejection reflex or Ferguson reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary has been suggested but not proven.
It is seen in stripping/sweeping and artificial rupture of membranes. Both of these are methods of induction of labor. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of

Comparison between two types of placental separation methods:
Brandt Andrew's method or controlled cord traction is a manoeuvre of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labour.
One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fi ngers over the anterior surface of the uterus. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backwar ds and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord.
Type III placenta previa is a type of incomplete or partial central placenta previa. Here, the placenta covers the internal os partially i.e. it covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated.

The cardinal movements of labour are engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension, external rotation, expulsion.
(Mnemonic: Every Day FIRE Raises Extremely)
Every: Engagement
Day: Descent
F: Flexion
IR: Internal rotation
E: Extension

The most common presentation is cephalic and presenting part is vertex. Head enters the pelvis through transverse diameter majorly and left occipito transverse is the commonest fetal position. Internal rotation of fetal head occurs at the level of ischial spine. In a vertex delivery, the baby's head is delivered by extension and in a breech delivery, the baby's head is delivered by flexion.

Internal rotation begins with the occiput turning away from the transverse axis. In
majority, internal rotation is completed by the time the head reaches the pelvic floor. Internal rotation is followed by extension of the head, which is then followed by external rotation.
Rotation occurs earlier in multigravida than primigravida whereas engagement occurs earlier in primigravida than multigravida.

Solution to Question 16:
The practice of guarding the perineum during delivery of the fetal head is part of the WHO management guidelines for the second stage of labor.
The fingers of one hand support the perineum, while the second hand applies pressure to the fetal head to control the speed of crowning. The advantage of this is to prevent perineal tears.
The second stage of labor begins with full dilatation of the cervix and ends with the delivery of the fetus.
The main events include the descent of the fetus (bearing down by the mother, uterine contractions), cardinal movements of labor, and delivery of the fetus.
Management of the second stage of labor:
The most common position used is the dorsal position with the hips flexed, knees flexed and abduction of the thighs. WHO recommends any position of choice including the upright position.
WHO recommendations for the prevention of perineal tears include warm compresses to the perineum, perineal massage, guarding the perineum, and modified Ritgen's maneuver.
Modified Ritgen's maneuver: A sterile towel or pad is held in one hand and placed over the perineum; the other hand applies gentle downward pressure on the occiput to promote flexion and controlled delivery of the head (ensuring the smallest diameter of the head passes through the outlet). Once the occiput is born–with gentle pressure, the head is extended–forehead, nose, and mouth are then delivered.
WHO doesn't recommend fundal pressure and routine episiotomy. Other options:
Option A: A liberal or routine episiotomy is discouraged. Episiotomy is indicated in cases of:
Shoulder dystocia
Breech delivery
Fetal macrosomia
Operative vaginal deliveries
Persistent occiput posterior positions
Option C: Manual techniques, such as massage or application of warm compresses, are recommended for healthy pregnant women requesting pain relief during labor.
Option D: The position that is most comfortable to the mother i.e. upright/squatting position is encouraged. This position gives:
ess discomfort and difficulty in bearing down
ess labor pain
ess perineal/vaginal trauma and wound infections

In the given vertex presentation, the fetal position is right occipitoanterior.
Fetal position refers to the relation of the denominator (arbitrary bony fixed point on the presenting part), with respect to different quadrants of the maternal pelvis. In vertex presentation, the denominator is taken as the occiput (which is close to the triangular posterior fontanelle).
To determine the fetal position the following two steps are followed:
Determine the direction in which the occiput is facing:
Towards the pubic symphysis - occipito-anterior
Towards the sacral promontory - occipito-posterior
Midway between pubic symphysis and sacral promontory - occipito-transverse

During labour, normal uterine contractions are between 190 and 300 MV and at the time of delivery, it is 300 MV.

Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.
This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.
This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

Solution to Question 21:
Pain in the early stage of labor is limited to dermatomes T10-L1. This is of uterine origin.
Pain in the late stage of labour is due to dilatation of cervix and perineal stretching. The nerves carrying the pain include S2,3,4.
Solution to Question 22:
True labor pain is not relieved by enema and sedatives. It is characterized by the following:
Painful uterine contractions at regular intervals
The frequency of contractions increases gradually
The intensity and duration of contractions increase progressively
Associated with 'show'- extrusion of the mucus plug that had previously filled the cervical cana during pregnancy
Progressive effacement and dilatation of the cervix
Progressive descent of the presenting part
Formation of the 'bag of forewaters' i.e., bulging fluid-filled amniotic membrane presenting in front of the fetal head
Not relieved by enema or sedatives
False labour pain is seen more in primigravidae than in parous women. It usually appears prior to the onset of true labor pain by 1 or 2 weeks in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae.
Such pains are probably due to stretching of the cervix and lower uterine segment with consequent irritation of the neighboring ganglia.

Solution to Question 23:
The nerve roots blocked in pudendal nerve block are S2,3,4. It is blocked just above the tip of the ischial spine by piercing the sacrospinous ligament.
Pudendal nerve block can be used for:
Analgesia in the second stage of labor
Episiotomy repair
Pelvic floor relaxation for outlet instrument delivery
Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum
Perineal analgesia prior to application of vacuum/forceps
Pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina. It is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation such as manual extraction of the placenta.
Solution to Question 24:
Pain from the lower third of the vagina is relieved by pudendal block, not paracervical block.
Paracervical block relieves the pain of uterine contractions and cervical dilatation. It also relieves pain from upper third of the vagina. It is not useful at the time of episiotomy as the lower part of the vagina is not anesthetized.
Note: Paracervical block is no longer considered safe as it causes fetal bradycardia. Epidural analgesia is preferred when complete relief of pain is needed throughout labour.
Solution to Question 25:
Postdated pregnancy is not an indication for early cord clamping. Early cord clamping is indicated in:
Birth asphyxia
Rh isoimmunization
Diabetic mother
The benefits of delayed cord clamping for up to 60 seconds is an increase in total body iron stores, expand blood volume and a decrease in anemia incidence in the neonate.
On the other hand, delayed cord clamping can lead to a higher hemoglobin concentration, which increases risks for hyperbilirubinemia and extended hospitalization for neonatal phototherapy. Delayed cord clamping can also hinder timely neonatal resuscitation.
According to AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology, in uncomplicated preterm birth, delayed cord clamping should be attempted. This is done for a minimum time of 60 seconds after delivery for preterm infants not requiring immediate resuscitation after birth. It states that DCC must be done even if the mother has an HIV infection. But as per the NACO guidelines, early cord clamping is advised.
Solution to Question 26:
Lengthening of the umbilical cord is seen in placental separation. Signs of placental separation:
The uterus becomes globular, firm, and ballottable (earliest sign to appear)
Schroeder's sign - Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower segment and uterus rests over it
Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.
Kustner's sign - On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no onger recedes
A sudden gush of blood
Permanent lengthening of cord
Note: Schroeder's ring is a constriction ring/contraction ring formed due to incoordinate uterine action.
Solution to Question 27:
Each small square in a modified WHO partogram is equal to 30 minutes. Each small square in a composite WHO partogram is equal to 1 hour.
Solution to Question 28:
The instrument given in the picture is episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is to prevent the extension of pelvic tears into the anal margins and obstetric anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tears.
Complications of episiotomy:
They can be immediate or remote.
Immediate complications include an extension of the incision into the rectum, vulval hematoma, wound dehiscence and injury to anal sphincter.
Remote complications include dyspareunia, chances of perineal lacerations in subsequent labor and scar endometriosis (rare).
Mayo scissors are long and stout scissors. They can be blunt-tipped/pointed tip/straight or curved. Straight mayo scissors are designed for cutting body tissues near the surface of a wound. They are also used to cut sutures and are also known as suture-cutting scissors.
Curved mayo scissors allow much deeper penetration into the wound and are used to cut thick tissues such as those found in the uterus, muscles, breast, and foot. Mayo scissors used for dissection are placed in tissue with the tips closed. The scissors are then opened so that the tips open and spread out the tissue during the dissection process.

The WHO Labour Care Guide begins the documentation of labour progression at 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
The WHO Labour Care Guide is a tool designed to help health personnel involved in labour care. It aims to
Guide the monitoring and help in the documentation of the progress of labour.
Guide the health professionals to offer supportive care throughout labour.
Assist doctors in promptly identifying and addressing emerging labour complications.
Prevent the use of unnecessary interventions in labour.
Support audits and quality improvement.

Solution to Question 1:
Perineal injury cannot be prevented in normal labor by routine timely episiotomy. Routine episiotomy is associated with an increased incidence of disruption of anal sphincters and rectal tears.
Indications of episiotomy:
Shoulder dystoci
Breech delivery
Fetal macrosomi
Operative vaginal deliveries
Persistent occiput posterior positions Methods of prevention of perineal laceration:
Avoid delivery by early extension
Deliver head in between contractions
Perform timely episiotomy when indicated (not routine).
Solution to Question 2:
The most common cause of true cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) in India is rickets.
The most common cause of true CPD in developing countries is vitamin D deficiency and rickets. In developed countries, it is trauma to the pelvis. It occurs due to pelvic dystocia (larger fetus and smaller pelvis).
Relative CPD is the most common type of CPD. It is caused due to fetal malposition
(occipitoposterior position/brow presentation).
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of uterine tachysystole. Oxytocin administration is not beneficial here as it leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus.
Tachysystole (hypertonic uterine dysfunction):
The uterine contractions are uncoordinated and increased in frequency (>5 contractions in 10 minutes)
Contractions occur with an increase in the baseline tone without rest in between them
It is associated with late active phase dysfunction i.e., when the cervix is almost 7 cm dilated
The most common cause is occipito-posterior position. Hence, a wait and watch policy is dopted
It is more common in nulliparous females
Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus and is not recommended. Hypotonic uterine dysfunction:
Uterine contractions are inadequate
It is associated with early active phase
It is more common in nulliparous females.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either false labor pain or prolonged latent phase. The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.
False labor can be differentiated from the latent phase of labor by therapeutic rest i.e., the patient is sedated with morphine.
Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in prolonged latent phase.
There is no indication of cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is
present. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phase.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of uterine rupture. Maternal tachycardia is seen in this condition.
Clinical features of uterine rupture:
Maternal tachycardi
Fetal bradycardia/absent fetal heart sounds
Hypotension
Abdominal tenderness
Palpable fetal parts on per abdomen examination
Bandl’s ring
Bleeding per vagin
Hematuri
Common causes of uterine rupture are previous caesarean delivery, myomectomy, silent rupture (in previous pregnancy), excess use of oxytocin, grand multipara, uterine overdistension, obstructed labour, difficult forceps delivery, placenta percreta
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of intrauterine fetal death (IUFD). The best management for such cases at 36 weeks is waiting for spontaneous expulsion.
Forceps extraction is only necessary if spontaneous expulsion doesn't take place.
Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is not done due to the risk of infections. Cesarean section is avoided as far as possible in case of fetal death.
Waiting till term is not recommended in cases of uterine infections, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and psychological upset.
Solution to Question 7:
The best time for elective delivery in patients with a history of previous stillbirth is 39 weeks, either by induction or cesarean section.
The recommendations for the management of subsequent pregnancy after stillbirth is as follows:
Ultrasonographic screening for fetal growth restriction after 28 weeks
Kick counts starting from 28 weeks of gestation
Antepartum fetal surveillance starting at 32 weeks or 1-2 weeks earlier than prior stillbirth
Support and reassurance
Labor induction is suitable in such cases. Cesarean delivery is done for those with contraindication to induction.
Solution to Question 8:
The best management in the given clinical scenario is cesarean section.
Obstructive labor management involves administering intravenous fluids to correct dehydration, providing antibiotics to prevent infection, and promptly performing a cesarean section to relieve the obstruction. If the fetus is alive, an immediate cesarean section is typically performed.
Management of obstructed labor never involves a wait-and-watch approach or augmenting with oxytocin.
Clinical features of obstructed labor include maternal exhaustion, dehydration, tachycardia, tachypnea, genital sepsis, postpartum hemorrhage, and shock.
On P/A examination the upper uterine segment is tender and tonically contracted. The lower uterine segment is thin and stretched. A groove/depression is felt between the upper uterine segment and the lower uterine segment. This is called a Bandls ring.
Complications of obstructed labor include rupture of the uterus and vesicovaginal fistula.
Solution to Question 9:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.
There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.
There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.
Forceps can be applied only when the cervix is fully dilated and the head is low down.
Solution to Question 10:
External anal sphincter is the structure injured in an episiotomy extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body.
Perineal tear have been divided into four degrees:
First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette
Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through
Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external sphincter of the anus
Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involved
A central tear of the perineum is when the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginal wall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usually occurs in patients with a contracted outlet.
Solution to Question 11:
In this scenario the midwife should put the pregnant women in a Trendelenburg position or in an exaggerated and elevated Sims’ position with a pillow or wedge under the hip or thigh.
Caesarean section is the recommended treatment of choice for cord prolapse. Prior to performing the procedure, several measures can be taken to alleviate cord compression. These measures involve:
Manually elevating the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the entire hand through the vagin
Positioning the patient in steep Trendelenburg, exaggerated Sim's position, or knee-chest position
Filling the bladder with 500–700 cc or more of saline (known as the Vagos method)
After the diagnosis of cord prolapse is made, it is crucial not to attempt cord replacement. Such attempts are not only ineffective but also result in the inevitable rupture of the membranes, leading to cord prolapse.

Solution to Question 12:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.
The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.
With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.
The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

Solution to Question 13:
The most common cause of non-engagement at term in a primigravida is deflexed head followed by cephalopelvic disproportion.
Non-engagement at the onset of active phase of labour is a risk factor for caesarean section.
The problems of prolonged labour are that the woman is exposed to high risk of infection, ketosis and obstructed labour while the fetus faces the danger of asphyxia and infection.
Solution to Question 14:
Asynclitism is not a cardinal movement during labor.
Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby is presenting first and is tilted to the shoulder. This causes the fetal head to no longer be in line with the birth canal.
Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labor. However, if severe, this condition is common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis.
Asynclitism can be of 2 types:
When the sagittal suture lies anteriorly, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called posterior asynclitism.
When the sagittal suture lies posteriorly, the anterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.

Solution to Question 15:
Latent phase is said to be prolonged in a primigravida if it lasts for more than 20 hours. Friedman defined prolonged latent phase as:
A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase
A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase
Solution to Question 16:
The above partogram shows secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hour, arrest of descent for
>1 hour and a fall in fetal heart rate suggestive of fetal distress.
These are characteristic findings of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical features suggest that the patient is in latent phase of labor. Latent phase is said to be prolonged if it is:
>20 h in nullipar
>14 h in multipar
Causes of prolonged latent phase:
Excessive sedation/epidural analgesi
Poor cervical conditions (thick, uneffaced)
False labour (most common cause in multipara)
Friedman's curve is used in the diagnosis of prolonged labour. It is the sigmoid curve plotting the pattern of cervical dilatation during the latent and active phase of normal labour.

Management includes morphine administration, rest and oxytocin stimulation.

Poor cervical dilatation causes a prolonged latent phase.
Arrest of cervical dilatation is defined as the lack of cervical dilatation for  2 hours during the active phase of labour.
According to the Obstetric Care Consensus Committee, when cervical dilatation has reached  6 cm with ruptured membranes, and there is no cervical change despite 4 hours of adequate uterine contractions or 6 hours of inadequate contractions, a cesarean delivery is warranted.
Solution to Question 20:
The protracted descent in labor in a nullipara is less than 1 cm/hour.
Solution to Question 21:
Arrest of descent in labor in a multigravida is no descent for more than 1 hour.

Solution to Question 1:
The technique of stimulating uterine contractions prior to the onset of spontaneous labor is known as induction of labor.
It can be done irrespective of the rupture of membranes.
Augmentation is the enhancement of spontaneous contractions that are considered inadequate because of failed cervical dilation and fetal descent.
Solution to Question 2:
Heart disease is currently not considered a contraindication for the induction of labor. Vaginal delivery is preferred in such patients.
Solution to Question 3:
The minimum Bishop Score required before proceeding with induction of labour is 6.
A Bishop score >8 conveys a high likelihood of a successful induction. The latest guidelines state that a cut-off score of 6 can be used to choose between pharmacological and mechanical methods of induction.
This score is calculated based on the:
station of the fetal head
dilation of cervix
cervical length
position of cervix
consistency of the cervix.
This score is an important determinant of a successful induction.
Solution to Question 4:
Uterine tachysystole is defined as >5 contractions in a 10 min period and may occur in spontaneous or stimulated labor. It should always be qualified by the presence or absence of fetal heart rate abnormalities. Tachysystole interrupts maternal blood flow to the placenta during contractions and may lead to a reduction in fetal oxygenation. It is also associated with placental abruption.
It is caused by pharmacological agents used for cervical ripening and induction such as misoprostol (both oral and vaginal) and dinoprostone. Management includes stopping oxytocin infusion and terbutaline 0.25 mg SC.
Solution to Question 5:
Misoprostol (PGE1) is given as 25mcg 3-6 hourly vaginally or 25mcg 2 hourly orally for the induction of labor.
It is associated with the following side effects:
Uterine tachysystole
Meconium stained amniotic fluid
Uterine rupture
Solution to Question 6:
Competitive blocking of acetylcholine is not a mechanism of action of oxytocin. Mechanism of action of oxytocin is as follows:
Receptor mediation through G protein-coupled receptors
Activation of voltage-gated Ca channel leading to calcium entry
Prostaglandin production by a positive feedback mechanism. This induces production of more prostaglandins and stronger contractions.
Solution to Question 7:
Controlled artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is performed in a patient with amniotic fluid index (AFI)  25 cm. This points towards a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.
This is because if ARM is not done under controlled conditions in these patients, it can cause sudden decompression of the fetus. This can lead to abruption of placenta.
Contraindications to ARM:
Intrauterine fetal death
Active genital herpes infectio
Maternal HIV-AIDS
Solution to Question 8:
Stripping of membranes is being depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex. It is also known as the fetal ejection reflex and is seen due to the pressure at the internal os of the cervix.
It is associated with an increase in blood levels of a prostaglandin F2 metabolite, also known as dinoprost. This is released due to mechanical stretching of the internal os. This enhances the uterine activity and causes release of more prostaglandins. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.
Solution to Question 9:
The Bishop's score is rapidly improved by the use of laminaria tents.
It is a mechanical cervical dilator and acts by hygroscopic osmotic action, leading to slow dilatation of the cervix. The gentle dilatation by laminaria tents induces an endogenous synthesis of prostaglandins causing a softening of the cervix. This is useful in cervical ripening before induction of labour.
Solution to Question 10:
In a partograph, the first marking of cervical dilatation should be made on the left of the alert line. In a normal partograph, the plotting remains on the left of the alert line.

Solution to Question 11:
Moderate uterine contractions last for 20–40 s.
Weak contractions last for <20 s and strong contractions are >40 s.
During active labour, uterine contractions are 5 min apart for 1 hour, i.e.,  12 contractions in 1 hour. This is accompanied by cervical dilatation of 3–5 cm.

Solution to Question 12:
Abdominal amniocentesis followed by oxytocin drip is a safe method for induction of labor in polyhydramnios.
Abdominal amniocentesis drains a good amount of liquor (amnioreduction), after which the oxytocin infusion can be started. This will minimize the sudden decompression and reduce the risk of placental separation, cord prolapse and change in lie of the fetus.
Although polyhydramnios does not constitute an absolute contraindication for the application of prostaglandins, these substances should be administered with caution. There is a marked increase in the incidence of postpartum hemorrhage and amniotic fluid embolism with their use.
Hence, amnioreduction is a preferred mode of treatment in polyhydramnios.

Solution to Question 1:
Shoulder dystocia is defined as head to shoulder delivery time of more than 60 seconds. It occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.
Prelabour risk factors:
Diabetes Mellitus
Obesity
Postdatism and prior history
Excessive weight gain during pregnancy Intrapartum risk factors:
Prolonged 1st and 2nd stage of labour
Instrumental delivery
Augmentation of labour with oxytocin
Solution to Question 2:
A patient with gestational diabetes and the presence of turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Robert's manoeuvre, Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre, Gaskin's
manoeuvre, and Rubin's manoeuvre are all used in its management.
Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal pelvis. Turtle sign may be seen which refers to the recoil of the fetal head against the perineum.
Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: st line of management - Mc Roberts manoeuvre (flexion and abduction of thigh)
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
nd line of management - Rubin's (rotation of the easily accessible shoulder by 30-45°), Woods corkscrew manoeuvre (rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a cork screw fashion) ; OR Gaskin (all four's position)
Last line of management - Zavanelli manoeuvre (head is rotated to its pre-restitution position and caesarian section is performed); OR procedures such as cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle of the baby); symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)
In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli manoeuvre.



Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Roberts manoeuvre is the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. It involves flexion and abduction of
the maternal hips, positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia.
McRoberts manoeuvre:
Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby.
Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.
If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.
Rubin's manoeuvre:
Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position.
Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:
Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

Solution to Question 5:
Applying a gentle suprapubic pressure is the first step in the management of shoulder dystocia along with McRoberts manoeuvre. Fundal pressure is not a method of delivery in such cases.
Hernandez and Wendel suggested the use of a shoulder dystocia drill to better organize emergency management:
Call for help and mobilize labour assistants, anaesthesia and pediatric doctors.
An attempt at traction is tried followed by episiotomy to afford room posteriorly.
Apply pressure suprapubically, not fundally, with the palm or fist, directing the pressure on the anterior shoulder.
This should be both downward (below the pubic bone) and laterally (toward the baby's face or sternum) in conjunction with the McRoberts manoeuvre.
These manoeuvres will resolve most cases of shoulder dystocia. If the above-listed steps fail, the following steps may be attempted, and any of the manoeuvres may be repeated:
Rubin's manoeuvre
Woods corkscrew manoeuvre
Gaskin (all four's position)
Zavanelli manoeuvre
Cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle of baby)
Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother).

The most common fetal malpresentation is the breech presentation.
The most common breech presentation in primigravida is frank breech and in multigravida, it is flexed/complete breech. It is most commonly seen with prematurity.
In breech presentation:
The most common position is left sacroanterior
The engaging diameter is bitrochanteric.
Cord prolapse is common in footling presentation and rare in frank breech.
However, among all malpresentations, cord prolapse is most common in transverse lie.
Solution to Question 7:
Vagos method is used in cord prolapse.
Vagos method is also known as the bladder filling method. Here, the bladder is distended with saline to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. The bladder is filled with 400–•50 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.

Solution to Question 12:
The presentation depicted in the image is breech presentation. The most common cause of this presentation is prematurity.
The incidence of breech at term is 3%. At 28 weeks of pregnancy, 20% of women have a breech presentation. The fetus undergoes spontaneous version usually between 30 - 34 weeks thereby correcting its position by itself.
Persistent breech occurs when this spontaneous version is prevented by any of the following causes:
Intrauterine death of the fetus
Anomalies such as trisomy 13, 18, 21
Anomalies of uterus (septate/bicornuate)
Oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios
Twins
Short cord
Hydrocephalus
Placenta previa
Contracted pelvis
Recurrent/habitual breech is when breech recurs in 3 or more pregnancies. It is usually due to uterine anomalies and cornufundal attachment of the placenta.
Solution to Question 13:
Placenta previa is an absolute contraindication for external cephalic version (ECV).
Relative contraindications for ECV:
early labor
oligohydramnios
ruptured membranes
known nuchal cord
structural uterine abnormalities
fetal-growth restriction
multifetal gestation
prior abruption or its risk factors
severe pre-eclampsia and hypertension
previous LSCS
šote: In twin gestation, with a cephalic-noncephalic presentation, after the delivery of the first twin, an internal podalic version or intrapartum external cephalic version can be attempted for the second non-cephalic twin. However, ECV in this case, can lead to an increased incidence of fetal distress when compared with the internal podalic version. Hence, ECV is only a relative contraindication in twin pregnancy.
Previous LSCS is a relative contraindication for ECV. However, it is not attempted often and needs to be performed with caution.
Solution to Question 14:
The given examination findings are suggestive of transverse lie. The likely fetal presentation is shoulder presentation.
The most common cause of transverse lie is prematurity. In term pregnancy, it is commonly seen in patients with placenta previa. Although the most common cause of cord prolapse is transverse lie, hand prolapse is also frequently seen in such conditions. The transverse lie is managed by the caesarean section.
In a twin pregnancy, management of 1st twin with a transverse lie is caesarean section whereas the 2nd twin is managed by internal podalic version.
Solution to Question 15:
In a breech presentation, chin to pubis delivery can be done by Prague manoeuvre.
Rarely, the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the anterior. In such cases, rotation of the posteriorly oriented back of the fetus to the anterior may be achieved by using stronger traction on the fetal legs or bony pelvis.
If this still does not succeed, the fetus still may be delivered using the modified Prague manoeuvre. This consists of two fingers of one hand grasping the shoulders of the back-down fetus from below while the other hand draws the feet up and over the maternal abdomen.
If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau manoeuvre and delivering the fetus back down.

Solution to Question 16:
Delivery of the aftercoming head in breech is not done with the help of Keilland's forceps. These forceps are used for the rotation of the fetal head. It is not used anymore.
The methods used for delivery of the aftercoming head include the following:
Burns-Marshall manoeuvre: When the occiput is seen under the pubic symphysis, steady traction is given on the feet. The baby is swung in an arc towards the mother's abdomen. Simultaneous suprapubic pressure is given and the head is born by flexion.

Malar flexion and shoulder traction (modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique):
The baby is placed on the supinated left forearm (preferred) with the limbs hanging on either side. The middle and the index fingers of the left hand are placed over the malar bones. The ring and little fingers of the pronated right hand are placed on the child’s right shoulder. The index finger is placed on the left shoulder and the middle finger is placed on the suboccipital region.
Traction is now given in a downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch. The assistant gives suprapubic pressure during the period to maintain flexion. The fetus is carried in an upward and forward direction toward the mother’s abdomen releasing the face and brow. Lastly, the trunk is depressed to release the occiput and vertex.

The image below shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve.


Solution to Question 17:
The management of entrapment of aftercoming head does not involve Kristellar manoeuvre.
Kristeller manoeuvre is the application of uterine fundal pressure during the second stage of labour to shorten the second stage of labour. This should be used sparingly used as it leads to avulsion of the levator ani.
An incompletely dilated cervix will constrict around the neck and impede the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech.
Management options:
With gentle traction on the fetal body, the cervix may be manually slipped over the occiput.
If this is not successful, then Dührssen incisions may be necessary. These are a set of three incisions in the cervix:
Can be made at the 2 and 10 o'clock position on the cervix. An additional incision at the 6 o’clock position is sometimes needed.
Done for delivery of aftercoming head in breech or delivery of head through an incompletely dilated cervix.
There is a significant risk of haemorrhage; the cervical incision may extend upwards within the broad ligament causing broad ligament haematoma.

Other alternatives include intravenous nitroglycerin, typically 100 g, to provide cervical relaxation. General anaesthesia with halogenated agents is another option.
As a last resort, the following methods are used:
Zavanelli manoeuvre: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery. This is performed for the protruding head and intractable shoulder dystocia.
Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal cartilage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis. It is also used to aid the delivery of an entrapped aftercoming head.
Solution to Question 18:
Breech identified for the first time during delivery is not a contraindication for normal delivery. Vaginal breech delivery is considered when:
Fetal weight is between 1.5 kg and 3.5 kg

The presentation is frank breec

There are no medical or obstetric complications
Facilities for emergency cesarean section are available (anesthetists, neonatologists) (option B)
Facilities for continuous labor monitoring are available (option C)
A skilled obstetrician is present (option D)
Detailed informed consent has been obtained, explaining the risks of vaginal breech delivery Cesarean delivery for breech presentation is considered in the following cases:
Lack of operator experience
Patient's request for cesarean delivery
Prior perinatal death or neonatal birth trauma
Large fetus: > 3800 to 4000 g
Severe IUGR, term weight <2.5kg to 2.8kg
Incomplete breech presentation
Oligohydramnios
Fetal anomaly incompatible with vaginal delivery
Hyperextended head
Contracted pelvis
Prior cesarean delivery
Preterm breec
Twins, with the first baby in the breech position

Solution to Question 21:
Occipitoposterior position (OP) is the most common cause of a mobile head at term.
It is the most common fetal malposition. It is an abnormal position seen in the vertex presentation, not an abnormal presentation.
Occipitoposterior position is commonly seen in android pelvis/deflexed head.
The engaging diameter of this position is sub-occipitofrontal/occipitofrontal.
The most common type in occipitoposterior position is right OP.
A persistent occipitoposterior position results from a failure of internal rotation prior to birth.
Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) is a disproportion in the size of the fetus relative to the maternal pelvis. This can result in the failure of progress of labour in the second stage. This usually occurs due to fetal malposition e.g., extended or asynclitic fetal head, occipitoposterior or transverse position. It is also seen in malpresentations like mentum posterior, brow.
The diagnosis of CPD is subjective. However, true CPD may occur if the fetus has a large anomaly e.g., teratoma or conjoined twin, or in cases of a large fetus. It can also occur when the maternal pelvis is small or deformed like after pelvic trauma.
Solution to Question 22:
The most appropriate management for pregnant women in labour whose fetus is in occipitoposterior position is to wait and watch for progress of labour. In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle and the baby is born as occipitoanterior.
Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior is made, labour is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and favourable pelvis.
Indications of caesarean section in occipitoposterior position:
Arrest of labour
Inadequate uterine contraction
Fetal distress
Other obstetrical indications.
Solution to Question 23:
The most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery is complete perineal tears.
In face to pubis delivery, the occiput is posterior, and therefore, the largest biparietal diameter (Ž.4 cm) distends the perineum rather than the smaller bitemporal diameter (8 cm). A liberal episiotomy helps to avoid perineal tears.

Solution to Question 1:
Completely dilated cervix is a prerequisite for forceps delivery. Prerequisites for forceps delivery:
Experienced operator
Engaged hea
Ruptured membranes
Vertex presentation
Completely dilated cervix
Precisely assessed fetal head position
Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspecte
Absent fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder
Before operative vaginal delivery, the bladder should be emptied to provide additional pelvic space and minimize bladder trauma.
Solution to Question 2:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is a type of outlet forceps. Rotation of the fetal head should not exceed 45 degrees for the application of outlet forceps. This is because it increases the risk of vaginal wall lacerations.
Solution to Question 3:
Forceps can be used for delivery of the aftercoming head of breech. The advantages are as follows:
Delivery can be controlled by giving pull directly on the head and the force is not transmitte through the neck.
Flexion is better maintained.
Mucus can be sucked out from the mouth more effectively. Prerequisites for instrumental vaginal delivery:
Ruptured membranes vertex presentation
Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspecte
No fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder
Completely dilated cervix
Precisely assessed fetal head position
Engaged hea
Experienced operator
Note: Ventouse can be used for occipitotranverse or posterior position.
Solution to Question 4:
Forceps can be used to deliver a preterm baby where it is believed to form a protective cage. Vacuum is contraindicated in these cases.
Contraindications of forceps delivery:
Unengaged hea
Cephalopelvic disproportion
Malpresentations like brow and face (mentoposterior position)
Cervix not completely dilate
Inability to define position
Fetal coagulopathy or osteogenesis imperfecta
Note: Forceps delivery is only reserved for mentoanterior position.
Solution to Question 5:
The image shown is a vacuum delivery system. It is used for vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery of the fetus.
Theoretical advantages of ventouse (vacuum extraction) compared to forceps include:
Simpler requirements for positioning of the fetal hea
Avoidance of space occupying blades within the vagina
Lower maternal trauma rates
Solution to Question 6:
Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are more frequently seen with ventouse delivery than with forceps delivery.
Maternal morbidity is seen more with forceps deliveries and perinatal morbidity is seen more with vacuum deliveries.
Maternal morbidity seen in operative vaginal deliveries include:
Increased third and fourth-degree vaginal lacerations
Pelvic floor disorders
Postpartum hemorrhage
Perinatal morbidity seen in operative vaginal deliveries include:
Vacuum-assisted perinatal injuries: Cephalohematoma, subgaleal hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhage, neonatal jaundice secondary to these hemorrhages, shoulder dystocia, clavicular fracture, intracranial hemorrhage, and scalp lacerations.
Forceps-assisted perinatal injuries: Higher rates of facial nerve injury, brachial plexus injury, epressed skull fracture, and corneal abrasion.
In cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred. It is conducted with the laboring woman in an upright or left decubitus position. Prophylactic use of vacuum is done to cut short the second stage of labor. This is to minimize aortocaval compression. Caesarean section is not preferred since it is associated with more blood loss and higher thromboembolic and infection risk.
Solution to Question 7:
Deep transverse arrest is an indication for ventouse delivery.
In ventouse delivery technique, suction is created within a cup placed on the fetal scalp such that traction on the cup aids fetal expulsion. The important step in ventouse extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point.
The vacuum is gradually created by increasing the suction in increments of 0.2 kg/cm2 every 2 minutes until a total negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 is reached. Progressive descent should accompany each traction attempt.
Solution to Question 8:
An important step in vacuum extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point. It is a point on the sagittal suture that lies 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle.
Advantages of correct positioning of cup in vacuum extraction:
Maximum traction
Minimum cup detachment
Twisting of fetal head is avoide
Smallest head diameter is delivered through the pelvic outlet
Success rate is improve
Fetal scalp injury rates are lowere
Perineal trauma is reduced because the smallest fetal head diameter distends the vulva

Solution to Question 9:
The maximum negative pressure used in ventouse is 0.8 kg/cm2
Gradual vacuum creation is recommended. This is generated by increasing the suction in increments of 0.2 kg/cm2 every 2 minutes. This is done until a total negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 is reached.
This slow incremental approach would allow for a more firm attachment of the vacuum cup to the fetal head and thereby a lower failure rate.
Solution to Question 10:
Delivery with ventouse should occur within 3 pulls over 15-20 min.
Solution to Question 11:
Autorotation is seen with vacuum extraction and not assisted forceps delivery. Advantages of ventouse over forceps:
No need of anaesthesia
Less expertise require

Promotes autorotation
Does not occupy the sides

No maternal effort is neede
Quick in case of fetal distress
Can be used in face and breech
Can be used in preterm
Less cephalohematoma
Delivery failure is less

Solution to Question 13:
The ideal time to do external cephalic version is 37 weeks. This procedure is attempted in a woman who has completed 36 weeks of gestation and has a breech fetal presentation.
Before 37 weeks, a breech presentation has a high likelihood of correcting spontaneously. Moreover, if performed too early, there is time to return back to breech.
After 37 weeks, the success rates of ECV are very low. Although it can be performed until the early stages of labour, it is not recommended.
Solution to Question 14:
The procedure shown here is external cephalic version. A relative contraindication for this procedure is intra-uterine growth restriction.
Solution to Question 15:
The mediolateral episiotomy is directed at an angle of 60 degrees.
The mediolateral episiotomy incision starts in the midline at the fourchette and is directed at an angle 60 degrees from the midline. This 60-degree angle takes into consideration a distortion of perineal anatomy during crowning and ultimately yields an incision that is 45 degrees from the midline following delivery.

Solution to Question 1:
An elective caesarean section should ideally be performed after 39 weeks. It is not done before 39 weeks of gestation as there is an increased risk of:
Complications related to prematurity including respiratory problems
Neonatal adaptation problems such as hypothermia and hypoglycemia
Solution to Question 2:
According to ACOG guidelines, the ideal time to administer antibiotics is within a time period of 60 mins prior to the planned caesarean section.
Antimicrobial administration before surgical incision has been shown to lower postoperative infection rates without adverse neonatal effects, as compared with drug administration after umbilical cord clamping. A 1 g dose of cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice.
For emergency delivery, antibiotic prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible.
Solution to Question 3:
The above partogram is suggestive of obstructed labour and the definitive management in this case is caesarean section. Cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice for antibiotic prophylaxis before caesarean section.
According to the partogram, there is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate indicating fetal distress. Hence, the management plan is to perform a caesarean section.
The recommended prophylactic drug is a single intravenous dose of a -lactam antimicrobial. This could either be a cephalosporin or an extended-spectrum penicillin derivative. A 1 g dose of cefazolin is usually given. For obese women, a 2 g dose is better to provide an adequate coverage.
Solution to Question 4:
Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis before surgical procedures is recommended in patients with prosthetic valves, prior history of endocarditis, and unrepaired cyanotic heart diseases.
Pregnant women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease, prosthetic valves, or both. However, endocarditis prophylaxis is not required if the patient is already receiving intrapartum prophylaxis with broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent endometritis.
Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for atrial septal defect (ASD). The risk of endocarditis with ASD is negligible. Bacterial endocarditis is associated with unrepaired ventricular septal
defects where antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended. Similarly, prophylaxis for bacterial endocarditis is indicated at delivery for unrepaired patent ductus arteriosus.
Solution to Question 5:
In an obese pregnant woman who is allergic to penicillin, a dose of 900 mg clindamycin with an aminoglycoside is used for antibiotic prophylaxis.
In women with significant penicillin or cephalosporin allergy, a single 600 mg intravenous dose of clindamycin combined with a weight-based dose of aminoglycoside is recommended. For obese women, a 900 mg dose is preferred.
Solution to Question 6:
General anaesthesia is the anaesthesia of choice here since the patient presents with haemorrhage.
General anaesthesia may be indicated for emergency cesarean delivery in patients with a reassuring airway examination. It is also recommended for patients with severe coagulopathy where neuraxial anesthesia is contraindicated.
Spinal anesthesia is not preferred when the operation is expected to result in blood loss or in a previously haemorrhaging patient. It is because in such cases the development of severe hypovolemia is likely which is a contraindication for this type of anaesthesia.
Solution to Question 7:
The recti muscles are transected in the Maylard incision for caesarean delivery which is marked as
'2' in the given image.
It is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision.
The various incisions mentioned in the image are:
Incision '1' - Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below the umbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to the transverse abdominal incision.
Incision '3' - Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia was incised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; finger dissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally.
Incision '4' - Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery. It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis.
This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Solution to Question 8:
Transverse abdominal incisions offer a narrow operating space.
Solution to Question 9:
In a C-section, the incision on the uterus can be extended by using lateral and slightly upward pressure applied with each index finger.
If the lower uterine segment is thick, then cutting laterally and then slightly upward with bandage scissors will extend the incision.
Note: When scissors are used, the index and middle fingers of the non-dominant hand should be insinuated between the myometrium and the fetal parts to prevent fetal laceration.
Solution to Question 10:
A T-shaped incision has the highest risk of uterine rupture among the given options. Among all the incisions, a previous classical cesarean incision has the highest risk of rupture but it is not an option here.
Overall, the maximum risk of uterine rupture is in patients who have had a previous upper segment uterine rupture. Women with single prior low-transverse hysterotomy have the lowest risk of symptomatic scar separation.
Solution to Question 11:
Adnexal exposure is high and hence tubal sterilization is easy.
After delivery of the placenta, the uterus is lifted through the incision onto the draped abdominal wall. The fundus is covered with a moistened laparotomy sponge and this is known as exteriorisation of uterus.
Benefits of exteriorization:
Relaxed, atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applied.
The incision and bleeding points are more easily visualized and repaired.
Adnexal exposure is superior, and thus, tubal sterilization is easier. Drawbacks of exteriorization:
Intraoperative nausea and vomiting
Need for additional uterotonics
Longer time duration to the first recognized bowel movement The below image shows the exteriorisation of the uterus.

Solution to Question 12:
Cervical cancer is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy. Indications for peripartum hysterectomy include:
Uterine atony - when every other method fails to control PPH
Uterine extension
Uterine rupture
Postpartum uterine infection
Cervical laceration
Leiomyoma - large leiomyomas in a woman with completed family
Ovarian neoplasia
Solution to Question 13:
Skin laceration is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section. Other injuries seen include:
Cephalohematoma
Brachial plexus injury
Clavicular fracture
Skull fracture
Facial nerve palsy
Solution to Question 14:
Elective caesarean section decreases the risk of chorioamnionitis.
Maternal complications increase with caesarean section when compared with vaginal deliveries. Some of these complications include:
Post-operative infection
Haemorrhage
Thromboembolism
Anaesthesia-related complications
Mendelson syndrome/ aspiration pneumonitis
Solution to Question 15:
The given image shows a pneumatic compression device. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for cesarean section (statement A) and it is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery (statement C).
The device is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.
According to recent guidelines, patients with no additional risk factors and not placed on any pharmacological thromboprophylaxis are placed on pneumatic compression devices before
cesarean delivery. Patients undergoing cesarean delivery with additional risk factors are put on both pneumatic compression devices and pharmacological therapy (UFH or LMWH).
UFH-unfractionated heparin, LMWH-lower molecular weight heparin. Indications of pharmacological thromboprophylaxis:
Inherited coagulation disorder
Overweight or obese patient
Heart failure
Family history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism
Solution to Question 16:
Age >35 years is a risk factor for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section. The other risk factors include:
Emergency cesarean
Obesity
Parity >3
Caesarean hysterectomy
Concurrent infection
Preeclampsia
Prior deep-vein thrombosis or thrombophilia
Solution to Question 17:
Transverse incision in prior caesarean section is a low risk factor in vaginal birth after cesarean
(VBAC).
Risk factors for VBAC:
High risk -
Classical or T-incision in prior cesarean
Prior rupture
Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa
Inadequate facilities Low risk -
Transverse incision in prior cesarean
Prior vaginal delivery
Sufficient personnel and equipment
Solution to Question 18:
Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) in neonates has a higher incidence with trial of scar or VBAC as compared to elective cesarean.
Uterine rupture is a dangerous complication of VBAC. This leads to hemorrhage which can cause the baby to be hypoxic eventually leading to permanent brain damage from hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. This results in developmental delay and cerebral palsy.
Birth trauma, transient tachypnea of newborn (TTN) and neonatal sepsis are more commonly seen with elective caesarean in comparison to VBAC.

Solution to Question 8:
Endometrial regeneration starts by 7th day and is completed by the 10th day. Regeneration of the epithelium at the placental site takes about 6 weeks.
Endometrium regenerates from zona basalis which remains intact and is the source of new endometrium. This arises from proliferation of the endometrial glandular remnants and the stroma of the interglandular connective tissue.
Solution to Question 9:

Temperature is assessed every 4 hours for the first 8 hours after delivery.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of afterpains which are seen during puerperium.
In primiparous women, the uterus tends to remain tonically contracted following delivery. In multiparous women, it often contracts vigorously at intervals and gives rise to afterpains, which are similar to but milder than labor contractions.
These are more pronounced as parity increases and worsen when the infant suckles, likely because of oxytocin release. Afterpains gradually decrease in intensity and become mild by the third day.

Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.
The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament.
It is the most common obstetrical neuropathy after vaginal delivery, followed by femoral nerve involvement.
Note: The nerves most commonly injured during cesarean section are the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves.
Solution to Question 15:
The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve causing foot drop.
The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is the most commonly injured nerve after vaginal delivery followed by femoral neuropathies.
Obstetrical neuropathies are due to the pressure on branches of the lumbosacral nerve plexus during labor. They can manifest as complaints of intense neuralgia or cramp-like pains extending down one or both legs as soon as the head descends into the pelvis. Footdrop can be secondary to injury at the level of the lumbosacral plexus, sciatic nerve, or common fibular (peroneal) nerve.
Injury of the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves may occur with cesarean delivery, which may manifest as an inguinal hernia and loss of sensation at the pubic region respectively.
Note: Since there are no options relating to intense neuralgia in the lower limb, foot drop becomes the best possible answer.
Solution to Question 16:
Puerperal fever is defined as the temperature of 38 °C or higher (100.4 °F) recorded on 2 separate occasions 24 hours apart within the first 10 days following delivery. This excludes the first 24 hours.
In the first 24 hours, a slight rise of temperature is not uncommon and hence the first 24 hours are excluded while defining puerperal pyrexia.
Note: Generally, fever in an adult is defined as an oral temperature of >37.5 °C.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever, foul-smelling lochia, and pelvic tenderness is suggestive of puerperal sepsis. The most common route of spread of this condition is direct spread.
Streptococcus sp. is the most important causative organism of puerperal sepsis. The commonest manifestation is endometritis.
The route of delivery is an important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis (cesarean> vaginal). The most common site of puerperal infection is the placental site in vaginal delivery and uterine incision in cesarean section.
The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following cesarean section is administrating a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of caesarean delivery.
Solution to Question 18:
Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers and should be taken for 10-14 days.
Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus. It is common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth.
Clinical features of mastitis include:
Fever and malaise
Localized pain and tenderness
Purulent nipple discharge
Redness and swelling of the affected breast
Positive fluctuation test
A culture from nipple discharge or test-needle aspiration of the cellulitic area is done to confirm the organism and its antibiotic sensitivity. An ultrasonogram of the involved breast is done to exclude abscess. They are treated with antibiotics and adequate breast support. Choice of antibiotics in lactational mastitis:
Dicloxacillin 500 mg 4 times a day is to be started empirically.
Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.
If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus species then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given for at least 10 days.
Solution to Question 19:
The clinical vignette of breast pain, fever, and leucocytosis with the image showing a red and swollen breast suggests a diagnosis of mastitis. The most common etiological agent is Staphylococcus aureus.
Mastitis refers to infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. Symptoms usually appear in the 3rd or 4th week. The infection is usually unilateral, with the source of infection being the infant's nose and throat. Predisposing factors are fissures, abrasions, and nipple cracks.
Management:
Breastfeeding should be continued. If the infant is unable to nurse on the inflamed breast, the mother may resort to breast pumping. When nursing bilaterally, suckling is best started on the uninvolved breast.
Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment of mastitis. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.
If an abscess forms, surgical treatment is done.

Solution to Question 23:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism secondary to the necrosis of the pituitary gland. It usually results from severe hypotension or shock caused by massive hemorrhage during or after delivery. Patients with SS have varying degrees of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of infarction.
Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Because
deficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.
It can present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases,
severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death. Also, it can present late with the following features:
Loss of pubic and axillary hair
Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion
Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH
Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out. Fertility can be achieved in these women with hMG and hCG. Clomiphene is ineffective.
Option B: Rotor syndrome is a type of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia with autosomal recessive inheritance. Affected individuals have mild jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia.
Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 g/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.
Option D: Acromegaly is characterized by the signs and symptoms pertaining to excessive growth hormone secretion.
Solution to Question 24:
Antibiotics plus heparin is the next course of treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis.
Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis refers to the presence of an endovascular thrombus in the setting of associated bacterial or fungal infection.
The treatment of septic pelvic thrombophlebitis is broad-spectrum antibiotics plus anticoagulation. Anticoagulation is thought to prevent further thrombosis and reduce the spread of septic emboli.

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova released in the same cycle, by two separate acts of coitus within a short period of time.
Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova in the same menstrual cycle (as suggested by the same gestational age) by separate acts of coitus. It can occur even after artificial reproductive therapy. Hence, after embryo transfer, intercourse must be avoided. Heteropaternal superfecundation is used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins.
This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings. This may give rise to the doubt of adultery and infidelity.
Superfetation is the fertilization of two ova released in different menstrual cycles. This is not seen in humans. The nidation and development of one fetus over another fetus is theoretically possible until the decidual space is obliterated by 14-16 weeks of pregnancy.

Solution to Question 10:
The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is 11-14 weeks.
Twin pregnancies should ideally be dated when the crown–rump length (CRL) measurement is between 45 and 84 mm (i.e. 11 + 0 to 13 + 6 weeks of gestation).
Chorionicity should be ideally determined between 11 + 0 and 13 + 6 weeks of gestation (the earliest time to identify chorionicity is 7 weeks). This is done using the membrane thickness at the site of insertion of the amniotic membrane into the placenta. The T■sign (in monochorionic twins) or lambda sign (in dichorionic twins) can be seen here. As the determination of chorionicity is most accurate when the amnion and chorion have not yet been fused, the first■trimester scan in twin pregnancy is highly important.
Markers of dichorionicity include 4 layers of membranes between the twins, membrane thickness
>2mm, different sex of twins, 2 different placentas, and positive twin peak sign.
Women with an uncomplicated dichorionic twin pregnancy should have a first■trimester scan, a detailed second■trimester scan, and scans every 4 weeks thereafter.
Women with uncomplicated monochorionic twins should have a first■trimester scan and then scans every 2 weeks from 16 weeks onwards. This is done in order to detect TTTS and TAPS in a timely manner.
Solution to Question 11:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign.
In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane.

Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:
Number of placental masses - 2
Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign
Thickness of intervening membranes  2mm
The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

This can be seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester.

Discordant growth is the unequal size/ weight among the fetuses in a multifetal gestation. It can be diagnosed by either of the following:
Estimated fetal weight difference > 20%
Discordance = (weight of larger twin - weight of smaller twin/weight of larger twin) x 100
Discordant growth in monochorionic twins is due to placental vascular anastomoses. In dichorionic twins, it occurs due to differences in genetic growth potential and suboptimal implantation site for one of the fetuses.
