Solution to Question 16:
Artery-vein anastomoses are most commonly seen in monochorionic pregnancies. All monochorionic placentas have anastomoses that can be:
Superficial artery-vein
Deep artery-vein
Artery-artery
Vein-vein
One vessel with connections to multiple arteries and veins
These anastomoses are not functional as long as the fetuses are hemodynamically balanced. When a pressure gradient develops between the fetuses, complications can occur like:
TTTS - Twin-twin transfusion syndrome
TAPS - Twin anemia polycythemia sequence
TRAP - Twin reversed arterial perfusion
The most common complication in monochorionic twins is twin-twin transfusion syndrome
(TTTS). Deep artery-vein anastomosis is the pathology seen in this condition.
Solution to Question 17:
Congestive heart failure is seen in the recipient twin.
Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen
in monochorionic diamniotic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through the anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. Oxygenated blood is taken up by the recipient twin causing imbalance in the blood volumes.
Diagnosis of TTTS depends on 2 USG criteria:
Monochorionic diamniotic gestation
Hydramnios (DVP>8cm) in one twin and oligohydramnios (DVP<2cm) in the other twin Treatment modalities for TTTS:
Serial amnioreduction
Laser ablation of vascular placental anastomoses
Selective fetal termination
Note: Donor twin is called the stuck twin as the oligohydramnios limits fetal movement.

The given image shows an acardius acephalus fetus. This refers to the acardiac twin seen in twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP). Both artery-artery and vein-vein anastomosis can be seen in TRAP.
TRAP is a placental vascular anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic twins. In this disorder, deoxygenated blood from the donor twin enters the recipient twin through the anastomosis and supplies the lower half of the recipient’s body. Hence, the heart and upper body of the recipient is poorly developed.

Solution to Question 22:
The second twin being in transverse lie is the only indication for internal version in modern obstetrics.
In a twin pregnancy, if the first twin has vertex presentation, vaginal delivery can be performed. Following the vaginal delivery of the first twin, if the second twin is in transverse lie, it is corrected by external version (preferably cephalic) into a longitudinal lie. If external version fails and the membranes are intact, internal version is done under general anaesthesia, followed by breech extraction.
If the membranes are ruptured, caesarean section is done immediately. Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin:

Solution to Question 3:
Endometrial sloughing in ectopic gestation is due to the fall in the levels of progesterone and hCG.
During normal pregnancy, endometrium is maintained by the high levels of hCG and progesterone. In ectopic pregnancy, a fall in the levels of these hormones will cause endometrial sloughing and uterine bleeding. If the decidua is expelled as a single piece through the cervix, it is called a decidual cast.
Solution to Question 4:
Interstitial tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage i.e. at 12-16 weeks. This is because pregnancy at this site is closer to the uterine myometrium which provides support as pregnancy progresses.
Isthmic and ampullary pregnancies terminate by tubal rupture. However, isthmic pregnancy ruptures earlier. Ampullary and infundibular pregnancy can terminate by tubal abortion as well.
Solution to Question 5:
A shock index of >0.85 is seen in a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. There is massive blood loss (SBP<110 mmHg) sometimes leading to shock.
The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP.
Option A: Sub-diaphragmatic blood irritates the phrenic nerve. This causes a referred pain at the shoulder tip. This is called as Danforth sign.
Option B: The expulsion of decidua in a single piece through the cervix is called a decidual cast. This is due to the fall in the levels of  hCG and progesterone.
Option C: Vertigo and syncope are due to reflex vasomotor disturbances due to peritoneal irritation from hemoperitoneum.

Solution to Question 6:
Low levels of  hCG and prolonged doubling time increase the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.
Urine pregnancy test is very sensitive and found positive in most ectopic pregnancies. Hence, serial serum  hCG levels are estimated to detect ectopic pregnancy. In early normal pregnancy, the doubling time of  hCG concentrations in plasma is 1.4 to 2 days.
Solution to Question 7:
Ring of fire pattern is seen on color doppler in a tubal ectopic pregnancy. This is due to placental blood flow in the tubal pregnancy.
This finding may also be seen in corpus luteum cysts but the wall is less echogenic compared to tubal ectopic.
Option A: There is an enhanced blood flow pattern outside the uterine cavity in case of ectopic pregnancy.

Option B: Arias-Stella reaction/phenomenon is a histological finding. It is an atypical endometrial change due to the action of progesterone on the endometrial tissue seen in normal, ectopic, and molar pregnancies.
On histology, there are:
large cells with abundant eosinophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm
nuclear enlargement
hyperchromasia

Option D: Whirlpool sign refers to the twisted ovarian pedicle seen on USG of ovarian torsion.

Solution to Question 9:
In the given scenario, the next step would be to confirm the tubal ectopic by measuring serum  hCG. This can be used to differentiate tubal ectopic pregnancy from missed abortion and early intrauterine pregnancy.
If the level is 2000 IU/L, ectopic pregnancy is suspected. If the level is <1500 IU/L, a repeat serum  hCG is taken after 48 hours. If the levels are:
Doubled - early intrauterine pregnancy
Decreased - abortion
Increased but less than doubled value - ectopic pregnancy Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:
Serum  hCG - lower levels compared to normal pregnancy, prolonged doubling time
Transvaginal ultrasound - empty uterine cavity, fluid in pouch of Douglas, adnexal mass
Colour Doppler - ring of fire pattern
Laparoscopy
Dilatation and curettage - decidua identified without villi
Serum progesterone
Culdocentesis
Diagnostic laparoscopy may be done when the diagnosis is still uncertain after serial -hCG monitoring and repeat ultrasonography. In high-risk situations, such as a history of previous ectopic pregnancy, earlier diagnostic laparoscopy is considered.

A gestational sac size of <4 cm is an indication of expectant management.
Expectant management is done only in the case of unruptured tubal pregnancy. In this, observation is done till there is spontaneous resolution. It can be done but is not preferred due to prolonged follow-up and uncertainty in resolution.
The indications are:
Initial serum  hCG <1500 IU/L
Falling serum  hCG levels
Gestational sac size <4 cm
No fetal cardiac activity on TVS
No evidence of rupture or bleeding on TVS

Solution to Question 12:
In the multi-dose protocol, methotrexate is given at a dose of 1 mg/kg as an IM injection on alternate days 1, 3, 5, and 7.
This regimen is continued on alternating days until the hCG level drops by 15% over two days. Up to 4 doses may be given. Along with this, leucovorin rescue (folinic acid) is given at 0.1 mg/kg after 24 hrs (on days 2, 4, 6, and 8) to buffer the side effects of methotrexate.
Note: If the decline is 15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L.

Solution to Question 13:
Sunlight exposure, sexual intercourse and NSAIDs must be avoided when patients are on methotrexate therapy.
The following should be avoided when methotrexate therapy has been initiated for the treatment of ectopic gestation:
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs - can cause reduced renal blood flow and delay drug excretion
Alcohol - can predispose to concurrent hepatic enzyme elevation
Sunlight - may provoke methotrexate-related dermatitis
Sexual intercourse - can rupture the ectopic pregnancy
Phenytoin, tetracyclines, salicylates, and sulfonamides - can increase serum methotrexate levels
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy which must be immediately managed with simultaneous resuscitation and laparotomy. On laparotomy, salpingectomy is the definitive surgery.
Diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made based on clinical features:
Amenorrhoea for 6-8 weeks followed by bleeding PV
Abdominal pain
Hemodynamically unstable
Urine pregnancy test - positive
Surgical treatment of ectopic pregnancy includes salpingectomy or salpingostomy, performed either through laparoscopy or laparotomy.
Management of suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy consists of initial resuscitation and stabilization, followed by point-of-care ultrasound (FAST) to identify intraperitoneal free fluid and surgical exploration.
Laparotomy is done for hemodynamically unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies. Salpingectomy is the treatment of choice and is done with preservation of the ipsilateral ovary and its vascular supply.
For patients wishing to preserve future fertility, if the contralateral fallopian tube is damaged, salpingostomy is preferred. However, salpingostomy may result in inadequate evacuation of the products of conception and a recurrence of symptoms. Therefore, after a patient undergoes salpingostomy, it is important check the -hCG level on a weekly basis to ensure that it reaches zero.

Solution to Question 15:
Spiegelberg’s criteria used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy include intact ipsilateral tube, pregnancy occupying ovary connected by the utero-ovarian ligament.
Studdiford’s criteria used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy include the presence of normal bilateral tubes and pregnancy related to the peritoneal surface.
Rubin's criteria used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy includes presence of soft, enlarged cervix and closed internal os and partially opened external os.

Anti-D is given at a dose of 300 g intramuscularly for alloimmunization after surgical management of ectopic pregnancy.
The dose of anti-D in a surgically treated case of ectopic is 50 g if gestation <12 weeks. If the gestation is >12 weeks, 300 g of anti-D is given intramuscularly.
Anti-D is not given when the ectopic is treated with medical methods.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heterotopic pregnancy. Surgery is the ideal treatment in heterotopic pregnancy.
A normal uterine pregnancy co-existing with an extrauterine (ectopic) pregnancy is termed a heterotopic pregnancy. Although heterotopic pregnancy can occur spontaneously, it is more likely after ART and ovulation induction.
Tubal ring sign also referred to as bagel sign is one of the ultrasound signs of a tubal ectopic. It comprises an echogenic ring that surrounds an unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Solution to Question 18:
Methotrexate is most effective when given at  hCG levels are <5000 IU/L.
Methotrexate is given at a dose of 50 mg/m2 of body surface area. Monitoring is done by measuring  hCG levels on days 4 and 7. If the decline is 15% of the initial value, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. If the decline is <15%, a 2nd dose of methotrexate is given on day 7.
Solution to Question 19:
Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.
Primary abdominal pregnancy is the rarest type of ectopic gestation. The conceptus implants on the peritoneal surface of the abdomen.
Studdiford’s criteria:
The presence of normal bilateral tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy.
No evidence of a uteroperitoneal fistula.
The presence of pregnancy, related exclusively to the peritoneal surface, early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation
Criteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are:
Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria); Rubin's criteria (histological criteria)
Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg’s criteria

Solution to Question 1:
Antepartum haemorrhage (APH) is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract after 28 weeks of gestation up to the delivery of the baby. The lower limit is the period of viability and the upper limit includes the 1st and 2nd stages of labour.
Causes of APH:
Placental causes:
Abruptio placenta (most common)
Placenta previa (2nd most common)
Circumvallate placenta
Circummarginate placenta
Fetal causes:
Vasa previa
Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions):
Local trauma
Varicose veins
Cervical polyp
Carcinoma cervix.
Note: According to RCOG criteria, the lower limit for APH is 24 weeks. However, in India, the period of viability is 28 weeks, so it is taken as the lower limit for APH.
Solution to Question 2:
Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage (APH).
Placental abruption or abruptio placenta is the premature separation of a normally situated placenta. The bleeding can be revealed, concealed or mixed type.
Causes of APH:
Placental causes:
Abruptio placenta (most common)
Placenta previa (2nd most common)
Circumvallate placenta
Circummarginate placenta
Fetal causes:
Vasa previa
Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions):
Local trauma
Varicose veins
Cervical polyp
Carcinoma cervix.
Solution to Question 3:
In low lying placenta, the edge of the placenta lies within 2 cm from the internal os but does not cover the internal os.
Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted over the lower uterine segment
(partially or completely).
ACOG classification of placenta previa:
True placenta previa - placenta covers the internal os partially or completely
Low lying placenta - placenta does not cover the internal os but the edge is within 2 cm of the internal os

Solution to Question 7:
Painless recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen in placenta previa. Clinical features of placenta previa:
Bleeding per vaginum - sudden onset, painless, recurrent, bright red in colour, sometimes a history of warning haemorrhage is present
Uterus - relaxed, soft, no tenderness, size proportional to the period of gestation
Floating head i.e., persistent displacement of fetal head as it cannot be pushed down into the pelvis
Fetal heart sound - present
Stallworthy sign - seen in low lying placenta, especially the posterior type. Slowing of fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved, is called Stallworthy sign.
Solution to Question 8:
Stallworthy sign is observed in posterior placenta previa.
The slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly when the pressure is relieved, is called Stallworthy sign.
Note: This sign is not always significant as this could also occur in normal pregnancies due to fetal head compression.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of antepartum haemorrhage (APH) due to placenta previa (painless bleeding PV). The next step in the management is to confirm the diagnosis with transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) as the patient is stable.
Transabdominal ultrasound (TAS) is used to detect the cause of APH.
If the placenta is in the lower uterine segment on TAS, confirmation of placenta previa is done by TVS. TVS provides a clearer image of the relationship between the edge of the placenta and the internal cervical os than TAS.
Approach to placenta previa after confirmation with TVS:
Minor placenta previa - repeat USG at 36 weeks
Major placenta previa or accreta - USG at 32 weeks followed by elective caesarean delivery
Bleeding present - individual management
On TAS, if the placenta is in the upper uterine segment with evidence of retroplacental blood clot, abruptio placenta is suspected.
Per vaginal examination in placenta previa must not be done as it may further separate the placenta and cause excessive bleeding. However, transvaginal ultrasound is safe as long as the probe is 2-3 cm away from the cervix.
Solution to Question 10:
Then given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa and precipitate labour is not a complication. Precipitate labour is seen in abruptio placenta and uterine tachysystole.
Vaginal bleeding in placenta previa is sudden in onset, recurrent, painless, unrelated to activity, and often occurs during sleep.

Solution to Question 11:
In the given clinical scenario, the next best step of management is conservative management till 37 weeks i.e., McAfee and Johnson's regimen.
The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health.
Prerequisites:
Blood for transfusion
Facilities for cesarean section
Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa:
Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%)
Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks
No active vaginal bleeding
Fetus reactive on cardiotocography and no congenital anomalies on USG Conduct of expectant treatment:
Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity
Bed rest or pelvic rest
Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding PV
Fetal surveillance with USG
Tocolytics if contractions are present
Anti-D to all Rh-negative unsensitized women
Option A: Immediate caesarean section after resuscitation is done if the patient is unstable.
Option B: Vaginal delivery is considered when the edge of the placenta is >2 cm away from the internal os.
Option D: Sher and Page grading is for abruptio placenta.

The duration of pregnancy must be less than 37 weeks for expectant management which was advocated by McAfee and Johnson.

Placental abruption is the most common cause of severe consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics.
Consumptive coagulopathy, also known as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), is a pathologic disruption of hemostasis. It is characterized by systemic activation of blood coagulation, which results in thrombosis and fibrin deposition in the small blood vessels throughout the body.
Other causes of DIC in pregnancy:
Amniotic fluid embolis
Sepsis
Preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
Postpartum haemorrhage.

Solution to Question 17:
The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe forms of concealed abruptio placenta.
There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity.
It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.
Solution to Question 18:
The doppler findings are suggestive of vasa previa. Maternal mortality is not seen in vasa previa, but fetal mortality is seen.
Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture.
Fetal mortality is high and is due to fetal exsanguination.

Investigations of vasa previa:
Colour flow Doppler (TVS)
Singer's alkali denaturation test - to detect nucleated red blood cells
Apt test (alkali denaturation test) - to detect fetal haemoglobin Management of vasa previa:
No bleeding

Solution to Question 19:
Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal haemoglobin (HbF). It is positive in vasa previa and Rh incompatibility.
Apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. It is done by taking the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding 10% NaOH. Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube.
Bleeding due to vasa previa must be managed immediately with an emergency caesarean section. Hence, Apt test is not practically done in all cases.
Other options: Bleeding due to cervical polyp, placenta previa, and abruptio placenta is of maternal origin. So, Apt test will be negative in these cases.

Apt test - to detect fetal haemoglobin Management of vasa previa:
No bleeding

Solution to Question 1:
Postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) in vaginal delivery is defined as a blood loss of more than 500 ml after completion of the third stage of labour.
In Caesarean section, blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract is called PPH. Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be:
Minor (<1L)
Major (>1L)
Severe (>2L)
In most cases, the magnitude of haemorrhage cannot be assessed accurately as visual estimates are unreliable.
Note: as per the latest ACOG guidelines, PPH is defined as cumulative blood loss 1000 mL or bleeding associated with hypovolaemia in the first 24 hours after birth, irrespective of the route of delivery. It is added that despite the new definition, blood loss >500 mL in a vaginal delivery should raise suspicion and mandates further evaluation.
Solution to Question 2:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara.
Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.
Types of PPH:
Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH.
Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained placenta is the most common cause.
The risk factors for atonic uterus include:
Primiparity or grand multiparity
Previous PPH
Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia
Precipitate labour
Prolonged labour
Uterine malformations
Uterine fibroid
Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta
Obesity
Age >40 years
Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.
Solution to Question 3:
Retained cotyledon is the most probable cause of late or secondary PPH i.e., bleeding that occurs after 24 hours of delivery.
Other options are causes of early PPH. Types of PPH include:
Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. The causes are: (mnemonic 4T)
Tone: Atonic PPH (è0%)
Trauma: Traumatic PPH
Thrombin: Coagulopathy
Tissue: retained products of conception Risk Factors for primary PPH:
Atonic PPH:

Solution to Question 7:
As per the latest guidelines, uterine massage is no longer a core component of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) that is performed for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
Uterine massage or fundal massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin (core component of AMTSL). Hence, it is now an optional component of AMTSL that is done in patients with uterine atony as a part of the management of PPH.
AMTSL is recommended by the WHO to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Uterotonics are the most important components in AMTSL to do so.

Solution to Question 12:
Using a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) is not one of the first measures for the management of atonic PPH. NASG is used to reduce bleeding and stabilize the patient for shifting to tertiary centers.
The below image shows a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment.

Non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) works by applying circumferential counterpressure. It decreases blood flow to the abdomen, pelvis, and lower extremities. It increases the blood flow to the heart, lungs, and brain.
First step measures in the management of PPH must be done immediately and simultaneously. This includes:
Continuous iv oxytocin infusion
Fundal massage and bimanual uterine compression
Volume resuscitation with crystalloids
Insertion of Foley’s catheter to monitor urine output
Alert the anesthesia team to begin a manual exploration of the uterus under GA to check for:
Retained placental fragments
Uterine abnormalities
Lacerations
Rupture
Blood transfusion should be done if vitals are still unstable
If bleeding still continues, further steps are taken depending on the patient profile:
Balloon tamponade
Surgical methods:
B lynch compression sutures
Uterine artery ligation
Internal iliac artery ligation
Angiographic embolization
Hysterectomy.

Solution to Question 14:
The image shows a Bakri balloon. It is used in uterine tamponade in patients with atonic PPH who are unresponsive to medical management.
The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterine cavity.

It acts by stimulating uterine contraction and direct hemostatic pressure to the open uterine sinuses (tamponade effect).
The maximum capacity of the balloon is 500mL. It is inflated with normal saline (200-500mL) and can be retained for up to 12 hours. Success rates are high and it can be used to avoid hysterectomy.
Other options: Sengstaken Blakemore tube, condom catheter, and 34F Foley with 60mL balloon are other instruments that can be used for uterine tamponade.
The image below depicts Sengstaken Blakemore tube.

The image below depicts Foley's catheter.

Solution to Question 15:
The capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH is 300 to 500 mL.
Bakri balloon is used in uterine tamponade in cases of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management.
Insertion of Bakri balloon requires three team members.
One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure.
Another member places the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilizes it.
The third member instills fluid to inflate the balloon.
Initially, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL of normal saline is done. It is followed by further infusion over a few minutes up to 300 to 500 mL.

Balloon tamponade is the next step in the management of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management and bimanual uterine massage.

Option A: Tight intrauterine packing has become unpopular due to the dangers of concealed bleeding and infections. It can be used in low-resource settings while shifting the patient to tertiary care centers.
Option C: Uterine artery ligation is done when tamponade fails (Bakri balloon and compression sutures).
Option D: Hysterectomy is the last option when all the other treatment modalities fail. Usually, the uterus contracts and bleeding stops with ligation or embolization. However, hysterectomy is done sooner rather than later in cases of placenta accreta and uterine rupture.

All these stitches are types of uterine compression sutures. They used to surgically oppose the walls of the uterus to arrest bleeding in case of atonic PPH.
Solution to Question 19:
The procedure is B-lynch compression sutures and it is used in atonic PPH.
B lynch suture is a technique to arrest hemorrhage in severe postpartum atony.

The suture bites are taken over the lower uterine segment anteriorly. Then it is looped over the fundus to go posterior. Another bite is taken posteriorly. Then it is looped back over the fundus and taken anteriorly. The final bite is taken over the lower uterine segment and the free ends are tied in a surgical knot.
The uterus is compressed antero-posteriorly.
The success rate is high.
Ischaemic uterine necrosis is a complication of this procedure.

Solution to Question 21:
The most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion.
Hydramnios is a risk factor for uterine inversion due to uterine over-distension. Fundal pressure while the uterus is atonic (soft, relaxed, and boggy) causes uterine inversion. It results in haemorrhage followed by complete uterine inversion protruding out of the vulva. Neurogenic type of shock develops due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament and the ovaries.
Option A: Amniotic fluid embolism causes cardiac arrest, acute hypoxia and severe haemorrhage.
Option B: There was only moderate bleeding per vaginum and soft uterus. But since there is protrusion of the uterus per vaginum, the most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion.
Option D: Placenta accreta rarely causes uterine inversion.
Uterine inversion is an extremely rare but life-threatening complication in the 3rd stage of labor, in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely.
Causes:
Most common cause is mismanagement of 3rd stage of labour
Spontaneous
Placenta accreta (rarely)
Features:
Shock immediately after delivery
The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding
Shock is either neurogenic or hemorrhagic

Solution to Question 4:
A cervical length of 32 mm (3 cm) does not help in confirming preterm labour as it is highly unlikely when the cervical length is >3 cm. The length of the cervix in preterm labour, as measured in transvaginal ultrasound is 2.5 cm.
Preterm labor is the onset of labor before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation).
Features of preterm labor:
Uterus - regular contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, with/without pain
Cervix - dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80%
TVS - length of cervix <2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm
Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge or bleeding PV Predictors of preterm labor:
Clinical predictors:
History of prior preterm birth
Multiple pregnancies
Presence of genital tract infection
Symptoms of preterm labour
Biophysical predictors:
Uterine contractions 4/hour
Bishop score 4
Cervical length (TVS) 25 mm
Biochemical predictors:
Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervical/vaginal discharge >50 ng/mL
Increased levels of IL-6, IL-8, TNF-alpha
The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on TVS.

It is measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. When the test is negative, it reassures that the delivery will not occur within the next 7 days.

Solution to Question 16:
Magnesium sulphate can cause multiple fractures and hypocalcemia in a preterm baby.
The FDA warned against prolonged use of magnesium sulphate to arrest preterm labour. The antagonistic effect of magnesium lowers the calcium levels in the fetus. This causes bone thinning and fractures in fetuses exposed to the drug for more than 5 to 7 days.

ACOG defines post-term pregnancy as a pregnancy continuing beyond 42 completed weeks of gestation.
For clinical purposes, a pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery
(> 294 days) is called a post-term pregnancy.
Inaccurate LMP is the most common cause of misdiagnosis of post-term pregnancy. Hence, early ultrasound dating is important to determine fetal gestational age.

Solution to Question 1:
Partial hydatidiform mole has a 69XXY or 69XYY karyotype.
Hydatiform mole belongs to the benign group of gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD). It is an abnormality in chorionic villi making them partly proliferative and degenerative, thereby resulting in the formation of multiple small cysts. Based on the portion of the chorionic villi involved, they could be complete (diffused) or partial (focal)
Solution to Question 2:
Early ultrasonography is not highly sensitive in a patient with partial molar pregnancy. However, USG features like thickened, multicystic placenta along with fetal tissue or even a fetus may be seen.
Hydatidiform mole or molar pregnancy is an abnormal condition of the placenta. It is characterized by trophoblastic proliferation and stromal edema. They are classified into complete and partial moles based on the absence or presence of embryonic elements.
Pathogenesis of complete and partial moles are as follows:


Solution to Question 3:
Vitamin A deficiency, not Vitamin C deficiency is a risk factor for hydatidiform mole. Risk factors for hydatidiform mole are:
Maternal age - pregnancy in teenage and women >35 years
Previous history of gestational trophoblastic disease
Dietary deficiency - vitamin A deficiency, inadequate protein and animal fat intake
AB blood group.
Solution to Question 4:
Theca lutein cysts are rare in partial molar pregnancy, but may be seen in 25-30% of patients with complete molar pregnancy.
Serum -hCG levels are elevated more than expected for gestational age in a complete mole.
The sensitivity of most hCG tests is set to the pregnancy hCG range. An excessive -hCG hormone causes an oversaturation of the test assay giving a false negative UPT. This is called the hook effect.
The thyrotropin-like effects of hCG frequently cause serum free-T4 levels to be elevated which normalize after uterine evacuation.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario and USG showing snowstorm appearance is suggestive of a complete mole.
The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces. Fetus and amniotic sac are absent.
Investigations for molar pregnancy are:
USG - shows snowstorm appearance
Serum  hCG - elevated to >2 MoM (multiples of median) for corresponding gestational age
Histological examination of products of conception Snowstorms in radiology:
Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound)
Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound)
Carcinoma thyroid - pulmonary metastases (chest X-ray).
Solution to Question 6:
The given USG image shows theca lutein cysts in the ovary. These cysts are usually seen in patients with complete molar pregnancies. They are usually bilateral and are also seen in multiple pregnancies.
Theca lutein cysts result from the overstimulation of lutein elements by massive amounts of 
hCG. The cystic fluid is rich in chorionic gonadotropin, estrogen, and progesterone.
Solution to Question 7:
Untwisting of the cyst is the only management in an asymptomatic patient with a twisted theca lutein cyst.
Laparoscopic oophorectomy is done only when there is associated extensive necrosis or hemorrhage.
Theca-lutein cysts regress within 2 months after pregnancy evacuation, and hence expectant management is preferred in uncomplicated cases. If the cysts are symptomatic, they can be aspirated trans-abdominally under ultrasound guidance.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy which is managed by suction and evacuation, regardless of uterine size.
If the cervix is unfavorable, slow dilatation is done with vaginal PGE1. Volume resuscitation with IV fluids and parenteral antibiotics can be given as supportive therapy. Blood transfusion is done
if the patient is anaemic.
Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.
Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:
Women who have completed their family
Age >40 years
Uncontrolled hemorrhage
Perforation during surgical evacuation.
Solution to Question 9:
In the given scenario, the patient is followed up with serum  hCG every month for 6 months.
Follow-up after the termination of molar pregnancy is done with serum  hCG levels. During the follow-up period, pregnancy must be avoided as it might interfere with the  hCG levels.
The initial -hCG level is obtained within 48 hours after evacuation and used as a baseline.
It is measured weekly till it becomes negative, and three consecutive normal values are obtained. This normally happens in 4-8 weeks.
After this,  hCG levels are measured monthly for 6 months. Women who undergo chemotherapy must be followed up for 1 year.
Solution to Question 10:
Thyrotoxicosis is seen as a complication of molar pregnancy, not hypothyroidism. Complications in molar pregnancy include:
Immediate:
Early-onset pre-eclampsia - molar placentas produce more antiangiogenic proteins than normal placentas.
Thyrotoxicosis - as  component of hCG mimics TSH and causes thyroid storm
Acute pulmonary insufficiency - due to embolization of trophoblastic cells
Electrolyte imbalance i.e., hypokalemia, hyponatremia - due to hyperemesis caused by  hCG
Shock - hemorrhage due to the separation of vesicles and intra-peritoneal haemorrhage
Disseminated intravascular coagulation
Late: Choriocarcinoma.

A partial mole is not a gestational trophoblastic neoplasm (GTN).
Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is the term used to describe a group of tumors due to abnormal trophoblast proliferation. Malignant forms of GTD are termed gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

Solution to Question 13:
Chorioadenoma destruens or invasive mole is the most common non-metastatic GTN that follows hydatidiform moles. Almost all invasive moles arise from partial or complete moles.
Invasive mole is characterized by extensive tissue invasion by trophoblast and whole villi. They can penetrate deep into the myometrium, peritoneum, parametrium, or vaginal vault. They are locally aggressive and do not usually metastasize.
The most common GTN following term pregnancy or miscarriage is choriocarcinoma.

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated -hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN:
Persistence of -hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longe
Rise in -hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longe
Elevated -hCG level for 6 months or more
Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma
Treatment for low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from implantation site intermediate trophoblast. As syncytiotrophoblastic cells are generally absent in this site, it is composed mainly
of cytotrophoblastic cells.
Patients with placental site trophoblastic tumors present with vaginal bleeding and modestly elevated serum -hCG levels. Local invasion into the myometrium and lymphatics occurs.
Hysterectomy is the preferred treatment.

Solution to Question 2:
The second most common pathological cause of anemia during pregnancy is anemia associated with chronic disease. The most common pathological cause of anemia during pregnancy is iron deficiency anemia.
Women with chronic disorders may develop anemia for the first time during pregnancy. Causes include:
Chronic renal insufficiency - the most common cause. Recombinant erythropoietin is used for treating anemia due to chronic renal failure.
Inflammatory bowel disease
Connective tissue disorders
Granulomatous infections
Malignant neoplasms
Rheumatoid arthritis
Chronic suppurative conditions.
Note: The most common cause of anemia in pregnancy is physiological. It is normally seen during pregnancy. This occurs due to the expansion of plasma volume by 30–40%. This increase is much more than the increase in red cell mass (20-30%) during pregnancy. This leads
to hemodilution and an apparent decrease in hemoglobin levels.
Solution to Question 3:
Maternal requirement of iron during a singleton gestation averages close to 1000 mg.
The average iron stores in a non-pregnant female is around 300 mg. This falls short of the requirement of iron during pregnancy which is 1000 mg. Hence iron supplementation is necessary to prevent iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy. This also forms the basis for prophylactic iron supplementation during pregnancy.
Note: The Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (FOGSI) states that the iron requirement in pregnancy is 840 mg, as about 160 mg of iron is saved due to amenorrhea during pregnancy.

pregnancy. Ideally, this must be continued until 180 days postpartum.
Solution to Question 5:
The amount of folic acid to be given to pregnant women suffering from sickle cell anemia is 5 mg.
This is to reduce the risk of neural tube defects and to compensate for the increased demand for folate during pregnancy.
Normally in all sickle cell patients (irrespective of age or sex), 1mg of folic acid is given to prevent folate deficiency.
Note: William's Obstetrics 26th Edition mentions folic acid 4 mg daily for pregnant women with sickle cell disease. However various other sources and RCOG guidelines mention it as 5 mg daily. Hence this is the best answer.
Solution to Question 6:
In the given scenario, history suggestive of restless leg syndrome and Hb of 10.1g/dL points to a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. Serum ferritin is the most sensitive indicator of iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women.
This is because its concentrations are not affected by the recent intake of iron-rich foods. Serum ferritin concentration <15 g/L indicates iron deficiency anemia.
However, treatment needs to be initiated when the concentration falls <30 g/L, as this indicates early iron depletion.
Restless leg syndrome also called Willis-Ekbom Disease, causes unpleasant or uncomfortable sensations in the legs along with an irresistible urge to move them. It may be associated with iron deficiency anemia.
Solution to Question 7:
In the given clinical scenario presence of microcytic hypochromic RBCs indicates iron deficiency anemia, and hyper segmented neutrophils indicate anemia due to folic acid or vitamin B12 deficiency. This is also known as dimorphic anemia.
Blood picture in iron deficiency anemia:
Microcytic hypochromic RBCs
Typical photo pencil cells
Presence of poikilocytes (pre-erythrocytes)
Blood picture in folic acid/vitamin B12 deficiency anemia:
Hyper segmented neutrophils - earliest change
Macrocytic RBCs

Solution to Question 8:
The given scenario is suggestive of pica associated with moderate iron-deficiency anemia. Since the anemia was diagnosed late in pregnancy, the most appropriate treatment is parenteral iron therapy. Ferrous sucrose is a form of parenteral iron given as an IV infusion.
If anemia is diagnosed:
In the first trimester - Oral iron therapy is preferred
In the second trimester - Oral iron therapy should be switched over to parenteral iron if Hb falls
<8g/dl or if serum ferritin is <15ng/ml
In the third trimester - Parenteral iron therapy is preferred
Ferrous sucrose is the most commonly used preparation for IV infusion. It is safe and does not require a test dose.
Other iron preparations include:
Oral preparations- Ferrous sulfate, ferrous gluconate, ferrous ascorbate
IM preparations- Iron sorbitol, Iron polymaltose
IV preparations- Ferric carboxymaltose
Both IM and IV- Iron dextran.
Solution to Question 9:
Ferric carboxymaltose is considered superior to all other parenteral iron supplementation especially for iron deficiency anemia in postpartum women.
Ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) is a dextran-free IV iron preparation. It allows rapid administration of high doses of iron (up to 1000 mg iron in 15 min).
It is safe and effective in improving the mean Hb level. It avoids the need for blood transfusions.
Solution to Question 10:
The formula for calculating dose of parenteral iron is:
Total dose in mg = 2.4 š (Target Hb - Actual Hb) š Body Wt. + 500 mg

question_text:
4 - conversion factor
Target Hb - Hb you want to achieve
Actual Hb- level of current Hb
500 mg - additional amount to replenish the iron stores
Iron sucrose must be diluted only using normal saline at a concentration of 1-2 mg of iron/mL of saline. It is given over 20-30 minutes intravenously.
Solution to Question 11:
Parenteral iron therapy for iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy is avoided if the patient has a history of chronic liver disease.
It is used as an alternative therapy in people who cannot tolerate oral iron. Contraindications include:
A history of prior anaphylactic reaction to parenteral iron therapy
First trimester of pregnancy - there is no evidence on the use of IV iron in the first trimester of pregnancy
Chronic liver disease
Active infection (acute or chronic)
A sensitivity test prior to the infusion is not mandatory. IV iron should be given with caution even if previous administrations have been well tolerated.
Oral iron should be stopped at least 24 hours prior to therapy to avoid iron toxicity.
Solution to Question 12:
The treatment of choice for severe anemia (< 7g/dL) in the third trimester is packed cell transfusion. It is preferred over whole blood as it avoids volume overload.
Indications of blood transfusion in pregnancy include:
Pregnancy <34 weeks
Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
Pregnancy >34 weeks - Hb <7 g/dL.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario points to vitamin B12 deficiency. It is treated by vitamin B12 injections with folic acid supplementation. 1000 g of IM cyanocobalamin should be given initially every week for 6 weeks, following which it should be given once every month.
Megaloblastic anemia caused by Vit B12 deficiency should be identified and treated accordingly because folic acid supplementation alone will not help.
Causes of Vit B12 deficiency leading to anemia in pregnancy:
Gastric resection
Addisonian pernicious anemia
Crohn’s disease
Ileal resection
Bacterial overgrowth in the small bowel.
Solution to Question 14:
Among the given options, patients with sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing urinary tract infections.
Sickle cell disease, on the other hand, is associated with increased risk of :
Miscarriages
Fetal growth restriction
Preterm labor
Venous thromboembolism
Pre-eclampsia
Placental abruption
Fetal distress in labor
Note: Sickle cell trait is a benign condition in which the affected person has only one abnormal hemoglobin beta gene allele whereas, in sickle cell disease, the affected person has two abnormal hemoglobin beta gene alleles and is hence severely symptomatic. Unlike individuals with sickle cell disease, those with sickle cell trait do not have symptoms related to sickling and mostly lead a normal life.
Solution to Question 15:
Low-dose oral progestins or progesterone injections or implants are ideal contraceptives in a patient with sickle cell anemia. Progesterone has been known to prevent painful sickle cell crises.
It is considered very safe in pregnancy. It is rated level 1 indicating that there is no restriction in their use.
Contraceptive methods and their safety profile in sickle cell anemia: Level 1 contraceptives (no restriction):
Progestogen-only injection (DMPA)
Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Mirena)
Emergency contraception containing progestins
Level 2 contraceptives (advantages outweigh disadvantages):
Combined oral contraceptive
Copper intrauterine device.
Solution to Question 16:
In thalassemia major, both oral and parenteral iron preparations are avoided. This is because these patients are already in a state of iron overload due to multiple blood transfusions.
Pregnancy in patients with thalassemia major is very rare. In case pregnancy occurs the following strategies are adopted:
Iron chelating agents should be stopped
5mg folic acid supplementation should be given daily
Pneumococcal vaccination and boosters are advised prior to pregnancy
Repeated blood transfusions are given to maintain Hb levels above 10 g/dL
Breastfeeding is safe and iron chelation therapy can be resumed post-delivery.

Solution to Question 1:
Gestational hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 after 20 weeks of gestation.
Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as BP of >140/90 mmHg measured 2 times with at least a 4-hour interval.
Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia. Pre-eclampsia is hypertension with any of the following features:
Proteinuria
Thrombocytopenia
Renal insufficiency
Liver involvement
Cerebral symptoms
Pulmonary edema.
Note: A normotensive pregnant woman may have an acute increase in BP from baseline levels and develop eclamptic seizures/HELLP syndrome, despite being normotensive. This condition is known as delta hypertension.

Solution to Question 2:
The cut-off for defining proteinuria is 30 mg/dl (0.3 g/L) in a random urine sample. Proteinuria in preeclampsia is also defined by:
0.3 g protein in a 24-hour urine specimen.
Random urine protein: creatinine ratio (PCR) 0.3 mg protein/mg creatinine
Protein 1+ on urine dipstick
A urine dipstick is used only if the above quantitative methods are not available. Note: Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia.
Solution to Question 3:
In a normal pregnancy, the remodeling of spiral arteries begins at 12 weeks.
Remodeling of arteries includes invasion of arteries by trophoblasts that convert them from low-flow, high-resistance to high-flow, low-resistance vessels. These modified vessels are more capable of meeting the demands of the developing fetus.
’teroplacental vessel development takes place in two stages:
The first stage occurs before 12 weeks post-fertilization. During this stage, invasion of spiral arteries up to myometrium occurs.
The second stage occurs between 12-16 weeks. It involves invasion of the endovascular trophoblasts into the intra-myometrial segments of spiral arteries. Interstitial trophoblasts surround the arteries.
Incomplete trophoblastic invasion leads to pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) where the vessels remain in a state of high resistance leading to placental ischemia and release of inflammatory mediators and vasoactive substances leading to endothelial injury.
As the second stage of invasion occurs by 18 weeks, PIH develops after 20 weeks of pregnancy.
Solution to Question 4:
In the above scenario of hypertension in a patient with gestational age <20 weeks, the diagnosis is chronic hypertension.
Chronic hypertension is diagnosed when the patient is a known hypertensive (or) BP > 140/90 mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation.
Gestational hypertension and preeclampsia are only diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation.
Solution to Question 5:
Smoking is not a risk factor for pre-eclampsia rather it is protective.
Although smoking during pregnancy causes various adverse pregnancy outcomes, it is associated with a reduced risk for hypertension in pregnancy.
Risk factors for pre-eclampsia are:
Previous history of pre-eclampsia
Primigravida: young or elderly
Family history: Hypertension, pre-eclampsia.
Placental abnormalities:
Hyperplacentosis: excessive exposure to chorionic villi (molar pregnancy, twins, diabetes)
Placental ischemia
Thrombophilias: APLA, Protein C, Protein S deficiency, Factor V laden mutation, homocysteinemia
Twin pregnancy
Molar pregnancy
Rh-negative pregnancy
New paternity - A new partner for subsequent pregnancies
Solution to Question 6:
Placental perfusion is reduced in patients developing pre-eclampsia. The development of pre-eclampsia may be explained by:
Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels, leading to decreased placental perfusion.
Maternal inflammatory response directed against foreign fetal antigens leading to immunological maladaptation.
Maternal maladaptation to cardiovascular and inflammatory changes of normal pregnancy.
Genetic factors and epigenetic influences.
Solution to Question 7:
Calcium supplementation above the RDA does not reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia.
However, women who have a calcium-deficient state may benefit from calcium supplementation to reduce their risk of preeclampsia.
Prophylactic measures for the prevention of pre-eclampsia include low-dose aspirin administration (50–150 mg/day). It is started after the 1st trimester, continued throughout pregnancy, and is to be stopped 7 days before labor.
Magnesium administration may be beneficial as it lowers endothelin-1 concentrates. There is no role of a low salt diet, anti-oxidants, or vitamin C.
Solution to Question 8:
In pre-eclampsia, there is an increase in the level of soluble endoglin.
Excessive amounts of antiangiogenic factors, increased sensitivity to angiotensin, and lowered angiotensinase levels worsen hypoxia at the uteroplacental interface.
Trophoblast of women who develop preeclampsia overproduces at least two antiangiogenic peptides that enter the maternal circulation. They increase months before clinical preeclampsia develops.
Soluble endoglin (sEng) is derived from the placenta and blocks endothelial nitric oxide-dependent vasodilatation. It also inhibits various TGF isoforms from binding to endothelial receptors.
Soluble Fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) is a variant of the Flt-1 receptor for placental growth factor (PlGF) and for VEGF. Increased maternal sFlt-1 levels inactivate and decrease circulating free PlGF and VEGF concentrations, leading to endothelial dysfunction.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of pre-eclampsia and low fibronectin is not a feature of pre-eclampsia.
Features associated with pre-eclampsia:
Fibronectin is a glycoprotein associated with vascular endothelial cell basement membrane and is elevated in women with preeclampsia.
Thrombocytopenia (HELLP syndrome)
Hemolysis (HELLP syndrome)
Increased hemoglobin, caused by a decrease in plasma volume.
Hemoconcentration is a hallmark of eclampsia. In preeclampsia, hemoconcentration is present but usually not marked.
Solution to Question 10:
Decreased GFR is seen in pre-eclampsia.
During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and GFR are increased. However, in pre-eclampsia, renal blood flow and GFR decrease due to increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance. The hallmark renal lesion is glomerular endotheliosis. Diminished filtration causes serum creatinine levels and plasma uric acid concentration levels to rise. The elevation is also due to enhanced tubular reabsorption.
The most common system involved in pre-eclampsia is the renal system.
Several studies have demonstrated that pre-eclampsia is associated with low urinary calcium. This is often used as a predictive test.
Solution to Question 11:
Serous retinal detachment does not cause permanent visual loss. The most common visual symptom of preeclampsia is scotoma.
Blindness can be due to occipital cortex edema, Purtscher’s retinopathy (retinal ischemia), or retinal detachment. The blindness is mostly reversible and corrects automatically after delivery.
Retinal artery occlusion sometimes causes permanent vision loss.
Solution to Question 12:
The above clinical scenario and radiological image are suggestive of posterior reversible leukoencephalopathy syndrome (PRES). This condition is usually reversible.
Endothelial dysfunction and cerebral autoregulation failure are implicated as etiologies of PRES. PRES lesions are almost universal in women with eclampsia but less frequent in
pre-eclampsia.
PRES is characterized by the following:
Severe headaches
Altered sensorium
Seizures
Visual disturbances. Radiological findings in PRES:
Hyperintense T2 lesions in the subcortical and cortical regions of the parietal and occipital lobes.
The basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellum are commonly involved.
Posterior circulation is commonly involved, and anterior circulation involvement is seen in severe cases.
Neurological manifestations of preeclampsia include:
Headaches
Convulsions
Cerebral edema
Blindness
Cerebral hemorrhage.

Among the given statements, the presence of pulmonary edema, scotoma, or epigastric pain is indicative of severe pre-eclampsia.
Criteria for diagnosing severe preeclampsia include:
Signs and symptoms of significant end-organ dysfunction are:
New-onset cerebral or visual disturbance i.e., photopsia, scotoma, altered mental status, and severe headache
Severe, persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, unresponsive to medication and not accounted for by an alternative diagnosis (OR) Serum transaminase concentration 2 times upper imit of normal.

Progressive renal insufficiency (serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dL)
Pulmonary edema.

Limb contracture
Pulmonary hypoplasia.

Angiotensin receptor blockers
Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in CCF)
Reserpine
Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension)
Diazoxide.

Solution to Question 19:
Corticosteroid treatment for thrombocytopenia is not recommended in patients with HELLP syndrome.
HELLP syndrome is a serious complication in pregnancy characterized by HEmolysis, ELevated liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count. It occurs in 0.5-0.9% of all pregnancies and in 10–20% of patients with severe preeclampsia.
Management of HELLP syndrome is supportive, including:
Antiseizure prophylaxis with MgSO4
Platelet tansfusion if platelet count <50,000/mm3 , FFP transfusion
Plasmapheresis
Immediate termination of pregnancy in the interest of the mother.
The most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome is abruptio placenta and DIC.

If pregnancy is at 27-34 weeks - in the absence of contraindications, expectant management is followed and the baby is delivered at 34 weeks, as shown below in the flowchart.

Solution to Question 24:
MgSO4 blocks calcium influx, not sodium. Mechanism of action of MgSO4:
It is a membrane stabilizer and acts as a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach.
It blocks neuronal calcium influx.
It reduces the presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate.
It blocks glutaminergic NMDA receptors and potentiates adenosine action.
Solution to Question 25:
Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if knee jerks are present.
The next dose of MgSO4 is only given when all signs of magnesium toxicity are absent. Signs of magnesium toxicity:
Loss of deep tendon reflexes
Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min)
’rine output <30 ml/hr
Chest pain, heart block Management of magnesium toxicity:
Stop magnesium therapy
Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
Injection of calcium gluconate 10 ml (10% solution) IV Side effects of MgSO4:
Anuria
Pulmonary edema.
Solution to Question 26:
Patellar reflexes disappear when plasma magnesium concentration reaches 10 mEq/L. As there is no respiratory depression, the plasma concentration is likely to be 10-12 mEq/L.
The disappearance of the patellar reflex is the first sign of impending magnesium toxicity. MgSO4 is prophylactically used in impending eclampsia, severe pre-eclampsia, and HELLP syndrome.
Signs of magnesium toxicit y
Plasma concentrations of ma gnesium (mEq/L)
Loss of patellar reflex

Solution to Question 27:
Magnesium sulfate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a premature baby, where there is a deficit of surfactant (which results in alveolar collapse).
Magnesium in the MgSO4 competes with calcium on voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby altering its uptake and release. Functions of MgSO4 include :
Membrane protector and neuro stabilizer. It is used in the prevention of cerebral palsy in very ow birth weight neonates.
Reduction of motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine, and thus is used as an adjunct in the management of acute severe asthma in children and adults
Blocking of neuronal calcium influx, and is thus used in the conservative management of pre-term labor (tocolytic, option D)
Inducing cerebral vasodilatation, dilating the uterine arteries, increasing the production of endothelial prostacyclin, and inhibiting platelet activation. Hence it is used in the management of pre-eclampsia (option A) and to prevent progression to eclampsia (option A).
Solution to Question 28:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and management may be based on recommendations from the Magpie trial.
The Magpie trial showed that prophylactic use of magnesium sulfate lowers the risk of eclampsia.
The first step in the management of eclampsia is maintaining the airway, ensuring oxygen delivery to both mother and fetus. Then, MgSO4 is administered to control seizures.
Thiopentone > phenobarbitone may be used to control seizures. No attempt should be made to shorten the convulsion using diazepam as it often leads to thrombophlebitis and respiratory depression.
Maternal acidosis usually occurs and is corrected when present.
Solution to Question 29:
Antepartum eclampsia has the worst prognosis and the most common MRI finding of eclampsia is subcortical white matter edema.
Antepartum eclampsia is the most common type of eclampsia. It has the highest rate of maternal mortality.
The outcome of eclampsia depends on the duration of hypertension and not severity. The most common cause of death in eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia is intracranial bleeding.
Solution to Question 30:
Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation. The image shows compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus which can sometimes lead to supine hypotension.
During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine, when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but the aorta, owing to its structure is relatively resistant.
Normally, the vena cava compression results in opening up collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygous veins but in some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed resulting in hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome.
The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position.

Solution to Question 1:
Obesity in first-degree relatives is not a high-risk factor for gestational diabetes mellitus. However, severe obesity is a risk factor for developing gestational diabetes.
Gestational diabetes mellitus is defined as carbohydrate intolerance of variable severity with onset or first recognition during the present pregnancy.
It usually presents in the second or third trimester. More than 50% of women with GDM ultimately develop overt diabetes within 20 years.
It is recommended to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus in the presence of the following high-risk factors:
Severe obesity
Strong family history of type-2 diabetes
Previous history of gestational diabetes mellitus
Impaired glucose metabolism or glucosuria.
Solution to Question 2:
Overt diabetes is when fasting blood sugar is  126 mg/dl. Overt diabetics are women who are known to have diabetes before pregnancy.
A patient is said to have overt diabetes if:
Fasting blood sugar  126 mg/dL
A random blood sugar of  200 mg/dL
HbA1c of  6.5%
The maternal complication of diabetes:
increased Miscarriage and preterm labor.
increased incidence of preeclampsia
polyhydramnios
prolongation of labor due to shoulder dystocia, operative interference, and cephalo-pelvic disproportion.
Fetal and Neonatal complications of diabetes:
fetal macrosomia (birth weight > 4kg)
congenital malformations - Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies.

In two-step approach patient is given glucose and subsequent values measured in two separate steps.
Step 1 - the patient is given 50 grams of glucose and blood glucose is measured after one hour. If it is 140 mg/dl then the screen is positive and step 2 is done.

According to the American college of obstetricians (ACOG), macrosomia is defined as the fetal birth weight of  4.5 kg.
Macrosomia refers to growth beyond a specific threshold, regardless of gestational age. In developed countries, the most commonly used threshold is the weight above 4.5 kg, but weight above 4 kg is also commonly used.
The WHO defines the cut-off at 4.0 kg for fetal macrosomia in its guidelines for the management of common maternal conditions. This is followed in India.

BMI (body mass index) is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia in both diabetic and non-diabetic mothers.
BMI levels are associated with increased birth weight, regardless of glucose levels. Gestational diabetes prevalence increases by approximately 1 percent for every 1 kg/m2 increase in BMI.
BMI cutoffs for pregnancy:
Underweight - < 18 kg/m2 Normal - 18.5 to 24.9 kg/m2
Overweight - 25 to 29.9 kg/m2 Obese - >30 kg/m2
Weight distribution also seems to play a role because the risk of gestational diabetes is increased with truncal obesity. HbA1c levels are associated with fetal malformations in pre-gestational diabetes.

Solution to Question 15:
Tetrology of Fallot (TOF) is usually not seen in infants of diabetic mothers.
Ventricular septal defect and transposition of great arteries are the most common cardiac anomalies in infants of diabetic mothers.
Cardiac defects that present more often in infants of diabetic mothers are:
Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
Double outlet right ventricle (DORV)
Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
Truncus arteriosus
Tricuspid atresia
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
The most common cardiac anomaly in an infant of a diabetic mother is a controversial topic. Most resources mention VSD and TGA are the most common and do not specify which among them is more common.
Solution to Question 16:
Hypocalcemia in a newborn is defined as serum calcium < 8 mg/dl.
Hypocalcemia is one of the potential metabolic derangements in neonates of diabetic mothers.
There is hypomagnesemia in the mother and the infant due to increased maternal urinary excretion of magnesium due to diabetes. There is maternal hyperparathyroidism due to hypomagnesemia which leads to increased maternal calcium.
This maternal calcium passes to the infant through the placenta and suppresses fetal PTH synthesis and impairs PTH response to postpartum hypocalcemia. PTH suppression, in this case, can be severe and lead to convulsions in the early neonatal period and may persist for months.
Solution to Question 17:
Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as blood glucose levels <45 mg/dL.
Maternal hyperglycemia stimulates the fetal pancreas to secrete excess insulin, which causes increased neonatal fat deposition, abdominal girth, and macrosomia (Pederson's hypothesis). It also leads to a rapid drop in plasma glucose concentration after delivery.
Solution to Question 18:
The image showing a poorly developed lower limb suggests the diagnosis of caudal regression sequence/sacral agenesis seen in pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes.
The caudal regression sequence is a rare malformation, frequently associated with maternal pre-gestational diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae.
E evated maternal HbA1c levels correlate with fetal malformations. It occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants.
Overt diabetes (pregestational diabetes) is associated with higher malformation rates than the general population. Neural tube defects (encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen.
Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters. Option B: Malformations are not associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
Malformations occur due to the disruption of organogenesis, usually occurring in the first
trimester. The abnormal glycemic status in GDM manifests only in the second trimester. Option C: Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis.
Option D: ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.
Solution to Question 19:
Intrauterine devices are the most effective contraceptive choice in patients with gestational diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
It is suitable in patients with diabetes and comorbidities like obesity, hypertension, or dyslipidemia. It is a method without potential cardiovascular consequences, unlike hormonal contraceptives.
Low-dose hormonal contraceptives can be used safely in women with gestational diabetes if there are no associated comorbidities.
Even though the barrier method will not lead to complications in such patients, the failure rate is high due to incorrect use and non-compliance. Hence it is not preferred.
Option D: DMPA(depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate) is an injectable hormonal contraceptive that is contraindicated in diabetic pregnant women with co-morbidities.

Cardiac failure in pregnancy is least likely to occur during 24 weeks, considering the given options.
The order of risk of cardiac failure in pregnancy is immediate postpartum > 2nd stage of labor
> 30 weeks > 22 weeks.
Maternal cardiac risk predictors: [Mnemonic: NOPE] N-NYHA class >2
O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2 or aortic valve area <1.5 cm2, peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg)

Scoring systems used to calculate risk are Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy (CARPREG) and ZAHARA scores.

Solution to Question 5:
Prosthetic valve replacement is not an indication for therapeutic termination as it comes under the WHO category risk 3. Only conditions included under WHO category risk 4 are considered as indications for termination of pregnancy.
WHO class 4 comprises of diseases with very high risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity, such as:
Pulmonary arterial hypertensio
Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (NYHA III-IV or LVEF 30-40%)
Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular functio
Severe left heart obstructio
Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >40 mm
Termination of pregnancy is also advised in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome.
Solution to Question 6:
Primary pulmonary hypertension is not a cardiac indication for caesarean delivery.
In primary pulmonary hypertension, maternal mortality is about 50% and the majority die (75%)
postpartum.
Simpson’s criteria for cesarean delivery for cardiac disease in pregnancy:
Dilated aortic root >4 cm or aortic aneurysm
Acute severe congestive heart failure
Recent myocardial infarctio
Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
Warfarin administration within 2 weeks of delivery
Need for emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery
Coarctation of the aorta and aortic dissection are other indications for cesarean delivery.
In general, vaginal delivery is preferred, and labor induction is usually safe. Cesarean delivery is limited to obstetric indications, and considerations are given for the specific cardiac lesions only. Epidural anesthesia is given during LSCS in heart disease. The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given.
Solution to Question 7:
Perimortem cesarean delivery should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation in 5 minutes, according to the AHA 2020 Guidelines.
The goal of perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) should be primarily aimed at saving the life of the mother. PMCS improves maternal survival by decreasing compression of the IVC by the gravid uterus. This improves venous return and diaphragmatic displacement, which in turn improves respiratory dynamics.

Solution to Question 8:
Lateral recumbent position is advised during the first stage of labor in this patient. Management of labor in patients with heart disease:
First stage:
Lateral recumbent or propped up positio
Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
Analgesia by epidural
Fluids should not be infused more than 75 ml/h
Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labour and 48 h after delivery
Central venous pressure monitoring Second stage:
No maternal pushing
Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anaesthsia
The benefit of avoiding haemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, haemorrhage and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery.
Third stage:
Oxytocin by infusio
IV frusemide if needed

Solution to Question 10:
The best technique for managing the second stage of labor in a patient with heart disease is using ventouse.
For most cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred and cesarean section is reserved for obstetric indications since the cesarean section is associated with more blood loss and higher thromboembolic and infection risk. If vaginal delivery is selected as the mode of choice, it will be conducted with the laboring woman in an upright position, or in the left decubitus position. This minimizes aortocaval compression.
Active pushing during the second stage may also be limited, depending on the degree of cardiac compromise. In moderate to severe cardiac disease, it may be prudent to completely avoid an active second stage. Regional anesthesia can be used to allow the fetal head to descend to the perineum without active pushing. Delivery can be further facilitated by forceps or vacuum extraction.
The benefit of avoiding hemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, hemorrhage, and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery.
Some journals report that ventouse is preferable to forceps, as it can be applied without putting the patient in lithotomy position (raising the legs increases the cardiac load) however it is controversial.
Solution to Question 11:
In pregnant ladies with intracardiac shunts, general anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia.
The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given.
Note: Aortic stenosis will also be affected by the hypotension caused by epidural/spinal analgesia. However, in aortic stenosis, slow epidural anesthesia is adequate and doesn't compromise ventricular preload. Only a few severe cases of aortic stenosis warrant GA. Hence, in the context of this MCQ, 'intracardiac shunts' would be the most appropriate answer.
Solution to Question 12:
Warfarin is not contraindicated during lactation.
Warfarin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH) do not accumulate in breast milk. They do not induce an anticoagulant effect in the infant.
The choice of anticoagulants is the main problem in pregnancy due to the following reasons:
Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
Heparin: It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin.
LMWH: Inadequate and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.
If the patient delivers when the anticoagulant is still effective and bleeds excessively, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously.

Solution to Question 13:
The most common cause of death in HOCM in pregnant women is ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Most affected women are asymptomatic, but some patients may develop:
Dyspnea
Anginal or atypical chest pai
Syncope
Arrhythmias.
Strenuous exercise is prohibited during pregnancy. Abrupt positional changes are avoided to prevent reflex vasodilation and decrease of preload. Diuretics and vasodilators are generally not used as they decrease preload. If angina develops, beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers are used.
The mode of delivery depends upon obstetric indications and if cesarean section is done, general anesthesia is considered the safest.
Solution to Question 14:
Left ventricular systolic dysfunction is a feature of peripartum cardiomyopathy (also known as postpartum cardiomyopathy) and not diastolic dysfunction.
Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. It develops during the last month of pregnancy or within the first 5 months following delivery.
The predisposing factors include Cardiac gene mutations involving several genes like TTNC1, TTN, and STAT3, Twin pregnancy/ multifetal gestation, Smoking, and Preeclampsia. Other proposed causes include viral myocarditis, abnormal immune response to pregnancy, malnutrition, inflammation, etc.
PPCM is associated with increased secretion of prolactin by the pituitary and antiangiogenic molecule sFlt-1 (soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase) by the placenta at term gestation.
Pearson’s diagnostic criteria for PPCM:
Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery
Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure
Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy, and
Left ventricular systolic dysfunction demonstrated by echocardiographic criteria, such as ejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30% along with a dilated left ventricle.
Management involves treating the features of heart failure. Bromocriptine has been found useful in this condition. Many women recover within 6 months of delivery, while some continue to have residual effects.
Solution to Question 15:
Prolactin has been proposed to be responsible for peripartum cardiomyopathy.
Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting 16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism and contractility of cardiomyocytes.
The etiology of peripartum cardiomyopathy remains unknown. Many potential causes have been proposed but are not proven.
Viral myocarditis
Abnormal immune response to pregnancy
Abnormal response to the increased hemodynamic burden of pregnancy
Malnutritio
Inflammatio
Apoptosis
Prolacti
Solution to Question 16:
The given scenario is suggestive of peripartum cardiomyopathy and bromocriptine is effective for its treatment.
Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting 16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism and contractility of cardiomyocytes. Based on this proposed mechanism, bromocriptine therapy has been suggested because it inhibits prolactin secretion.
Solution to Question 17:
The best time of surgery for mitral stenosis in pregnancy is between 14–18 weeks.
Balloon valvuloplasty is the procedure of choice for mitral stenosis in pregnancy. Any cardiac surgery in pregnancy should usually be postponed until after delivery, but if required, it can be performed safely in the 2nd trimester.
Solution to Question 18:
Hypertension is a common maternal complication of congenital cardiac disease in pregnancy. The common maternal complications in patients with congenital cardiac disease include:
Congestive cardiac failure

Arrhythmia

The most common arrhythmia seen in reproductive-aged women is paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.
Solution to Question 20:
Women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease and prosthetic valves.
The American heart association recommends prophylaxis for dental procedures with:
Prosthetic valves
Unrepaired cyanotic heart defects
Valvulopathy after heart transplantatio
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists do not recommend endocarditis prophylaxis for either vaginal or cesarean delivery in the absence of pelvic infection.
Solution to Question 21:
Eisenmenger syndrome is the heart disease with the worst prognosis, having a maternal mortality rate of 50%.
The most common cause of death in Eisenmenger’s syndrome is right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock. If antenatal diagnosis of Eisenmenger syndrome is made in the first trimester, termination of pregnancy is advised. Eisenmenger syndrome has the highest risk of maternal mortality. However, since mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac condition in pregnancy, it is the most common cause of maternal mortality overall.
Mitral regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse and pulmonary stenosis are well tolerated during pregnancy. Severe aortic stenosis can be life-threatening. However, women with mild to moderate aortic valve stenosis may have a relatively low-risk pregnancy.
