Contraindications of methyl ergometrine are:
Twin pregnancy - Second baby gets compromised by tetanic contractions of uterus if given after delivery of first baby
Organic cardiac disease - Causes overloading of right heart by squeezing blood from uterine circulation.
Severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia
Rh negative mother - Increases chance of fetomaternal transfusion.

Solution to Question 1:
The genetic locus for the Rh antigen complex is on the short arm of chromosome 1.
RhCcEe and RhD are the two distinct genes located within the Rh locus. The presence of D antigen on one or both chromosomes 1, determines heterozygosity or homozygosity respectively.
Solution to Question 2:
The Lewis antigens do not cause alloimmunization or hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn.
Alloimmunization/isoimmunisation is defined as an immune response to foreign antigens after exposure to genetically different cells or tissues.
The Kell blood group system is complex and contains many antigens that are highly immunogenic. These antigens are the third most potent, after those of the ABO and Rh blood groups, at triggering an immune reaction. Anti-Kell causes severe fetal anemia by suppressing fetal RBC synthesis.
MNS and Kidd blood types cause alloimmunization. Hemolytic disease of newborn is mild with Kidd whereas MNS causes potentially severe anemia.
Solution to Question 3:
In a non-immunized Rh-negative primigravida, Anti D is given at 28 weeks of gestation. It is also given within 72 hours of delivery.
Routine postpartum administration of anti-D immune globulin to at-risk pregnancies within 72 hours of delivery decreases the alloimmunization rate by 90 percent.
Additionally, the provision of Anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks of gestation reduces the third-trimester alloimmunization rate from approximately 2 percent to 0.1 percent.
Solution to Question 4:
Postpartum hemorrhage is not an indication of Anti-D prophylaxis.
Anti-D prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative patients in the following circumstances:
Pregnancy loss due to:
Ectopic pregnancy
Spontaneous abortion/hydatiform mole
Elective abortion
Fetal death (any trimester)
Procedures:
Amniocentesis
Chorionic villus sampling
Fetal blood sampling
External cephalic version
Delivery
Trauma
Placental abruption
Unexplained vaginal bleeding during pregnancy
Solution to Question 5:
The dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given in the first trimester is 50 g.
All Rh-negative unsensitized women should receive 50 g of Rh-immune globulin IM in the first trimester in the following conditions:
Within 72 hours of induced or spontaneous abortion
Ectopic/molar pregnancy
Chorionic villus sampling
Women with a pregnancy beyond 12 weeks should receive a full dose of 300 g. Generally, a 300
g dose will protect a woman from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of fetal whole blood. The dose in the 3rd trimester and post-delivery is 300 g or 1500 international units (IU).
Solution to Question 6:
The reagent used for the Kleihauer-Betke test is citric acid.
Kleihauer-Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test used to detect fetomaternal hemorrhage i.e., the approximate volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation. It is also known as the acid elution test.
The principle behind it is that fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A.
After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as “ghosts.” Fetal cells are counted and expressed as a percentage of adult cells.
Flow cytometry is the best test for the quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage. It is more sensitive and accurate as compared to the Kleihauer-Betke test.
Flow cytometry can analyze a larger number of cells and is not influenced by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin and fetal levels of maternal hemoglobin. It utilizes monoclonal antibodies to HbF or to the D antigen followed by quantification by fluorescence.

Solution to Question 9:
MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negative sensitized mothers.
The middle cerebral artery is used as other fetal vessels require a larger insonating angle and confers significant measurement error.
MCA PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity of fetal blood, which permits the reliable, noninvasive detection of fetal anemia in cases of blood-group alloimmunization.
If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replaced amniocentesis as the preferred test for the detection of anemia.
Solution to Question 10:
A severely affected fetus is represented by zone 3.
Liley developed a chart of changing amniotic fluid bilirubin levels (delta OD450) and weeks
of gestation. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm (OD450).
However, middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PCV) is non-invasive and more accurate than optical density at 450 nm, hence Liley’s chart is no longer used in practice.
Liley’s chart has three zones as shown below, delineating the severity of rhesus disease.
Liley’s zone I (low zone) - mild disease.
Liley’s zone II (mid zone) - fetal anemia.
Liley’s zone III (high zone) - severely affected fetus and fetal death is imminent.

Solution to Question 11:
Threshold (critical value) of middle cerebral artery (MCA) peak systolic velocity is 1.5 multiples of the median (MoM).
If the MCA peak systolic velocity exceeds 1.5 MoM, further evaluation by fetal blood sampling is necessary to assess the need for fetal transfusion.
The anemic fetus shunts blood preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. The velocity increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity.
In many centers, serial measurement of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery has replaced amniocentesis for the detection of fetal anemia. This method provided 100 percent sensitivity.
Solution to Question 12:
Intrauterine transfusion is done if fetal haematocrit is <30%.
The blood for transfusion is usually O negative and cross-matched with the mother's blood. It is highly packed to achieve a hematocrit of 75 -80%.
Intrauterine transfusions may be done intraperitoneally where blood is absorbed through diaphragmatic lymphatics. It may also be done intravascularly through the umbilical vein. The segments of the umbilical vein used are the intrahepatic portion or at its insertion into the placenta.
Complications of intrauterine transfusion include:
Fetal demise
Chorioamnionitis
Placental abruption
Pre-term labor
Bradycardia/tachyarrhythmia
Umbilical cord hematoma
Solution to Question 13:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of maternal mirror syndrome/Ballantyne syndrome. It may be considered a form of severe pre-eclampsia.
Maternal mirror syndrome is the association between fetal hydrops and the development of maternal edema. The syndrome is named as such because the mother mirrors the fetus. It is characterized by triple edema i.e., the fetus, mother, and placenta become edematous.
The pathogenesis of mirror syndrome, although not well established, mimics trophoblastic damage and maternal vascular endothelial dysfunction, as is also seen in pre-eclampsia. Hence, these two conditions may have a similar clinical presentation, with common features such as:
Edema
Hypertension
Proteinuria
Liver enzyme elevation
Headache and visual disturbances.
However, in contrast to preeclampsia, the following features are noted in maternal mirror syndrome:
Low maternal hematocrit i.e., hemodilution rather than hemoconcentration
Polyhydramnios rather than oligohydramnios
The fetus always shows signs of hydrops.
The etiology of fetal hydrops is not related to the development of mirror syndrome. Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, congenital infections, fetal cystic hygroma, Ebstein anomaly, sacrococcygeal teratoma, vein of Galen aneurysms, etc.
In most cases with mirror syndrome, prompt delivery is indicated, because women with severe features of preeclampsia can deteriorate rapidly. In few cases, identification and treatment of the cause of fetal hydrops resulted in the resolution of symptoms for both the mother and baby for the remainder of the pregnancy.
Solution to Question 14:
The earliest sign of hydrops fetalis on a USG is scalp edema. Subcutaneous scalp edema is also known as the Halo sign.
Other USG signs include:
Ascites
Pleural effusion
Pericardial effusion
Typical position termed as Buddha's position

Solution to Question 15:
The pale, oedematous fetus in the image is suggestive of fetal hydrops. Fetal hydrops is associated with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.
It often occurs as an effect of iso-immunization in an Rh-negative pregnancy. Other complications that may occur are fetal anemia and hyperbilirubinemia.
Fetal anemia occurs in the initial stage of iso-immunization. It is associated with polyhydramnios and increased placental thickening (hyper-placentosis). An increase in the right atrium size of the fetus is seen.
Fetal hydrops is usually accompanied by severe anemia. It results in stillbirth or fetal demise soon after birth. It is also associated with:
Congestive cardiac failure
Ascites
Pleural effusion
Pericardial effusion
Hepatosplenomegaly.

Solution to Question 1:
Obstetric cholestasis is a condition in which cholestasis occurs in pregnancy. Serum bilirubin increases very late in the disease and total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 5 mg/dL.
Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment.
It is also referred to as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum. There is a significant genetic influence. It may be more common in multifetal pregnancies.
Patients present with pruritus that develops usually during the third trimester, typically involving the palms and soles. It is worse at night. Icterus may also be present.

Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of cholestasis in pregnancy. Serum bile acid is the earliest and most consistent parameter to increase in obstetric cholestasis.
Serum cholic acid is preferred compared to serum chenodeoxycholic acid.
Although serum bile acid increases after meals it is still considered an important investigation among women with obstetric cholestasis. This is because serum bile acid levels remain significantly elevated in women with obstetric cholestasis in comparison to pregnant women without it.
Solution to Question 3:
The given scenario is suggestive of obstetric cholestasis. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choice in obstetric cholestasis.
It relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum enzyme levels (like SGOT, ALP). It may also reduce certain neonatal complications such as preterm birth, fetal distress, and respiratory distress syndrome.
Antihistamines and topical emollients may provide some relief.
Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin K deficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial hemorrhage and stillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred.

Proteinuria
Edema
Thrombocytopenia
Moderate to severe liver dysfunction - manifested by:
Hypofibrinogenemia
Hypoalbuminemia
Hypocholesterolemia
Prolonged clotting time.
Solution to Question 5:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is more commonly associated with male fetuses and not female fetuses.
AFLP is a rare, potentially fatal complication also known as acute fatty metamorphosis or acute yellow atrophy. It is more common in the third trimester. It is due to a defect in the
long-chain-3-hydroxy acyl-CoA-dehydrogenase (LCHAD) pathway. It is also associated with:
First pregnancy - uncommon in subsequent pregnancies
Maternal obesity
Multiple pregnancies Investigations:
Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised.
Hemolysis with coagulopathy:
Decreased platelets and fibrinogen
Elevated d-dimers and prothrombin time
Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.
The definitive management of AFLP is rapid delivery of the fetus and supportive care. Hepatic dysfunction usually normalizes within a week of delivery.
Solution to Question 6:
Hypertension is not a risk factor for urinary infections in pregnancy. Risk factors for urinary infections in pregnancy include:
Urinary retention
Vesicoureteric reflux of pregnancy
Diabetes in pregnancy
Sickle cell anemia
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of asymptomatic bacteriuria. Antibiotic therapy should be given regardless of the symptoms.
Asymptomatic bacteriuria refers to persistent, actively multiplying bacteria within the urinary tract in asymptomatic women.
Organisms that cause urinary infections are those from the normal perineal flora. The most common causative agent is E.coli. Others include Klebsiella, and Proteus.
Incidence is similar to that in non-pregnant women. Prevalence depends on parity (more in higher parity), race, socioeconomic status (more in low SES).
It is more common in patients with sickle cell anemia/trait, diabetes. There is a high risk of developing chronic renal lesions in later life.
It is also associated with:
Hypertension
Anemia
Premature labor
Intrauterine growth retardation
Urinary tract abnormalities in recurrent cases. Diagnostic criteria:
A positive bacterial count of the same species - over 1,00,000/mL
Organisms in midstream clean-catch specimen of urine on two occasions
No symptoms of urinary infection Treatment:
Single-dose therapy - Amoxicillin 3g, Nitrofurantoin 200mg
Regular 10-14 days therapy - Amoxicillin, Nitrofurantoin, Cephalexin, or Amoxiclav
Recurrent cases need to be treated until delivery with prophylactic doses.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystitis. Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone antibiotic, is contraindicated in pregnancy as it causes cartilage and bone defects in the fetus.
Antibiotics are used for treating cystitis in pregnancy. Antibiotics safe in pregnancy include:
Penicillin group
Cephalosporins
Erythromycin
Metronidazole (except in the 1st trimester) Antibiotics unsafe in pregnancy include:
Tetracycline
Aminoglycoside
Chloramphenico
Metronidazole(in the first trimester)
Fluoroquinolones
Solution to Question 9:
Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy most often complicates 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
Acute pyelonephritis occurs more commonly in those with preexisting renal disease. It is caused by E. coli >> Streptococcus sp., S.aureus > Enterobacter, Klebsiella sp.
Clinical features include:
Fever with chills
Loin pain
Vomiting
Right-sided renal angle tenderness
Patients may develop acute respiratory distress syndrome due to endotoxin-mediated alveolar injury. Hemolysis can also occur due to endotoxins, leading to anemia.
Treatment includes intravenous fluids with antibiotics.
Solution to Question 10:
Triad of Gregg is seen in a neonate infected congenitally with rubella virus. The features include:
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
Cataract
Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL)
Other infections which cause congenital malformations are:
Organis m
Effect
Toxopla sma
Hydro/microcephaly, convuls ions, chorioretinitis, cerebral calcification
Varicell a
Skin scarring, hypoplastic li mbs, eye defects, microcepha ly
Parvovir us
Non-immune hydrops
Syphilis
Hutchinson's triad:Interstitia l keratitisHutchinson's teeth Eighth nerve deafness
Solution to Question 11:
Toxoplasmosis causes maximal complications in 1st trimester and is maximally transmitted in the 3rd trimester.
This is because the risk of transmission increases and the risk of damage decreases as pregnancy progresses further.
Clinical features of affected neonates include:
Hydrocephalus or microcephaly
Chorioretinitis
Intracranial calcifications
Convulsions
Low birthweight
Hepatosplenomegaly
Jaundice
Anemia
Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario points to a diagnosis of maternal toxoplasmosis. It is treated using spiramycin.
Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide is used when fetal infections are confirmed. It should be avoided in the first trimester.
Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. Cats are definitive hosts. It can be transmitted to humans either by ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat or by ingestion of oocysts via exposure to cat litter or soil.
Acute infection is diagnosed either by the presence of IgG and IgM antibodies or by a four-fold increase in paired specimens 4 weeks apart.
Solution to Question 13:
Painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy are suggestive of herpes virus infection. The cytological image showing multinucleate giant cells, Tzanck cells confirms the diagnosis of HSV. The best step in the management of delivery in this patient is a cesarean section.
Herpes infection in the newborn may occur during birth, particularly if the mother has genital lesions due to HSV-2. In such cases, a cesarean section may prevent neonatal infection.

Solution to Question 14:
The maximum risk of HSV transmission from mother to child is during labor. This is due to the shedding of the virus from an active infection in the genital tract during delivery.
HSV is a sexually transmitted infection. There is a higher risk of transmission during primary infections than with recurrences. Reactivations are less severe.
Cesarean delivery reduces the risk of vertical transmission during labor and is indicated in:
Cases of active genital lesions - both primary and recurrent
Prodromal symptoms - like vulval itching or burning
Suspicious lesions should be sent for PCR testing or culture. Antiviral treatment with acyclovir should be given if found positive.
Women without active genital lesions, without symptoms, or those with active lesions in non-genital areas can undergo normal labor and delivery.
Management of HSV infection during pregnancy:
Primary or recurrent infections during pregnancy - Oral acyclovir or valacyclovir
Severe or disseminated infection - IV acyclovir followed by oral acyclovir
Pain relief - Oral analgesics or topical anesthetics
Urinary retention - catheterization.
Solution to Question 15:
The risk of developing fetal varicella syndrome (congenital varicella syndrome) is highest when the mother develops varicella infection between 13 to 20 weeks.
Congenital varicella syndrome occurs in 2% of infants with maternal varicella between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation and in 0.4% of infants before 13 weeks of gestation. It is rare after 20 weeks.
Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like pattern (zig-zag scarring), and limb hypoplasia (shown below). They can also present with neurological abnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy, mental retardation), ophthalmic features (chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cataract), and renal and autonomic system abnormalities (hydronephrosis, neurogenic bladder). Low birth weight is also common.
Infants born to mothers with varicella in the period from 5 days prior to delivery up to 2 days after delivery are at high risk for severe neonatal varicella. They acquire the infection transplacentally.
Since the mother has not developed a strong antibody response, the infant lacks the protective effect of maternal anti-varicella-zoster virus (VZV) antibodies. Therefore varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) should be administered as soon as possible after birth to newborns whose mothers have varicella 5 days before and up to 2 days after the delivery.
Since perinatally acquired varicella can be potentially life-threatening, the infant should typically be treated with intravenous acyclovir (10 mg/kg every 8 hours) when lesions appear.
For pregnant women with uncomplicated primary varicella or herpes zoster that does not require hospitalization, the recommended treatment is oral acyclovir (800 mg five times daily for seven days).

Solution to Question 16:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. It is seen in babies born to mothers who had chickenpox infections during their pregnancy.
Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:
Chorioretinitis
Limb hypoplasia
Cicatricial skin lesions
Microphthalmia
Cerebral cortical atrophy
Growth restriction
Hydronephrosis
The image below shows limb hypoplasia in fetal varicella syndrome:

Solution to Question 17:
A pregnant woman with syphilis can transmit T. pallidum to the fetus at 10–15 weeks of gestation. Features of congenital syphilis include:
Hutchinson's triad - It is seen in late congenital syphilis.
Hutchinson’s teeth - small widely spaced, peg-shaped, notched upper incisors
Interstitial keratitis
Sensorineural hearing loss
Mulberry molars
Rhagades - deep fissuring of mucocutaneous junctions in the nares, lips, and anus
Frontal bossing
Saber shins - anterior tibial bowing
Clutton’s joints - painless, symmetric hydrarthrosis of the knees and elbows The image below shows Hutchinson incisors.

Note: The risk of fetal infection during untreated early maternal syphilis is ~75–95%, decreasing to ~35% for maternal syphilis of >2 years duration.
Solution to Question 18:
Enlarged and pale placenta is due to infection by syphilis. Other clinical manifestations and complications include:
Spontaneous abortion
Stillbirth
Non-immune hydrops
Intrauterine growth restriction
Perinatal death.
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of early syphilis in a pregnant woman. 2.4 million units of benzathine penicillin should be given intramuscularly as a single injection.
Treatment of syphilis includes:
Early syphilis - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection
Late syphilis (>1 year duration) - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses
Treatment of neurosyphilis:
Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 3–4 million units intravenously every 4 hours for 10–14 days
Procaine penicillin, 2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally four times daily, both for 10–14 days.
Solution to Question 20:
The above scenario points to a diagnosis of SLE. Preterm labor is a complication in pregnant women with SLE, not post-term delivery.
Complications in a pregnant patient with SLE include:
Thrombophilia
Preterm labor
Hypertension, eclampsia, and preeclampsia
Anemia
Thrombocytopenia
Stroke
Renal failure
Features of neonatal lupus include:
Cardiac abnormalities - Complete heart blocks
Cutaneous lupus
Hepatobiliary diseases - liver failure, transient conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, transient transaminase elevations
Hematologic abnormalities - thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, or anemia
Solution to Question 21:
Cesarean delivery is the preferred mode of delivery in a woman with HIV viral load above 1000 copies/ml at 34-36 weeks of gestation.
Cesarean delivery is usually scheduled at 38 weeks of gestation, or two weeks before the due date.
Pregnant women with HIV on ART throughout pregnancy, with a viral load <1000 copies/mL evaluated within 4-6 weeks of delivery, may choose to have a vaginal delivery.
Solution to Question 22:
ART should be initiated immediately and continued lifelong in all pregnant and breastfeeding women with HIV. This is regardless of their WHO clinical stage and CD4 cell count.
*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.
Solution to Question 23:
In India, according to the NACO guidelines, nevirapine is given in the syrup form for 6 weeks to an infant of a mother who is on long-term ART.
In infants born to mothers with HIV who are not on ART, syrup nevirapine should be continued for 12 weeks.
According to the NIH guidelines, zidovudine should be given to the neonate for 4 weeks.
Solution to Question 24:
The highest incidence of stroke in pregnancy is 5 days to 2 weeks postpartum. This is followed by the intrapartum period.
There is an increased risk of cerebrovascular thrombosis post-delivery due to a sudden reduction in the blood volume, a fall in the level of circulating antithrombotic factors, and venous stasis.
Risk factors of stroke in pregnancy include:
Hypertensive disorders
Gestational diabetes
Antepartum hemorrhage
Cesarean delivery.
Solution to Question 25:
Untreated epilepsy has no association with fetal malformations. Anti-epileptic medications such as valproate, phenytoin, etc., are responsible for fetal malformations.
Seizure frequency is unchanged in 50%, increased in 30%, and decreased in 20% women. Seizure risk increases during labor as pain and hyperventilation decrease the seizure threshold.
The ideal contraceptive in a breastfeeding mother with a seizure disorder is depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA), as progestins increase the seizure threshold.
Disorders of Menstruation

question_text:
c
Solution to Question 1:
Primary amenorrhoea is seen in Turner syndrome
Amenorrhoea is a symptom and not a disease entity. It refers to the absence of menstruation that can be physiological or pathological.
Primary amenorrhea is defined as an absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years. At age 13 years, if no menses have occurred and there is a complete absence of secondary sexual characteristics such as breast development, evaluation for primary amenorrhea should
begin. Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome), androgen insensitivity syndrome, and Turner syndrome present with primary amenorrhea. In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure, resulting in hypogonadism and amenorrhea.
Secondary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menses for 3 or more months or fewer than 9 cycles per year after the establishment of regular menstrual cycles. Polycystic ovarian syndrome and hypothyroidism are associated with secondary amenorrhea. Pregnancy is the most common physiological cause of secondary amenorrhea.
Solution to Question 2:
The absence of withdrawal bleeding after the estrogen-progesterone challenge test points towards a local endometrial lesion.
Estrogen–progesterone challenge test is indicated as an investigation in case of secondary amenorrhea. It depends on estrogen-primed endometrium being present in the uterus.
Procedure:
Ethinyl estradiol 0.02 mg or conjugated equine estrogen 1.25 mg is to be taken daily for 25 days.
Medroxyprogesterone acetate 10 mg daily is added from day 15–25.
Alternately, one course of oral contraceptive pill is given and to observe whether withdrawa bleeding occurs or not.
Results:
If there is no bleeding, a local endometrial lesion is present such as uterine synechiae. This is to be confirmed by HSG or hysteroscopy.
If withdrawal bleeding occurs, the endometrium is responsive but the endogenous estrogen production is inadequate. Hence, the defect lies in the ovary, hypothalamus, or pituitary.
Solution to Question 3:
The risk of developing Asherman syndrome is the highest if D&C is done for postpartum hemorrhage.
This is because the postpartum uterus is larger and bulkier. Hence, a greater area of the uterine wall is curetted. This increases the risk of developing Asherman syndrome.
Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium. The treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.
Solution to Question 4:
Oligomenorrhoea can progress to develop into amenorrhoea.
Oligomenorrhoea means infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occurring at intervals of more than 38 days.
Solution to Question 5:
The given case scenario is suggestive of polymenorrhoea, also known as epimenorrhea. It refers to frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less.
The definitions of various menstrual cycle irregularities are:
Amenorrhoea refers to the absence of menstruation.
Intermenstrual bleeding refers to occasional episodes of bleeding (usually not excessive) that occur between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed cycles, but having scanty episodes of bleeding.
Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed menstrual cycles with excessive bleeding (>80 mL in amount) and/or increased duration of flow (>8 days).
Metrorrhagia refers to normal cyclical bleeding with superimposed irregularly timed episodes of bleeding.
Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals.
Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed cycles with intervals of more than 38 days. Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
Solution to Question 6:
Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding.
Menorrhagia denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>8 days). Nowadays, menorrhagia has been replaced by the term heavy menstrual bleeding. This is defined as greater than 80 mL per cycle, which will result in anemia if recurrent
Investigations done in case of menorrhagia:
Complete blood count (CBC) - to rule out anemia and thrombocytopenia.
Coagulation studies are ordered only in case of clinical suspicion and correlation with CBC
Sonohysterography/Hysteroscopy - to diagnose endometrial polyps and fibroids
Endometrial biopsy - in case of suspected endometrial hyperplasia
Transvaginal ultrasound - supplements biopsy
Solution to Question 7:
Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive to non-hormonal therapy.
Menorrhagia/heavy menstrual bleeding is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding, >80mL of blood loss, or >8 days of bleeding per menstrual period. It can be acute (<6 months) or chronic (>6 months).
It is managed as follows:
Medical - first line of treatment.
NSAIDs
Tranexamic acid
OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails
Mirena IUCD
GnRH agonists
Blood transfusion, if required
Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis:
Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc (option B)
Uterine artery embolization (option A)
Uterine tamponade
Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail (option D)
Solution to Question 8:
Menometrorrhagia refers to menstrual bleeding at frequent intervals.
Menometrorrhagia means excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals. It can be caused by cervical cancer and granulosa cell tumors.
Solution to Question 9:
In the given clinical scenario, the pattern of bleeding is called hypomenorrhea. Hypomenorrhea along with a prior history of dilatation and curettage are suggestive of partial Asherman's syndrome.
Hypomenorrhoea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding. It can be seen in:
Partial Asherman's syndrome - uterine synechiae, causing scarring
Oral contraceptive use
Perimenopausal age group
Solution to Question 10:
The given case scenario is suggestive of intermenstrual bleeding, also known as metrorrhagia. Usually, this is scanty, and not excessive.
Intermenstrual bleeding or metrorrhagia refers to irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding. It can be caused by:
Ovulation (physiological)
Polyps
Cervical cancer
Lower genital tract infections etc.
Solution to Question 11:
Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years.
McCune Albright syndrome is associated with cafe-au-lait spots, precocious puberty (and precocious menstruation), and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia leading to recurrent fractures. The image given below shows cafe-au-lait spots.

Solution to Question 12:
The given case scenario is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica.
Metropathia hemorrhagica is a form of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding. It is characterized by continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhea. It is usually seen in the age group of 40-45 years. A history of menorrhagia may be present.
On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:
Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm
Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as swiss cheese pattern
Absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of corkscrew glands
Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity
Corpus luteum is absent
One or both ovaries may contain a cyst
Option A: Senile endometritis occurs after menopause when the endometrium is thin and atrophic. It may be associated with accumulation of pus in the uterine cavity.
Option B: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow is present.
Option D: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.
Solution to Question 13:
The 'I' in the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) stands for iatrogenic causes.
AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:
Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.
Chronic AUB - it lasts for 3-6 months minimum. PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:
Polyp (AUB-P):
Endometrial polyps
Endocervical polyps
Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
Submucosal (SM)
Other (O)
Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M)
Endometrial hyperplasia
Endometrial carcinoma
Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
von Willebrand's disease
Hemophilias
Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
PCOD
Hypothyroidism
Hyperprolactinemia.
Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis
Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
Intrauterine contraceptive devices
Anticoagulants
Tricyclic antidepressants
Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
Arteriovenous malformations
Myometrial hypertrophy
Solution to Question 14:
The first investigation to be done in a case of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in the reproductive age group is urine -hCG estimation. This is done to rule out pregnancy.
In the reproductive age group, anovulatory uterine bleeding is encountered less often. Therefore, pregnancy must be excluded. Pregnancy complications such as miscarriage, ectopic pregnancies, and molar pregnancies may present with AUB, hence these need to be ruled out by urine
-hCG levels. This is done for all women in the reproductive age group.
Other investigations to be done for AUB are:
Pap smear - to rule out cervical cancer and preinvasive lesions (CIN).
Transabdominal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs and lesions such as endometria hyperplasia, polyps, fibroids, etc.
Transvaginal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs. It is done after evaluating -hCG. This is more comfortable for a patient compared to a transabdominal ultrasound as it doesn't require a full bladder.
Solution to Question 15:
Fertility is not preserved with ablative procedures, because the endometrium and superficial myometrium are destroyed.
In ablative procedures, the uterus is preserved, and hysterectomy is avoided. The endometrium along with 2-3mm of superficial myometrium is destroyed.
Various methods of endometrial ablation include:
Hysteroscopic endometrial ablation
Transcervical endometrial resection (TCRE) - now replaced by bipolar electrode called Versapoint
Radiofrequency induced thermal ablation (RITEA)
Microwave ablation
NovaSure - impedance-controlled endometrial ablation
Bilateral uterine artery embolization
Uterine tamponade
Solution to Question 16:
Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) as it increases the risk of ascending genital infection.
D&C is a minor gynecological procedure of dilating the cervix and curetting the endometrial tissue from the uterine cavity. Diagnostic indications of D&C include AUB, secondary
amenorrhea to detect tubercular endometritis, postmenopausal bleeding to rule out endometrial cancer or hyperplasia, and infertility due to genital TB.
Therapeutic indications of D&C include missed abortion, incomplete abortion, retained products of conception, and endometrial polypectomy.
Absolute contraindication of D&C includes Suspected/ desired pregnancy and lower genital tract infection. However, D&C is performed in some cases with genital infections like septic abortion (where retained pieces of placenta act as a nidus and need to be removed) and pyometra (as there is cervical obstruction with superinfection of menstrual blood and cellular debris, D&C is appropriate to remove the obstruction as well as the source of infection)
Complications of D&C include ascending infection, cervical tear with bleeding, incompetent os, uterine perforation, and ashermann syndrome.

Solution to Question 17:
The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine perforation. In a non-pregnant uterus, uterine perforation is most likely to occur due to dilatation and curettage.
In pregnancy and uterine malignancies, the uterus is soft. Hence, uterine perforation is common during surgeries.
The etiology of uterine perforation is as follows:
Insertion of intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCD)- due to the lack of provider experience.
Spontaneous migration of IUCD within the myometrium
Dilatation and curettage (D&C)
Hysteroscopy - diagnostic (e.g, hysteroscopic biopsy) or therapeutic (adhesiolysis)
Laparoscopy
It can present with fever, acute abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and bleeding pv. Imaging reveals air within the uterine wall or pneumoperitoneum.
The management is as follows:
Conservative management - Fundal injuries are managed conservatively, as the myometrium contracts around the defect.
Surgical management:
Small defects can be repaired laparoscopically or hysteroscopically.
Emergency laparotomy - as abdominal viscera may prolapse through the defect.
Hysterectomy - if the defect is large, and the patient has completed her family, hysterectomy is done as last resort.
Solution to Question 18:
The given case scenario is suggestive of spasmodic dysmenorrhea. It presents with cramping pain at the onset of menses which is more pronounced in the first two days of menstruation.
Dysmenorrhoea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation. It can be classified as follows:
Etiological classification:
Primary dysmenorrhoea - no identifiable pelvic pathology. Commonly occurs in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles.
Secondary (acquired) dysmenorrhoea - is associated with pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis.
Unilateral dysmenorrhoea can occur in a rudimentary horn of a bicornuate uterus, IUCD users, and cervical stenosis.
Clinical classification:
Spasmodic dysmenorrhoea:
Most prevalent
Cramping pain at the onset of menses, more pronounced on the first 2 days.
Occurs due to myometrial contractions due to increased PGF2
Common in adolescents and young women
Congestive dysmenorrhoea:
Pelvic pain and pelvic discomfort occurs, a few days before menses begin
Occurs due to pelvic venous congestion
Seen in pelvic endometriosis, PID, fibroids, and IUCD users
Membranous dysmenorrhoea:
Least prevalent
The endometrium is shed as a cast at the time of menstruation
The passage of the cast is associated with painful uterine cramps
Solution to Question 19:
Spasmodic pain is attributed to myometrial contractions occuring due to increased PGF2 . This is secreted under the effect of progesterone.
Progesterone is secreted after ovulation by the corpus luteum. Hence, in anovulatory cycles, menstruation is not accompanied by spasmodic pain.
Solution to Question 20:
The given case scenario is suggestive of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine, sertraline, and paroxetine are the treatment of choice for PMDD.
DSM-5 defines premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) as the presence of at least five of the associated symptoms most of the time during the premenstrual week. Symptoms improve within a few days after menses and are minimal in the postmenstrual period. These symptoms include:
Marked emotional lability
Marked irritability or anger
Marked depressive mood, self-deprecating thoughts
Marked anxiety
Decreased interest in activities
Difficulty in concentration
Lethargy
Appetite changes
Bloating
Breast tenderness
Weight gain
Treatment of PMDD is as follows:
Lifestyle changes such as - stress reduction, adequate sleep, and exercise, reduction in caffeine intake, smoking cessation
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) - fluoxetine, paroxetine, sertraline
Evening primrose oil - to treat breast tenderness
Ovulation suppression - danazol, leuprolide, drospirenone
Other less proven methods - cognitive behavioral therapy, calcium supplements, etc.
Note: Premenstrual syndrome has no scientific definition. The constellation of symptoms is now defined under PMDD.

Solution to Question 1:
Vesicovaginal fistulas are mostly acquired.
In developing countries, the most common cause is obstetric trauma. In developed countries, iatrogenic injury during pelvic surgery is responsible for 90% of the vesicovaginal fistulas.
Congenital genitourinary fistulas and fistulas resulting from infectious conditions are rare.
Solution to Question 2:
Uterourethral type of fistula has not been reported.
A genitourinary fistula is defined as an abnormal communication between the urinary system
(ureter, bladder, urethra) and the genital systems (vagina, cervix, uterus).
Most genitourinary fistulas are acquired. In developing countries, the most common cause
is obstetric trauma. In developed countries, iatrogenic injury during pelvic surgery is responsible
for 90% of the vesicovaginal fistulas.
Congenital genitourinary fistulas are rare. If present, they are commonly associated with other renal or urogenital abnormalities.
Solution to Question 3:
Hysteroscopy is not an etiology for genitourinary fistulae. It can occur following hysterectomy. Most genitourinary fistulas are acquired. Its causes are enumerated below:
Prolonged obstructed labor - major cause in developing countries
Difficult instrumental or manipulative deliveries
Injury to bladder or ureter during hysterectomy - major cause in developed contries
Congenital (rare)
Other causes include:
Radiation
Malignancy
Trauma
Infections - PID, tuberculosis etc.
Solution to Question 4:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a vesicovaginal fistula. Vesicovaginal fistulas usually present with:
Constant dribbling of urine from the vagina
Excoriation in the groin region due to constant leakage of urine
History of pelvic surgery, vaginal delivery or prolonged labor
Amenorrhea may be present
On examination, the fistula may be visualized by observing urine collection in the vagina. Bimanual examination reveals its fixity and extent.
Note: Ureterovaginal fistulas usually occur following accidental ureteric injury during C-sections in developing countries.
Solution to Question 5:
Cystoscopy is the most useful test and also the investigation of choice for vesicovaginal fistula
(VVF).
Cystoscopy or cystourethroscopy helps to visualize the size of the fistulas, the exact location of multiple fistulas and their proximity to the ureteral orifice. It can also assess the bladder mucosa for any injuries.
The 3-swab test (Option B) is done to identify the types of genitourinary fistula.
In this test, three sterile pieces of cotton swabs are serially placed in the vaginal cavity, while
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
100ml of methylene blue solution is instilled in the bladder using a catheter. The cotton swabs are placed one at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus.
Interpretation:
Uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, as seen in ureterovaginal fistula
Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, as seen in vesicovaginal fistula
Lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra,as seen in urethrovaginal fistula The below image shows the 3-swab test.

Option C: MRI is usually not needed for the diagnosis of VVF. They can be used to study vesicouterine fistulas.
Option D: Cystometry is done to measure the capacity of the bladder. It is used to investigate urge incontinence.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a urethrovaginal fistula. Urethrovaginal fistulas have the following clinical features:
Continent and dry at rest
Urinary dribbling during micturition
Fistulous opening is seen on per speculum examination
In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.
Interpretation:
The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula
Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula The given image shows the 3-swab test.

Solution to Question 7:
MRI is not preferred for a case of vesicovaginal fistula as other investigations are more specific and useful.
Investigations in VVF include:
Urine culture - to treat concurrent UTI.
Ultrasound abdomen - kidney, bladder and ureter should be observed for the presence of a urinoma or hydronephrosis.
Intravenous pyelography - to look for hydronephrosis
Cystoscopy - used to visualise the number of fistulae and their location.
Methylene blue 3-swab test in urinary fistulae - A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra and 50-100ml methylene blue is injected. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. It is interpreted as follows:
The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula.
Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula.
The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula. The given image shows the methylene blue 3-swab test.

Solution to Question 8:
In the given scenario, the best time to perform fistula repair is 6 weeks after the inciting surgery.
In uncomplicated fistulas, early surgical intervention is preferred within the first 24 to 48 hours following the inciting surgery. This avoids the brisk postoperative inflammatory response.
However, if extensive and severe inflammation is present, repair of fistula can be delayed to 6 weeks after the surgery. This is usually done in a patient who has undergone major surgery,
During this delay it is ensured that all the tissue inflammation has subsided, tissue vascularisation has improved and local infection has cleared. Estrogen therapy should be instituted in postmenopausal women in this time period.
In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.
Solution to Question 9:
The given image shows the catheter emerging from the cervical os. This, along with the history of cyclical hematuria, is suggestive of Youssef syndrome seen in a case of vesicouterine fistula.
Vesicouterine fistulas can develop after cesarean section, uterine rupture, and placenta accreta. Most cases present weeks to years later.
Vesicouterine fistulas can present with cyclical hematuria, urinary incontinence or complete continence, menstrual abnormalities, and urinary tract infections. Youssef syndrome is seen in cases of vesicouterine fistulas, and it is associated with a classic triad:
Amenorrhea
Cyclical hematuria - also called menouria: Menstrual blood trickles into the bladder through the fistula, causing hematuria
Urinary continence (there is no vaginal leakage of urine) Hysteroscopy and cystoscopy are gold-standard investigations. Vesicouterine fistulas are treated as follows:
Prolonged bladder catheterization - leads to spontaneous closure
Surgical repair via abdominal route
Solution to Question 10:
Swabs stained with methylene blue are obtained in a bladder fistula and not in a ureteric fistula. Ureteric fistulas can present with the following features:
Constant urinary dribbling
Flank pain or loin tenderness
Renal angle tenderness
Fever
Hematuria
Oliguria
Ureteric fistulas are most commonly caused by iatrogenic trauma during pelvic surgeries, especially gynecological surgeries. An excretory urogram (intravenous pyelography) or a CT urogram are the investigations of choice. Hydronephrosis may be present on the affected side.
It is managed by performing a ureteroneocystostomy and percutaneous nephrostomy.
Solution to Question 11:
The ureter is identified intraoperatively by the following features:
Ovarian artery crosses anterior to it
It is cord-like on palpation
Peristalsis occurs on palpation
It has a pale, glistening appearance
Uterine artery crosses it, from lateral to medial, 2 cm lateral to the cervix

Solution to Question 12:
The given case scenario is suggestive of ureteric injury. The highest incidence of this complication is seen with Wertheim’s hysterectomy.
Urinary tract injury occurs almost exclusively in major gynecologic surgery that involves surgical dissection in proximity to the ureters or bladder. Vaginal hysterectomy tends to have lower rates of ureteric injuries than open (abdominal, Wertheim) or laparoscopic routes. The highest risk for ureteric injury is associated with the following procedures:
Surgical debulking of gynecological cancers
Advanced pelvic reconstructive surgery
Laparoscopic hysterectomy
Patients with ureteric injuries have a complicated post-operative period. They can present with the following features:
Fever
Flank pain
Abdominal distension
Prolonged paralytic ileus - bowel sounds are absent
High drain outputs, in case abdominal drains are placed.
CT urogram and retrograde pyelography are the investigations of choice. They reveal urinary extravasation from the ureter. Ureteric injuries are prevented by careful division of tissue planes during pelvic or genitourinary surgeries. The condition is managed by prompt surgical repair by ureteroureterostomy or percutaneous ureterostomy.
Solution to Question 13:
Iatrogenic injury to the ureter is unlikely to occur at the ureteropelvic junction during gynaecological surgeries like a hysterectomy.
Ureteric injury is most commonly caused by gynecological surgeries such as laparoscopic hysterectomy, abdominal hysterectomy, etc. It can occur at:
The infundibulopelvic ligament on the lateral pelvic wall
In the ureteric canal when the uterine vessels are ligated
Near the internal cervical os
Near the uterosacral ligament
Solution to Question 14:
Improper suturing of complete perineal tears is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula.
Rectovaginal fistulas occur most commonly due to obstetric causes such as perineal tears, obstructed labor, and instrumental deliveries. Other causes include:
Tuberculosis
Lymphogranuloma venerum
Bartholinitis - rupture of an abscess into the rectum can cause a fistula
Diverticulitis
Carcinoma cervix
Radiotherapy - can cause ulceration which can develop into a fistula
Solution to Question 15:
The external urinary sphincter is innervated by the Onuf's nucleus, but not the internal one. The following factors are prerequisites for continence in women:
Position of internal urinary sphincter lies above levator ani muscles
Normal urethral closure pressure is >20 cm of water
Urethrovesical angle >100
The tone of pelvic floor muscles
Solution to Question 16:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocele in a case of genital prolapse. Stress incontinence is seen in these cases.
In stress incontinence, involuntary leakage of urine occurs when there is increased intraabdominal pressure, such as during laughing, sneezing, or coughing. There is no normal urge to pass urine.
Option A: Urge incontinence is the involuntary voiding of urine when there is an imminent urge to urinate.
Option C: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence.
Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs due to defects anywhere in the pathway of the micturition reflex, e.g., spinal cord trauma, diabetes etc. It presents with with urgency or urge incontinence.
Solution to Question 17:
Marshall and Bonney's test is used to diagnose genuine stress incontinence. It also helps in assessing how successful a surgical repair will be.
It is performed as follows:
Test
Marshall test
Bonney's test

The vagina in the region of th e bladder neck is infiltrated with local anesthetic and it is elevated.
Two fingers are placed in the vagina at the urethrovesical j unction and the bladder neck is elevated.
Positive tes t
Absence of leakage of urine o n straining or coughing

Solution to Question 18:
The given case scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. It can be diagnosed with the help of the Q-tip test.
This test is performed by placing a xylocaine-covered Q-tip cotton swab stick in the patient's urethra. Initially, the stick will be parallel to the floor. Then the patient is asked to strain or cough. Normally the stick will reach an angle of around 10-15°.
In genuine stress incontinence (GSI), this angle increases by 20° or more. A positive test indicates a sufficient degree of bladder neck descent. Unfortunately, all patients with GSI may not have a positive test, and it is not specific.
Tests done for GSI(Genuine stress incontinence) include:
Stress test
Cotton swab stick test
Marshall and Bonney test
Urethroscopy
Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry etc
Solution to Question 19:
The given scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. In this case, the first line of treatment is conservative management.
Stress incontinence is managed as follows:
Conservative management:
It is the first line of treatment.
It includes:
Kegel pelvic floor exercises for 4–6 months
Electric/magnetic stimulation for nerve damage, magnetic stimulation
Artificial urinary sphincter in neurological condition
Vaginal cones
It is also done in case surgery fails. Medical management:
Estrogen cream in menopausal woman
Venlafaxine 75 mg daily
Imipramine 10–20 mg BD Surgical management:
Kelly's repair - vaginal approac
Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis.
Burch colposuspension
Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation
Slings
Tension-free vaginal taping
Transobturator taping
Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck
Periurethral collagen injection
Vaginal sling operations have the highest long term cure rate in cases of GSI (genuine stress incontinence). Their long term cure rate is more than 90%.
Solution to Question 20:
Latzko procedure is not beneficial for a patient with genuine stress incontinence as it is done for vesicovaginal fistula.
The various surgeries done for genuine stress incontinence (GSI) are as follows:
Vaginal approac
Kelly repair
Pacey repair
Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It is not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis.
Burch colposuspension
Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation
Slings
Tension-free vaginal taping
Transobturator taping
Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck
Periurethral collagen injection
Solution to Question 21:
The given case scenario is suggestive of urge incontinence. It occurs due to detrusor instability.
During normal micturition, the detrusor muscle contracts after being stimulated by the parasympathetic nerves. In detrusor instability, detrusor muscle contracts spontaneously or on provocation during filling of the bladder. It is often caused by overactivity of parasympathetic nerves. It is usually seen in older women and is caused by:
Decreased bladder capacity - due to fibrosis
Decreased sensation
Central nervous system (CNS) inhibition - due to stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord involvement etc.
It is associated with the following symptoms:
Incontinence
Urge to urinate
Increased frequency
Nocturia
Urination during sexual intercourse and with the sound of water, hand-washing.
Solution to Question 22:
In patient 3, detrusor instability is not seen, as this is a case of functional incontinence.
During normal micturition, the detrusor muscle contracts after being stimulated by the parasympathetic nerves. In detrusor instability, detrusor muscle contracts spontaneously or on provocation during filling of the bladder. It is often caused by the overactivity of parasympathetic nerves. It is seen usually in older women and is caused by:
Decreased bladder capacity - due to fibrosis
Decreased sensation
Central nervous system (CNS) inhibition - due to stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord involvement etc.
It is associated with the following symptoms:
Incontinence
Urge to urinate
Increased frequency
Nocturia
Urination during sexual intercourse and with the sound of water, hand-washing.
Treatment is initially conservative and include decreasing caffeine intake, smoking cessation, fluid restriction and weight reduction. Anticholinergic drugs and bladder training may also be tried.
Note: Functional incontinence occurs in patients with disabilities, whose bladder movements are normal. However, due to environmental or physical barriers, involuntary leakage of urine occurs.
Solution to Question 23:
The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine rupture. The most common cause is scar dehiscence due to a previous cesarean section. This can occur due to trial of labour after C-section, or due to spontaneous labor in a patient with previous C-section. Other causes of uterine rupture are:
Prolonged induction or augmentation of labor
Obstructed labor
Blunt abdominal trauma during pregnancy
Rupture of hematometra
Rupture of pyometra
Uterine rupture is managed as follows:
Immediate cesarean section
Depending upon the extent of rupture:
Subtotal hysterectomy
Hysterectomy
Prolapse

Solution to Question 1:
Congenital prolapse is an uncommon cause of prolapse.
The most important etiological factors that lead to prolapse are the atonicity of the uterus and asthenia, which occurs due to aging and follows menopause.
The other factors which lead to prolapse are as follows:
Pregnancy
Vaginal childbirth
Menopause
Aging
Hypoestrogenism
Peripheral nerve injury to the pudendal nerve
Premature bearing down before full dilatation of the cervix
Chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure
Chronic bronchitis
Constipation
Obesity
Spina bifida occulta
Congenital weakness of pelvic floor muscles
Abdominoperineal excision of rectum
Surgeries such as Stamey and Pereyra operation for stress incontinence
Solution to Question 2:
The most important support of the pelvic viscera is the levator ani muscle. The levator ani forms a large portion of the pelvic floor. It is composed of three separate paired muscles:
Pubococcygeus
Puborectalis
Iliococcygeus
Supports of the genital organs are given by DeLancey's levels of support. However, the broad ligament is a fold of the peritoneum, which doesn't provide support to pelvic organs.
Solution to Question 3:
The given image shows uterine prolapse, for which an episiotomy is not a risk factor. Episiotomy shortens the second stage of labor and prevents the atonicity of the uterus, thus reducing the risk of prolapse.
The risk factors for uterine prolapse are:
Pregnancy
Vaginal delivery
Menopause
Aging
Hypoestrogenism
Peripheral nerve injury to the pudendal nerve
Premature bearing down before full dilatation of the cervix
Chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure
Chronic bronchitis

Congenital weakness of pelvic floor muscles
Abdominoperineal excision of rectum
Surgeries such as Stamey and Pereyra operation for stress incontinence

Solution to Question 6:
In congenital elongation of the cervix, the vaginal portion of the cervix is elongated. The fornices are hence deep, and there is no accompanying vaginal prolapse.
In 2nd and 3rd degree uterine prolapse, the supravaginal portion of the cervix gets stretched and elongated as it is well supported by the Mackenrodt’s ligaments, while the vaginal portion of the cervix prolapses with the vagina. In prolapse, the cervix can elongate to as much as 10cm in length.
However, in procidentia, the entire uterus slides with the vagina, and hence the cervix retains its normal length.
Solution to Question 7:
The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine prolapse. A retroverted uterus is not a differential diagnosis for uterine prolapse.
However, retroversion of the uterus does occur with uterine prolapse. Differential diagnoses of genital prolapse include:
Congenital elongation of the cervix - vaginal part of the cervix is elongated. In genital prolapse, supravaginal part is elongated and vaginal part is prolapsed.
Vulval cyst and Gartner cyst - large cysts may mimic prolapse
Cyst of the anterior vaginal wall - tense with well-defined margins and cannot be reduced on pressure.
Urethral diverticula - rare, small, and situated low in the anterior vaginal wall. Urethroscopy helps in the diagnosis.
Cervical fibroid polyp - cervix remains high up in its anatomical position.
Chronic inversion of the uterus - Uterine sound is used to confirm the diagnosis. USG and aparoscopy will show fundal depression and the absence of uterine fundus in the pelvis.
Rectal prolapse
Solution to Question 8:
Decubitus ulcer seen in uterine prolapse is due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes.
Decubitus ulcer refers to the ulceration of prolapsed tissue which occurs due to the chronic dependent position causing venous congestion and stasis. It has a clean edge and usually heals well with prolapse reduction and daily packing with glycerine (hygroscopic agent) and acriflavine (antiseptic). It is a benign and non-infectious disease and does not require further investigation such as biopsy or culture.
Solution to Question 9:
The given case scenario is suggestive of pelvic organ prolapse. Urge incontinence is not a complication of this condition.
Complications of prolapse are:
Damage to the ureter - can occur during
Surgical repair
Kinking due to procidentia
Urinary tract infection - due to retention of urine in a cystocele
Hydronephrosis and hydroureter
Incarceration of the prolapse - the prolapsed organ becomes irreducible
Decubitus ulcer
Stress incontinence
Squamous cell carcinoma over the decubitus ulcer (rare)
Solution to Question 10:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocoele.
A cystocele is the herniation of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It is usually associated with uterine prolapse, and presents with the following features:
Mass descending in the vagina -
Increases in size on straining and coughing
Reduces on lying down, or manual reduction
Difficulty in micturition - difficulty initiating, straining required
Mass needs to be pushed inwards to urinate - repositioning of cystocele required
Increased frequency of micturition
Backache - due to stretching of uterosacral ligaments

Solution to Question 12:
Fothergill's operation preserves menstrual and reproductive functions.
Fothergill's repair is also known as Manchester's operation. It is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. The steps are:
Preliminary D and C
Anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix.
Raw area covered with the vaginal mucosa.
Mackenrodt ligaments sutured in the front of the cervix
Colpoperineorrhaphy
Since the uterus is preserved in this procedure, the patient is able to menstruate and can conceive and carry the pregnancy. However, fertility decreases due to the loss of cervical mucus. Moreover, cervical incompetence occurs, leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries.

Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.

Solution to Question 13:
In the clinal scenario of a 55-year-old woman with third-degree uterine prolapse, the ideal management is vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair.
Uterine prolapse is the descent of the uterus from its normal position which usually occurs due to laxity of ligaments that offer support, seen often due to childbirth, aging, or trauma. The uterine descent is clinically categorized into:
First degree: the external os remains above the vaginal introitus
Second degree: The external os protrudes below the vaginal introitus but the uterine body remains inside the vagina
Third degree (Syn: Complete prolapse): The uterine, cervix, body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus
Procidentia involves prolapse of the uterus with the entire vagina everted.
The patient usually presents with a sense of heaviness in the pelvic region with lower back discomfort. Based on the structures involved the patient can additionally have urinary symptoms (like incontinence and urgency), bowel disturbances (constipation and tenesmus), or sexual discomfort during intercourse.
Symptomatic uterine prolapse is managed surgically with different procedures based on the profile of the patient. Conservative management is done for old asymptomatic women with mild degree prolapse.
A vaginal hysterectomy is recommended for patients who satisfy the following criteria:
>40 years of age
Have completed their families
Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function Other options:
Option A: Fothergill repair or Manchester operation is a procedure done to preserve the reproductive function and vaginal prolapse with supravaginal cervix elongation. It initially involves preliminary curettage with low amputation of the cervix. After Mackenrodt's ligament is plicated, anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy are performed.
Option B: Sling operation (Purandare's operation) is indicated in congenital or nulliparous prolapse without cystocele. The procedure involves the extraperitoneal passage of rectus sheath strips joined to the anterior surface of the cervix by silk sutures.
Option D: Shirodkar procedure is a type of abdominal sling surgery done in young women to retain menstrual and reproductive function. It involves using a sling to fix the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
Solution to Question 14:
Le Fort’s repair is recommended in this case. This repair is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria:
Elderly (>60 years)
Do not wish to retain sexual function
Medically unfit for major surgeries
Solution to Question 15:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse, who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function
Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include:
Abdominal wall cervicopexy - cervical supports are fixed to the abdominal wa
Shirodkar’s sling operation - cervix is fixed to the lumbosacral fascia using Mersilene tape
Khanna’s abdominal sling operation - isthmus of the cervix is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spines. It is not done anymore due to the risk of periosteitis.
Virkud's sling operation - the tape is fixed from the isthmus and attached to the rectus compartment
Joshi's sling operation - the uterus is suspended from the pectineal ligaments.
Solution to Question 16:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an enterocele associated with fecal incontinence. It is preferably repaired using an abdominal approach like Moschcowitz repair.
An enterocele is herniation of the pouch of Douglas and small bowel loops into the rectovaginal septum. Enteroceles are most commonly associated with uterine prolapse. Patients present with the following clinical features:
Fecal incontinence
Sexual dysfunction
Constipation/diarrhea
Mass descending PV
Pelvic pain or pelvic discomfort
A bulge in the posterior vaginal wall:
Upper 1/3rd - enterocele
Lower 2/3rd - rectocele
Peristalsis may be observed in the bulge Enterocele repair is done via the following methods:
Vaginal approach - it is usually preferred over an abdominal approach. In McCall's culdoplasty, the uterosacral ligaments are used to suspend the vaginal vault. The posterior peritoneum and uterosacral ligaments are approximated.
Abdominal approach - it is preferred in cases where there is associated fecal incontinence. It includes:
Moschcowitz repair - the pouch of Douglas is obliterated by several purse-string sutures.
Halban's procedure - the peritoneal sac is obliterated using vertical sutures. This can also be done transvaginally.
Option B: Purandare's sling operation is abdominal wall cervicopexy for uterine prolapse. It is done for young nulliparous women.
Option D: Le Fort's repair is done in elderly patients with uterine prolapse, who are unfit for surgery.
Note: Enteroceles may be present along with uterine prolapse. Failure to identify and repair it during vaginal hysterectomy can lead to vault prolapse.
Solution to Question 17:
There are 3 degrees of vault prolapse.
Vault prolapse is a delayed complication of both abdominal and vaginal hysterectomy. It can also occur due to failure to identify and repair an enterocele during a hysterectomy.
In vault prolapse, level 1 supports become weak and deficient. Risk factors apart from past history of surgery are:
Advanced age
Menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
Parity
Obesity
Chronic cough
Solution to Question 18:
The given case scenario is suggestive of vault prolapse. Sacrospinous colpopexy is the gold standard management for vault prolapse.
Vault prolapse presents with pelvic or back pain, the descent of the vault through the vagina, difficulties in intercourse, and difficulty in walking due to the mass. It is commonly associated with a cystocele or a rectocele.
It can be prevented by identifying and repairing an enterocele and by attaching the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments to the vault during a hysterectomy.
Vault prolapse is managed as follows:
If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacra suspension
If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation/colpopexy - the gold standard
Laparoscopic colpopexy
If the patient does not want to retain sexual function:
Colpocleisis
Le Fort's repair
Anterior colporrhaphy in case of cystocele
Posterior colporrhaphy in case of rectocele
If the patient is unfit for surgery, ring pessaries can be tried
Posterior intravaginal slingplasty
Note: Kelly's repair and Burch colposuspension are done to manage stress incontinence.

Solution to Question 20:
The given image shows a ring pessary, which is only a palliative treatment for genital prolapse.
A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients and very elderly women. In these patients, it is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy.
Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. After being placed, they should be changed every 3 months. They may cause vaginitis; dyspareunia; and, rarely, carcinoma if retained for a long time.
The image below shows the types of pessaries:


Solution to Question 21:
The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's maneuver or cough and see if the pessary is in place.
There is some level of descent of the pessary with these maneuvers is to be expected, but the pessary should return to its normal position when these efforts are stopped. If the pessary descends to the introitus with these maneuvers, then a larger size pessary should be tried.
The pessary is well-fitted if you are able to slide the ring of the pessary up and down along the vaginal sidewall. It is well-fitted if you are able to insert one finger between the vaginal sidewall and the edge of the pessary. When the labia are separated, a well-supported pessary is not usually visible.
The patient should be comfortable, and able to void urine with the pessary in place before leaving the clinic.

Solution to Question 22:
Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent.
Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction. They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces. Weakening of levator ani and pelvic fascia from stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.
The levator ani muscle is a complex unit, which consists of 3 muscle components namely
Pubococcygeus (anterior fibers)
Pubovaginalis - elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
Puboperinealis - draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
Puboanalis - elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed
Puborectalis (intermediate fibers)
Iliococcygeus (posterior fibers)
Origin: The levator ani muscle has a linear origin from the pelvic surface of the body of the pubis, a tendinous arch of obturator fascia, and the pelvic surface of the ischial spine.
Insertion:
The anterior fibres form a sling around the prostate (levator prostatae) or vagina (sphincter vaginae) and are inserted into the perineal body (a mass of fibrous tissue) in front of the ana canal.
The intermediate fibres (puborectalis) form a sling around the anorectal junction to be inserted into the anococcygeal raphe (a fibrous raphe which extends from the anorectal junction to the tip of the coccyx).
The posterior fibres (iliococcygeus) are inserted into the anococcygeal raphe and the coccyx. Nerve supply:
perineal branch of 4th sacral nerve (S4) from its pelvic surface.
perineal branch of the pudendal nerve (S2, S3) from its perineal surface. Actions:
The levator ani muscles of two sides together support the pelvic viscera and resist the
intra-abdominal pressure during straining and expulsive efforts of the anterior abdominal wa muscles.
They also subserve a sphincteric action on the anorectal junction to maintain the continence of faeces in both sexes and vagina in females.
