Solution to Question 1:
Fibroids are more common in African-American women.
Uterine fibroids are benign, smooth muscle tumors present in the uterine musculature. They are most commonly seen during reproductive years. Estrogen and progesterone promote the development of fibroids.
Option B: Hypoestrogenism occurs in smokers, therefore smoking is protective for fibroids.
Option C: Estrogen exposure is increased in nulliparous women, therefore fibroids are more common. Increased parity is protective for fibroids.
Option D: Most fibroids do not increase in size during pregnancy. Pregnancy can have an unpredictable effect on fibroids based on individual genetic and environmental factors.
Solution to Question 2:
MLH1 gene is not associated with leiomyomas. Its mutation leads to endometrial carcinoma.
MED12 and HMGA2 are the most common genes associated with leiomyomas. Other genes involved are COL4A5-A6 and the gene for fumarate hydratase (FH). FH gene mutation leads to hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC) syndrome.
Solution to Question 3:
Leiomyomas convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone.
Leiomyomas create a hyperestrogenic environment, which is a requisite for their growth and maintenance. The hyperestrogenic environment is created by the following mechanisms:
Compared to normal myometrium, leiomyoma cells contain a greater density of estrogen receptors, which results in greater estradiol binding.
These tumors convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone.
There are higher levels of cytochrome P450 aromatase in leiomyomas compared with norma myocytes. This specific enzyme catalyzes the conversion of androgens to estrogen.
Solution to Question 4:
Initially, all fibroids are intramural. Fibroids develop in the myometrium, as intramural/interstitial and then branch out to form the other types.
Classification of fibroids based on anatomical location:
Body (corporeal) fibroids-
Interstitial/intramural fibroids: They are the most common (75%).
Subserosal fibroids: They are the least common (10%). Interstitial fibroids grow outwards to form subserous fibroids and are covered by the peritoneum. These include wandering or parasitic fibroids and broad ligament fibroids.
Submucous fibroids: Interstitial fibroid grows inwards towards the uterine cavity. It is the most symptomatic type.
Cervical fibroids

Solution to Question 5:
The given cut section image showing multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, and white-greyish with a whorled appearance is Leiomyoma (Fibroid).
Leiomyoma is the most common benign and the most common pelvic tumor in females and is more common in obese females(hyper-estrogenism). They are mostly asymptomatic and the most common symptom is menorrhagia.
Leiomyomas can also present with bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.
The image below different types of uterine fibroids classified according to their locations:

Sub-mucous fibroids are the most symptomatic type and intra-mural fibroids are the most common type of uterine fibroids.
Other options:
Option B: Endometrial cancer presents as a polypoid mass protruding into the uterine cavity or as a diffuse thickening of the endometrium. The cut surface may appear white to yellow and may show areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.
Option C: Endometrial polyps are usually small and may be single or multiple. Grossly, they appear as soft, red to pink, often pedunculated (attached by a stalk) masses protruding into the uterine cavity. It presents with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium.
Option D: In Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna), the uterus may appear bulky and symmetrically enlarged. On the cut section, the myometrium may appear thickened and may show tiny cystic spaces filled with old blood (chocolate cysts). The preferred treatment is hysterectomy. Localised excision or levonorgestrel IUCD is tried in younger women.
The image below shows both the gross and histologic appearances of adenomyosis:

Solution to Question 6:
Menouria and hypomenorrhea are not seen in patients with uterine fibroids. Menouria occurs due to vesicouterine fistulas. Hypomenorrhea is seen in Asherman's syndrome and due to OCP use.
Fibroids present with the following clinical features:
Menstrual symptoms such as:
Menstrual irregularities - heavy menstrual bleeding/menorrhagia which is the most common symptom, polymenorrhoea, and intermenstrual bleeding (metrorrhagia)
Dysmenorrhea
Postmenopausal bleeding
Abdominal pain
Abdominal distension, mass abdomen
Vaginal discharge
Infertility
Recurrent abortions
Pressure symptoms such as:
Urinary retention
Increased frequency of urination
Constipation
Broad ligament fibroids can cause compression of the ureter leading to hydronephrosis or hydroureter.
Solution to Question 7:
Intermenstrual bleeding is common with submucous fibroids. Metrorrhagia or intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs during the middle of the menstrual cycle.
Metrorrhagia in a woman over 40 years warrants a dilatation and curettage procedure to rule out endometrial cancer. This is associated with fibroids in 3% of cases.
Polymenorrhoea in a patient with fibroids occurs when she has polycystic ovaries or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
Progressive menorrhagia is seen in intramural and submucous myoma due to increased vascularity, endometrial hyperplasia, and an enlarged uterine cavity.
Note: Further the distance of the fibroid from the cavity, lesser is the possibility of menorrhagia. For this reason, subserous and pedunculated fibroids do not cause menorrhagia.
Solution to Question 8:
Investigations required to identify submucous fibroids include:
USG - most commonly done. Transvaginal USG is useful to assess the location, dimension, and associated adnexal pathology.
MRI gives better soft tissue details but is not routinely done
Saline infusion sonography and hysteroscopy - help to visualise submucous fibroid more clearly
Laparoscopy - If uterus <12 weeks size and associated pelvic pain and infertility and to detect pelvic endometriosis and tubal pathology.
Uterine curettage – A bump is felt in submucous fibroid during endometrial curettage. Dilatation and curettage is done in patients presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.
Hysterosalpingography – A filling defect is seen.
CT abdomen is not very useful for the identification of submucous fibroids. These cannot be visualised on colposcopy either.
The image below shows the ultrasonographic appearance of a submucous fibroid (asterisk):

The image given below shows hysteroscopic view of a submucous fibroid:

Solution to Question 9:
The ureter and uterine vessels lie lateral to a secondary broad ligament fibroid. There are 2 types of broad ligament fibroids:
Primary broad ligament fibroid:
It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid.
The arise from:
Uterosacral ligament
Round ligament
Tissues in the broad ligament
Relations:
The uterine vessels lie medial to it.
The ureter is usually beneath the fibroid. However, it can be present anywhere in relation to it. Secondary broad ligament fibroid:
It is also known as false broad ligament fibroid.
They arise from the lateral wall of the uterus or cervix, but grow laterally, between the two layers of the broad ligament.
Relations - the uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to it.
Solution to Question 10:
Fibroid calcification begins at the periphery and spreads inwards along the vessels.
A typical myoma is a well-circumscribed tumor with a pseudo-capsule and firm in consistency. Its cut surface has a whorled appearance.
The vessels that supply blood to the tumor lie in the capsule and send radial branches into the tumor. Therefore, the central portion of the tumour receives the least blood supply, and degeneration is noticeable early in this part of the tumour. However, fibroid calcification begins at the periphery.
The image given below show the gross appearance of fibroids.

Solution to Question 11:
The given specimen shows red degeneration of fibroid. Degeneration is most likely to start from the centre of the fibroid.
In a fibroid, centre of the tumor is the least vascular part and hence degeneration is more common here. The only exception is calcareous degeneration where phosphates and carbonates of lime are deposited in the periphery along the course of the vessels.
Solution to Question 12:
Hyaline degeneration of fibroids is unlikely here as it is usually painless and presents as an abdominal mass causing distension and heaviness.
Acute pain in fibroids is seen in the case of:
Fibroid torsion
Hemorrhage into the fibroid
Red degeneration
Sarcomatous change - seen in postmenopausal women.
Solution to Question 13:
The given case scenario is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid.
It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. The gross appearance is described as follows:
Fishy odor
Thrombosis of subcapsular vessels and vessels within the fibroid
Purplish-red color due to diffusion of blood pigments from the thrombosed vessels.
Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.
The image given below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration of fibroids

Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen, but fever and leukocytosis are absent.
Option C: Infection is more common in puerperium and presents with blood-stained vaginal discharge.
Option D: Sarcomatous changes occur very rarely, and are unlikely in patients <40 years of age. They are more commonly seen in post-menopausal women.

Fetal malformations have not been recorded to occur due to fibroids. Pregnancy complications due to fibroids are:
Increased risk of abortion or miscarriage
Preterm labor
Abnormal presentation
Fibroid degeneration (Red degenaration)
Accidental hemorrhage

Solution to Question 15:
Squamous metaplasia is not seen in fibroid.
Solution to Question 16:
The given image shows womb-stone appearance on CT, suggestive of calcific degeneration of fibroid.
These are also called calcareous myomas and are seen in old patients with long-standing myomas. This occurs due to the deposition calcium phosphates and calcium carbonates in the periphery of the fibroid, along the course of the vessels. It is easily visualized on radiography.
Solution to Question 17:
Sarcomatous change is the least common secondary change in fibroids. Its incidence is <0.5%.
Sarcomatous change leads to the development of malignant leiomyosarcomas. This is seen in postmenopausal women and is rare in women <40 years of age. Intramural and submucous tumors have a higher potential for sarcomatous change than subserous tumors.
Its gross appearance is described as follows:
Soft consistency
Yellowish-grey
Hemorrhagic spots seen
Radiology shows dark, irregular areas and air levels within the fibroid. These are indicative of sarcomatous change.
The image given below shows the CT appearance of a large fibroid that has undergone sarcomatous change. The image on the right shows a fluid level within the tumor.

Solution to Question 18:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a parasitic fibroid. The given histopathological image shows interlacing bundles of uniform spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with blunted nuclei that are characteristic of a fibroid.
A parasitic fibroid or a wandering fibroid gets cut off from its uterine origin and derives its blood supply from the vessels of the organ it is attached to. Thus, it can continue to grow in spite of uterine artery embolisation. It is managed by complete resection.
Option A: Pedunculated fibroids have a pedicle with which they're attached to the myometrium.
Option C: Leiomyosarcoma commonly presents in postmenopausal women with sudden increase in size and postmenopausal bleeding. It would show nuclear atypia on histology.
Option D: Disseminated intraperitoneal leiomyomatosis involves large areas of sub peritoneal surfaces. It is seen during pregnancy and while on oral contraceptives.
Solution to Question 19:
The given scenario of severe acute abdominal pain without fever/leucocytosis in a pregnant woman with a fibroid is suggestive of fibroid torsion.
The incidence of fibroid in pregnancy is about 1 in 1,000. Due to increased vascularity in pregnancy, the fibroid increases in size and becomes softer. The torsion is seen in the subserous pedunculated fibroid where the venous return is blocked at its site of attachment in the uterus. This leads to severe acute abdominal pain. Due to the complication being more local than systemic, fever or leucocytosis are generally not seen.
A transvaginal ultrasonogram is immediately done to detect the position and size of the fibroid, which is followed by laparotomic myomectomy as a part of emergency surgical management.
Other options:
Option A: Red degeneration of fibroid is seen commonly in the second half of pregnancy or puerperium. It is due to a hemorrhagic infarction of the tissue and typically presents as acute focal abdominal pain with fever and leucocytosis. Treatment is usually conservative with bed rest, analgesics, and sedatives.
Option B: Preterm labor is where the labor starts before 37 completed weeks. It is characterized by true labor pain. The abdominal pain is slowly increasing in intensity and duration and is also accompanied by show (expulsion of the cervical mucus plug). There are intervals between episodes of contractions where the patient doesn't complain of abdominal pain.
Solution to Question 20:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an uncomplicated fibroid during pregnancy. These are managed conservatively.
Surgery is only indicated in the case of a pedunculated fibroid undergoes torsion.
Solution to Question 21:
The given case scenario and ultrasound image showing a well-defined, heterogeneous hypoechoic mass are suggestive of a uterine fibroid. Misoprostol does not help to reduce the size of the fibroid and so is not recommended for its management.
Medical management of fibroids helps to reduce their size. The drugs used in therapy are as follows:
Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone / RU-486
GnRH analogs
Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, buserelin
Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system
Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM) – Asoprisni
Danazol - usually not used due to androgenic side effects.
Solution to Question 22:
The nasal spray is unlikely to contain histrelin, as it is only available as a subcutaneous implant.
GnRH analogues are used to treat leiomyomas. Intranasal preparations are available for leuprolide, nafarelin, and buserelin. However, leuprolide has maximal action as an intramuscular injection.
GnRH analogue therapy in fibroids is given as follows:
Leuprolide acetate (Lupron) - given intramuscularly. It is also available as an intranasal spray, but isn't commonly used.
Goserelin (Zoladex) - subcutaneous depot implant
Triptorelin (Trelstar) IM injection
Nafarelin and buserelin - given as intranasal sprays bd
Histrelin - available as subcutaneous implants.
Solution to Question 23:
Red degeneration of fibroid is managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics.
It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.
Solution to Question 24:
Red degeneration is not an indication of myomectomy. It is conservatively managed. Myomectomy is indicated in the following:
Symptoms compromising the quality of life such as:
Heavy menstrual bleeding, causing anemia
Pelvic pain
Urinary symptoms and ureteric obstruction.
The patient is unwilling for hysterectomy
The patient wishes to preserve childbearing function
Fibroids causing infertility
Solution to Question 25:
Ultrasound-guided transcervical metroplasty is not used in the treatment of leiomyomas. It is used for the resection of the uterine septum.
Uterine artery embolization/Uterine fibroid embolization (UAE/UFE) is an angiographic interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) microspheres or other synthetic particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. The vessels serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, hence these microspheres are preferentially directed to the tumors, thus sparing the surrounding myometrium.
Nd:YAG myolysis is laparoscopic myolysis performed with an Nd:YAG laser. It causes coagulation of a subserous fibroid.
The below image shows uterine artery embolization.

Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS) is also called MR-guided high-intensity focused ultrasound (MR-HIFU).
Ultrasound energy is focused to heat and incite coagulative necrosis in selected myomas. Concurrent MR imaging enables precise targeting and provides real-time tissue temperature feedback to limit surrounding thermal injury.
The given image shows MRgFUS.

Solution to Question 26:
The given image shows uterine artery embolization (UAE). UAE cannot be done in nulliparous women as embolization of ovarian vessels can cause ovarian failure and premature menopause.
Under local sedation, bilateral UAE is approached through percutaneous femoral catheterization. Embolization is done by releasing polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles or metal coils into the uterine artery.

Solution to Question 1:
Sampson's theory describes the implantation of endometrial tissue due to retrograde menstruation.
The various theories for the etiology of endometriosis include:
Given below is an illustration showing retrograde menstrual flow that is leading to the development of patches of endometriosis.
Theory
Mechanism
Sampson's implantation theo ry
Reflux of menstrual endomet rium and subsequent implant ation in the surrounding stru ctures
Theory of coelomic metaplasi a by Meyer and Ivanoff
Metaplastic changes in embr yonic mesothelium which res pond to hormone stimulation
Metastatic theory by Halban
Embolization of menstrual fr agments through vascular an d lymphatic channels

Induction of undifferentiated peritoneal cells to endometri al tissue by an endogenous fa ctor

Solution to Question 2:
The most common site of occurrence of endometriosis is the ovary. Endometriosis of the ovary is known as endometrioma.
By definition, endometriosis is the occurrence of benign endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the cavity of the uterus. Endometriosis can occur anywhere in the body (except spleen) including the abdominal wall, lung, pleura, brain, etc.
It is a proliferative, hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. Women between the age groups of 30-40 years are most commonly affected. Risk factors for endometriosis are as follows:
Family history (7-10x risk with a 1st-degree relative)
Nulliparity
In utero exposure to Diethylstilbestrol (DES)
Estrogen dependent conditions/Estrogen therapy
Immunological factor - Impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a woman may increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.
Solution to Question 3:
The most common symptom of endometriosis is dysmenorrhea.
Pain begins before the onset of menstruation and builds up continuously until the flow starts. Thereafter, the pain gradually declines. This pattern of pain is called triple dysmenorrhea.
Solution to Question 4:
Patients diagnosed with endometriosis are not likely to present with vaginal discharge. Clinical features of endometriosis include:
About 30% of the patients are asymptomatic.
The classic symptom complex includes:
Dysmenorrhoea
Dyspareunia
Menorrhagia
Infertility (30-40%)
Dysmenorrhoea - most common symptom
Dyspareunia - occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.
Deep-seated pelvic pain
Premenstrual and postmenstrual spotting
Solution to Question 5:
Pain in endometriosis mainly correlates with the depth of penetration.
Lesions penetrating more than 5mm are responsible for pain, dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. The dysmenorrhea associated with endometriosis precedes menses by 24 to 48 hours and is less responsive to NSAIDs and combined OCPs.
Solution to Question 6:
The sites of endometriosis arranged in the order of frequency of occurrence are: Ovary > Pouch of Douglas > Broad ligament > Uterosacral ligament > Fallopian tube.
Endometriotic lesions have been identified on all organs except the spleen.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario along with the tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligament points towards a diagnosis of endometriosis.
The nodularity of the uterosacral ligament in endometriosis gives rise to the cobblestone appearance seen on laparoscopy. This is referred to as 'sine qua non of endometriosis'.
The below image shows the cobblestone appearance of the uterosacral ligament.

Note: Endometrioma or chocolate cyst is endometriosis of the ovary. It presents as an adnexa mass.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario of dysmenorrhea with tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a retroverted uterus is suggestive of endometriosis. The gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of this condition is a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. It is also the investigation of choice for the condition.
Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:
Detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis
Locate the site of endometriosis and staging
To take biopsy
To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation Other investigations for endometriosis include:
Estimation of CA-125 levels - raised in endometriosis.
Estimation of MCP-1 (Monocyte chemotactic protein) levels - raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical history and the image showing characteristic powder burn spots seen over the pelvic peritoneum on laparoscopy point toward a diagnosis of pelvic endometriosis.
On laparoscopy, the typical endometriotic lesions appear like small black, dark brown or bluish dots. These are called powder burns or gunshot appearance of the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are nodules or small cysts containing old haemorrhages surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.
Subtle appearances of endometriosis seen on laparoscopy are:
Red flame-shaped areas
Red polypoid areas
Yellow-brown patches
White peritoneal plaques or scarring
Peritoneal defects - known as Allen Masters Syndrome
Subovarian adhesions.
The lesions mentioned above are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas.
Endometriotic lesions in the peritoneal cavity contain yellowish-brown fluid. This fluid contains prostaglandins that are responsible for the pain associated with this condition. Endometriosis of the ovary leads to formation of the chocolate cyst which is a true cyst with columnar epithelium lining.
The image below shows the laparoscopic appearance of endometriotic lesions in the pouch of Douglas and on the right, the sacrouterine ligament. Dyspareunia occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.

Solution to Question 10:
In endometriotic lesions, histology represents its high estrogen activity.
Endometriosis is defined by the presence of “ectopic” endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. Endometriosis is a proliferative hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. It is extremely rare before menarche and disappears after menopause.
The endometriotic implants show certain differences when compared to normal endometrium. There is increased production of estrogen by endometriotic stromal cells due to high levels of the enzyme aromatase. This is absent in normal endometrial stroma.

The given clinical history and the image is suggestive of a chocolate cyst of the ovary which is a benign cystic lesion.
Chocolate cysts of the ovary are a manifestation of endometriosis. Both the ovaries are usually affected. On histology, the cyst is lined by columnar epithelium. Pseudoxanthoma cells are present which are large macrophages or scavenger cells that appear brown in colour due to ingested blood pigments such as haemosiderin. They are polyhedral in shape and resemble lutein cells.

Endometrioma refers to ovarian endometriosis. CA-125 levels are raised to more than 35 U/mL in 80% of cases of endometriosis. The level is directly proportional to the extent of the disease.
Solution to Question 14:
Estrogen is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as the condition is estrogen-dependent.
For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow.
For moderate to severe disease, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They are known to antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy. The drug of choice is GnRH agonists.

Note: The best time to conceive in a patient with endometriosis is immediately after surgery.
Solution to Question 15:
The GnRH agonist available as a nasal preparation for the treatment of endometriosis is nafarelin.
GnRH analogues are used in the management of endometriosis and are given by continuous administration. This suppresses the secretion of pituitary gonadotropins and leads to atrophy of the endometrial tissue in 90% of cases.
Leuprolide and triptorelin are GnRH agonists which are given IM. Goserelin is available as a depot preparation.
Solution to Question 16:
Patients with adenomyosis commonly present with symptoms of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea.
Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. It usually occurs following vigorous curettage, repeated childbirth or in conditions with an excess of estrogen. Adenomyosis is more common in multiparous women aged 40 years and above. They commonly present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Other symptoms include pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia.
On per-vaginal examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. This is known as Halban's sign.
Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management because of menorrhagia.
Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision and levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger patients.
The image below is an illustration of adenomyosis.

The image below shows adenomyosis as seen during laparoscopy. The uterus is soft and enlarged; the blue spots represent subserous endometriosis.

Solution to Question 17:
Adenomyosis is not associated with sub involution of the uterus.
Uterine subinvolution is impaired or retarded involution of the uterus. It is associated with uterine fibroid, cesarean section and conditions causing overdistension of the uterus like twin pregnancies or polyhydramnios.
Adenomyosis often coexists with the following conditions:
Uterine fibromyomas
Pelvic endometriosis (15%)
Endometrial carcinoma
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical vignette and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blind appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. The definitive treatment for adenomyosis is hysterectomy.
Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical
assessment. Painful, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign.
TVS findings include salt and pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of subendometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.
Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

Solution to Question 1:
Mutation of the CYP21 gene can cause polycystic ovarian syndrome.
The gene for 21-hydroxylase (CYP21) is located in the short arm of chromosome 6. Heterozygosity of the gene has been linked to the development of PCOS. Defects in this gene also lead to congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical history of excessive growth of coarse hair is suggestive of hirsutism. The most common cause for hirsutism in female patients is polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).
Hirsutism is defined as excessive growth of androgen-dependent sexual hair or male distribution of hair in female patients. PCOS accounts for 70-80% of the cases of hirsutism, which typically begins in late adolescence or the early 20s.
Idiopathic hirsutism is the second most frequent cause. The most common rapid onset of hirsutism in young females is a testosterone-producing tumour like granulosa cell or Sertoli-Leydig cell tumours.
Other less common causes of hirsutism include:
Late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia
Tumours of the ovary and adrenal glan
Cushing’s syndrome
Drug-induce
Virilisation: Characterized by more extensive androgen-induced changes than hirsutism alone. It has the following features:
Acne
Increased oily skin
Temporal balding
Clitoromegaly
Deepening of the voice
Development of male muscular pattern and body habitus
Atrophy of breasts
Hypertrichosis: Excessive growth of non-sexual hair.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hirsutism. The Ferriman-Gallwey score is used to clinically assess and quantify the degree of hirsutism.
Within this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed at nine body areas and each of them scored from 0-4. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area. The maximum score is 36. The degree of hirsutism is mild if the score is 8. Moderate to
severe hirsutism is present if the score is 15.
Note: Ferriman Gallwey score originally had 11 sites which were modified later to exclude 2 sites, viz., forearm, and legs.
Solution to Question 4:
The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose Stein-Levinthal syndrome or PCOS. ESHRE/ASRM or Rotterdam criteria (2003):
Any two out of these three must be present-
Clinical/ Biochemical hyperandrogenism
Oligo/anovulation
Polycystic ovaries
Other criteria used for diagnosing PCOS:
National Institute of Health (NIH) criteria (1990)
To include both
Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism
Oligo/anovulation
Androgen excess and PCOS society(AE-PCOS) criteria:
To include both:
Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism
Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries
Option A: Meig's syndrome refers to ascites and pleural effusions that accompany a benign ovarian tumor.
Option B: Asherman's syndrome refers to the formation of intrauterine synechiae, usually following endometrial destructive procedures like curettage or ablation.
Option C: Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome is characterised by congenital absence of vagina, primary amenorrhoea, rudimentary cornua uteri and morphologically normal ovaries and Fallopian tubes situated on the pelvic sidewall.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical history and the necklace appearance on ultrasound are suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease.
The original Rotterdam consensus defined polycystic ovaries when 12 follicles were seen per ovary on USG. Each follicle should measure between 2 and 9 mm, and/or an ovarian volume should be >10 ml. Due to improvement in imaging modalities since that time, the threshold for
follicle number has now been raised to 20 per ovary.
Solution to Question 6:
PCOS is characterised by multiple small ovarian cysts, each less than 1 cm in size. Sonographic findings seen in PCOS are:
 12 small cysts of 2 to 9 mm in diameter.
Increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both.
A single ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS. However, this criteria does not apply to women taking combined oral contraceptive pills.
Note: In settings with improved sonographic imaging resolution, a follicle number  20 cysts per ovary can be considered significant for PCOS.
Solution to Question 7:
The hyperpigmented areas in the given image are acanthosis nigricans and this is associated with hyperinsulinemia. This skin condition is thought to be a cutaneous marker of insulin resistance.
Acanthosis nigricans is a velvety, darkening of the skin that usually occurs in the intertriginous areas. It has poorly defined borders, usually occurs in skin fold areas, such as the back of the neck, axilla, and groin, and may include thickening of the skin.
The pathogenesis of acanthosis nigricans is linked to growth factor levels and insulin-mediated activation of insulin-like growth factor (IGF) on keratinocytes and increased growth factor levels.
Acanthosis nigricans is usually seen in people younger than 40 years of age and is associated with the following disorders:
Obesity
Hypothyroidism
Acromegaly
Polycystic ovary disease
Insulin-resistant diabetes
Cushing’s disease
Addison’s disease
Gastrointestinal malignancies such as adenocarcinoma of the stomach or pancreas.
The treatment for acanthosis nigricans is directed towards the management of the underlying cause.
Solution to Question 8:
HAIR-AN syndrome is not characterized by mild hyperandrogenism but marked hyperandrogenism (HA). It also includes insulin resistance (IR) and acanthosis nigricans (AN).
HAIR-AN syndrome and ovarian hyperthecosis are exaggerated phenotypes of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Women affected by HAIR-AN syndrome often present with symptoms of severe hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne) and may occasionally display signs of virilization like clitoromegaly, temporal balding and voice deepening.
Ovarian hyperthecosis is a rare condition characterized by nests of luteinized theca cells distributed throughout the ovarian stroma.
Solution to Question 9:
A depressed HDL level and elevated total cholesterol:HDL ratios are seen in patients with PCOS. The following are associated with PCOS:
Insulin resistance
Impaired glucose tolerance and type 2 diabetes mellitus
Dyslipidemia: Increased LDL and triglyceride levels, elevated total cholesterol levels:HDL ratios.
Infertility/subfertility
A three-fold increased risk of endometrial cancer
Mild elevations in testosterone levels <200 ng/dL
Normal range of testosterone in women is 20-70 ng/dL. A mild elevation in testosterone is consistent with the diagnosis of PCOS. However, values > 200 ng/dL may suggest an ovarian tumour and warrant pelvic sonography.
Solution to Question 10:
The lesions shown in the image are acne. The drugs used to treat acne and hirsutism in a patient with PCOS are OCPs with cyproterone acetate.
The first step in the management of PCOS is weight reduction. OCPs are the drugs of choice for regularisation of cycles. They are also the drugs of choice for hirsutism and acne. OCPs used for PCOS should contain a 3rd/4th generation progestagen like cyproterone acetate. OCPs induce regular menstrual cycles, lower androgen levels and causes thinning of the endometrium.
Insulin sensitizers like metformin have been found to improve metabolic and gynecologic issues. It acts by reducing the insulin level and reducing hepatic production of glucose (liver neoglycolysis). Other benefits of metformin include improvement in fertility rate and reduction of the total and free testosterone levels. It also increases levels of sex hormone-binding globulin.
Metformin is contraindicated in hepatic and renal disease.
Treatment of infertility associated with PCOS is done using ovulation-inducing drugs like letrozole and clomiphene citrate. If medical management fails, surgical options like laparoscopic ovarian drilling can be considered.
Note:
FOGSI, in 2024, has replaced Letrozole as the first-line drug for induction of ovulation in patients with PCOS. However, the FDA approval for the same is still pending.
Solution to Question 11:
Clomiphene is an FDA approved drug used for the treatment of infertility associated with PCOS.
Clomiphene induces ovulation in 80% of the cases and 40–50% patients conceive. However, abortions are common due to luteal phase defects. Ovarian hyperstimulation occurs in <1% cases. Co-administration with dexamethasone leads to better outcomes. In resistant case, tamoxifen 20–40 mg daily for 5 days should be tried.
Currently, letrozole has proven to be more effective in ovarian infertility in obese women but its use in such cases is pending FDA approval.
Solution to Question 12:
Surgical management is indicated in all the above conditions except for morbid obesity. Indications of surgery in PCOS include:
Failed medical therapy
Ovarian hyperstimulation
Infertility
Previous pregnancy losses
Surgery comprises of laparoscopic drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It is done using a laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine milieu and improves fertility for a year or so. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may again reduce the fertility rate. The formation of adhesions can be reduced by hydrofloatation.
The advantages of surgery are as follows:
Tubal testing with chromotubation can be performed simultaneously
Other causes of infertility like endometriosis can be looked for
One-time treatment
Intense and prolonged monitoring for side effects is not require
Cost-effective compared to IVF
Reduces androgen and LH production
Following surgery, single ovulation occurs with drugs, and hyperstimulation and multiple pregnancies are avoide
Ovulation occurs in 80–90% and pregnancy in 60–70% The disadvantages of surgery are as follows:
It involves giving anaesthesia and performing an invasive procedure like laparoscopy
Adhesions may form postoperatively
If cautery is used, premature ovarian failure due to destruction of ovarian tissue may be seen
Solution to Question 13:
The image showing enlarged ovaries with multiple large cysts along with the history of treatment for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin suggests the diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).
Human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG) is a medication that is composed of FSH and LH. It is used to stimulate the release of ova in women who do not ovulate spontaneously. It can lead
to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.
Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a condition associated with ovarian enlargement due to exogenous gonadotropin therapy. Symptoms include abdominal pain, distention, ascites, gastrointestinal problems, respiratory compromise, oliguria, and thromboembolism. It can occur during ovulation induction or in early pregnancies conceived through exogenous ovarian stimulation.
Predisposing factors for OHSS include multi-follicular ovaries (such as in PCOS), young age, high estradiol levels during ovulation induction, and pregnancy.
Vasoactive substances produced by the corpus luteum, such as vascular endothelial growth factor
(VEGF) and angiotensin II, are believed to contribute to enhanced capillary
permeability, resulting in the loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity and hemoconcentration.
Sonographic examination reveals enlarged ovaries with numerous follicular cysts and ascites.
Maintaining fluid balance with isotonic fluids like normal saline is crucial. Strategies to prevent OHSS during exogenous ovulation include reducing follicular stimulation (low FSH dose), coasting (withholding FSH administration one or more days prior to the hCG trigger), prophylactic volume expanders, and substituting hCG for FSH towards the end of ovarian stimulation.
Other options:
Option B: Theca lutein cysts are a rare form of follicular cysts characterized by luteinization and hypertrophy of the theca interna layer. Both ovaries are enlarged and cystic. This condition is commonly associated with gestational trophoblastic disease, multifetal gestation, and placentomegaly.
Option C: Polycystic ovarian syndrome shows 12 or more small follicles each 2-9 mm in size placed peripherally (necklace pattern) (shown below). The patient presents with menstrual
irregularities, hirsutism, acne, etc.

Solution to Question 14:
All patients with hyperprolactinaemia do not present with galactorrhoea.
Galactorrhoea is the secretion of milky fluid from the nipple which is unrelated to childbirth. Prolactin is the most important hormone involved in the pathophysiology of amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea. Majority of women (80%) with high prolactin levels present with galactorrhoea. However, some hyperprolactinemic women may not have this symptom.
Normal prolactin level is 25 ng/mL and levels more than this can cause galactorrhoea. Levels up to 100 ng/mL occur in hyperprolactinaemia but prolactin level over 100 ng/mL is seen in pituitary tumours.
Galactorrhoea is caused by pituitary adenoma and hyperprolactinemia. The condition is associated with amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea and infertility. The drug of choice for this condition is cabergoline.

Solution to Question 1:
Anencephaly is not seen in the case of accidental conception in a woman using the rhythm method. It occurs due to deficiency of folic acid in the mother.
The calendar method or the rhythm method is one of the natural methods of contraception by fertility awareness. The couple is advised avoidance of sexual intercourse around ovulation. Thus, it is very cost-effective but it can only be used by educated couples.
According to this method, safe period in a normal 28-day cycle is from the 1st day of menstrual period to the 10th day and from the 18th to the 28th day. An alternate method is by calculating the risk period i.e., 3 days before and 3 days after ovulation. Ovulation can also be estimated by changes in cervical mucus and basal body temperature.
Another method of calculating the safe period is the Knaus–Ogino method. The fertile period is determined by subtracting 18 days from the shortest cycle and 10 days from the longest cycle. This gives the first and the last day of the fertile period, respectively.
Solution to Question 2:
Billing’s method of contraception refers to the cervical mucus method. It is also called ovulation method.
The properties of the cervical mucus change during the menstrual cycle. The female partner can predict the fertile period by examining her cervical mucus.
Under the influence of estrogen, the mucus increases in quantity and becomes more slippery and elastic i.e. wet days. This continues till it reaches a peak. After this, under the influence of progesterone, it becomes thicker, scanty i.e. dry days.
Abstinence is advised during the wet days till 4 days after the peak day. The safe period includes the dry days after menses till the appearance of mucus and from the 4th day after the peak day.
The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below.

Solution to Question 3:
The given image shows a female condom. It consists of a pouch made of polyurethane which is 17 cm in length with a flexible ring at each end. The inner ring at the closed end is smaller than the outer ring.
The inner ring is inserted at the apex of the vagina and the outer ring remains outside. It covers the cervix, the entire vagina, and external genitalia. Hence, it provides protection against HIV and STDs. It has a failure rate of 5–15 per 100 woman-years, which is higher than that of a male condom.
It can be fitted by the patient hours before intercourse, and easily removed soon after. It covers the cervix, vagina, and external genitalia and is protective against sexually transmitted diseases. It can also be worn in the puerperal period, unlike the cervical diaphragm.
The female condom should not be used along with a male condom because if worn together they may slip, tear, or become displaced.

Solution to Question 4:
Today sponge contains 1 g of nonoxynol 9. It is a mushroom-shaped polyurethane disposable sponge that is 2 inches wide and 1.25 inches thick.
It is provided with a loop for easy removal. It should be placed high up in the vagina with the concave side covering the cervix. It can remain effective for 24 h. It can be used only once.
It acts as a mechanical barrier preventing the entry of sperms into the cervical canal, absorbs semen, and contains a spermicidal agent. The failure rate is 9-16 per 100 woman-years.

Solution to Question 5:
The given image shows a cervical diaphragm or Dutch cap. It can be used by women having multiple sex partners.
Contraindications of cervical diaphragm usage:
Prolapse, cystocele, rectocele - accurate fitting is not possible
Recurrent urinary tract infection
Allergy to rubber or spermicidal agent
It must be removed following intercourse as it can lead to toxic shock syndrome (TSS) if left in the vagina for a long period. TSS is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus
aureus infection.
Solution to Question 6:
Nonoxynol-9 is one of the spermicidal agents which act by disruption of the sperm cell membrane.
Spermicidal agents are chemical contraceptives as they contain surfactants, such as nonoxynol-9, octoxynol, menfegol and enzyme-inhibiting agents. These are available as:
Foam tablets
Soluble pessaries
Creams
Jellies
Films
The spermicidal agent remains effective for 1–2 hours after the application. They are always used along with other contraceptives such as the diaphragm, cervical cap, and condom. When they are used alone, the failure rate is high i.e., 30 per 100 woman-years.
Chronic use of spermicides can cause vaginal irritation, abrasion, and ulceration. This increases the risk of HIV spread. Hence, spermicidal agents should not be recommended to HIV-positive couples.
Solution to Question 7:
Phexxi is a vaginal gel that contains lactic acid, citric acid, and potassium bitartrate.
Phexxi is a vaginal pH regulator which is a non-hormonal contraceptive. It works by maintaining vaginal pH within the range of 3.5 to 4.5. This acidic environment is inhospitable for sperms.
Phexxi comes in pre-filled vaginal applicators. A single dose must be applied before vaginal intercourse. If more than one act of vaginal intercourse occurs within one hour, an additional dose must be applied.

Solution to Question 8:
Mala-N is a combined oral contraceptive containing 0.15 mg levonorgestrel (LNG) and 0.03 mg ethinyl estradiol. It is supplied free of cost through all PHC's, urban family welfare centers, etc.
All combined oral pills contain a mixture of ethinyl estradiol in a dose of 20-30 mcg and an orally active progestogen. Mala-D has the same composition as Mala-N but is available at a price of Rs 3/- per packet.
Combined oral pill works by suppressing pituitary hormones, FSH, and LH peak which prevents ovulation. At the same time, progestogen causes atrophic changes in the endometrium and
prevents implantation.
Progestogen also acts on the cervical mucus making it thick and tenacious and impenetrable by sperms. It also interferes with tubal motility and alters tubal transport.
, so the fertilized egg reaches the uterine cavity before the endometrium is receptive for implantation.
These tablets are taken starting on the first day of the cycle for 21 days. A new course of tablets should be commenced 7 days after the cessation of the previous course. They should be taken at bedtime, preferably after a meal.
Solution to Question 9:
Norgestimate is one of the 3rd generation progesterone agents. All OCPs have the disadvantage of increasing the risk of venous thrombosis.
Third-generation progesterone agents are less androgenic and so reduce the occurrence of acne and hirsutism. They also have a lower risk of metabolic and cardiovascular disorders compared to the previous generation progesterone agents.
Benefits of combined pills:
Effective contraceptive
Useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhoea
Relieves dysmenorrhoea and premenstrual tension
Prevents anaemia by reducing the menstrual loss
Lower incidence of benign breast neoplasia (fibrocystic disease), functional ovarian cyst, ovarian and uterine malignancy
Reduced risk of PID - due to thick cervical mucus caused by progestogen, preventing the organisms from entering into the uterine cavity
Reduced incidence of ectopic pregnancy - due to suppression of ovulation and decreased risk of PID
Protects against rheumatoid arthritis
Reduces the risk of anorectal cancer
Useful in acne, PCOD, and endometriosis
Solution to Question 10:
Thyroid disorders like hypothyroidism are not a contraindication for OCP usage. Contraindications of OCPs:
Absolute contraindications -
Breast and genital cancers
Liver disease
History of thromboembolism
Cardiac abnormalities
Congenital hyperlipidemia
Undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding
Relative contraindications -
Age over 40 years, if smoker >35 years
Mild hypertension
Chronic renal disease
Epilepsy
Migraine
First 6 months of breastfeeding
Diabetes mellitus
Gallbladder disease
History of infrequent bleeding or amenorrhea
Solution to Question 11:
Sodium valproate is an inhibitor of CYP enzymes that are responsible for OCP metabolism. Thus, it does not lead to OCP failure.
Drugs leading to OCP failure are :
Rifampicin
Tetracyclines - interferes with enterohepatic circulation of estrogen
Phenytoin
Phenobarbitone
Antifungals
Cephalosporin
Ritonavir for HIV - interferes with absorption of OCP
Most of the anti-convulsants are enzyme inducers and hence increase the clearance of OCPs. This leads to OCP failure.
Solution to Question 12:
Minipills or progesterone-only pills (POP) do not kill sperm in the cervical canal. Progesterone-only pills act by thickening the cervical mucus (the main mechanism of all POPs
except cerazette) that inhibits penetration of sperms, inhibiting tubal motility, and suppressing ovulation.
Other advantages of POPs include a reduction in the incidence of pelvic inflammatory diseases and sexually transmitted diseases (due to thickened cervical mucus).
Due to the inhibition of tubal motility, the absolute risk of all pregnancies including ectopic pregnancy decreases, while the relative risk of ectopic pregnancy increases. But a previous history of ectopic pregnancy is not a contraindication for POP.
POPs do not affect clotting, lipid metabolism, and carbohydrate metabolism. So they can safely be used by women who are obese, breastfeeding, hypertensive, have SLE or a history of thromboembolism, diabetic with vascular disease. Significant adverse effects of POPs are irregular bleeding (mostly scanty), and secondary amenorrhea after longtime usage as it causes endometrial atrophy.
Contraindications for POPs include undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, pregnancy, known or suspected breast cancer, and benign or malignant liver tumors.
Solution to Question 13:
Centchroman is a non-hormonal oral contraceptive that is started at a dose of 30 mg on the first day of the menstrual cycle. It can be given to women with a family history of breast cancer where hormonal contraceptives are contraindicated.
Centchroman or ormeloxifene is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive. Following the initial dose of 30 mg on the first day of menses, it is taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter. It prevents implantation through endometrial changes. The return of fertility occurs within 6 months of stopping the drug.
It can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in 60 mg dose within 24 hours of coitus. It has a failure rate of 1.83 per 100 woman years. It does not provide protection against HIV and other STDs.
Side effects of centchroman:
Headache, nausea, vomiting
Weight gain
Delay in return of fertility (up to 6 months)
Atypical endometrial hyperplasia - prolonged use Contraindications of centchroman:
PCOD
Hepatic dysfunction
Cervical dysplasia
Allergy to the drug
This drug has been developed by Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow. It has been released in India under the name of Chhaya (previously called Saheli) under the National Family Planning
Programme.

Solution to Question 14:
The most effective reversible method of contraception among the given options is Norplant, which is a subdermal hormonal implant.
The most effective method of contraception overall is sterilization, which is one of the permament methods. Both methods belong to the first-tier category of contraceptives.
There are 2 types of subdermal implants:
Implanon (which has replaced Norplant I)
Norplant II
The implants work by inhibition of ovulation, endometrial atrophy, and thickening of cervical mucus. Implanon contains desogestrel and also reduces acne and osteoporosis.
The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days of insertion.

The image given below shows the insertion of a subdermal implant:

Advantages of implants:
Long-acting with sustained effect
Good compliance
Coital-independent with no nuisance of daily oral or frequent injections
Failure rate - 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman-years
Implanon reduces acne and osteoporosis. Disadvantages of implants:
Breakthrough bleeding
Irregular cycles
Amenorrhoea
Ectopic pregnancy
Local infection
Requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules
Expensive.
Solution to Question 15:
The given image shows Multiload Cu250, which is one of the copper containing IUCDs. Formation of cervical mucus plug is not one of its mechanisms of action. However, progesterone-containing IUCDs can alter the cervical mucus along with the local effects.
The various mechanisms of action of a copper-containing IUCD are:
Interference with the migration of spermatozoa
Foreign body reaction releasing prostaglandins - provokes uterine contractility and increases the tubal peristalsis which interferes with implantation
Leucocytic infiltration in the endometrium - macrophages engulf the fertilized egg if it enters the endometrial tissue
Enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrial tissue which interferes with implantation of the fertilized ovum
Some IUCDs like CuT-380A are effective for up to 10 years.
They are a good choice of method of contraception for the following groups of women:
Having low risk of STD
Multiparous woman
Having a monogamous relationship
Wanting long-term reversible method of contraception
Unreliable users of oral contraception or barrier contraception
IUCDs are avoided in unmarried and nulliparous patients because of the risk of PID and subsequent tubal infertility. Copper IUCDs can also be used as emergency contraception following intercourse.
Solution to Question 16:
IUCDs can be used in HIV-affected women.
Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) provide long-term contraception by preventing fertilization.
Contraindications for IUCD insertion:
Suspected pregnancy
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
Lower genital tract infection
Presence of fibroids
Severe anaemia
Uncontrolled diabetes - due to increased pelvic infection
Scarred uterus eg, post caesarean section
Septate uterus
Menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea - if Copper T is used
Breast cancer - if LNG IUCD is used Complications of IUCD usage:
Immediate -
Vasovagal attack
Uterine cramps
Early -
Expulsion of IUCD
Perforation of uterus
Spotting, menorrhagia
Dysmenorrhoea
Vaginal infection
Actinomycosis
Late -
PID
Ectopic pregnancy
Perforation of uterus
Menorrhagia
Dysmenorrhoea
The failure rate of IUCD is 1–3 per 100 woman-years.
Levonorgestrel IUCD also causes hormonal adverse effects such as headache, acne, breast tenderness, and functional ovarian cysts. Amenorrhoea occurs in 35% of women after 2 years of use.
Solution to Question 17:
Nova-T contains both copper and silver. The addition of the silver increases its effective lifespan.

In copper-carrying devices, copper wire is wrapped around the vertical stem of a polypropylene frame. Some of them have copper wire wrapped around the arms too. Based on the surface area, they are of various types:
Copper T 380 A
Multiload copper 250
Copper T 200
Copper 7
Copper T 220
Nova-T
They are effective for 3–5 years. It is estimated that about 50 mcg of copper is eluted daily in the uterus. Copper T 380A, known as Paraguard, has a lifespan of 10 years. Nova T has a lifespan of 5 years.

Solution to Question 18:
Progestasert releases 65 g of progesterone/day.
Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in a silicon oil reservoir in the vertical stem. The progesterone released causes the formation of a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os. This prevents entry of the sperms in addition to the local contraceptive effect of IUCDs.
There is lesser incidence of menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea compared to copper-containing intrauterine devices. However, it is expensive and requires yearly replacement.
Solution to Question 19:
Copper IUCDs increase the risk of PID.
OCPs, Mirena and DMPA injectables contain progesterone which causes thickening of the cervical mucus and decreases the motility of the female genital tract. Thus, they reduce the risk of PID by preventing the ascent of bacteria from the vagina.
Solution to Question 20:
IUCDs are the most effective mode of contraception for women with heart diseases. IUCDs are safe in these patients and come under the first-tier contraceptive methods.
Condoms are not contraindicated in heart disease patients but they are third-tier contraceptives. Hence, they are not as effective as IUCDs.
OCPs and hormonal implants are contraindicated in patients with heart diseases as the constituent hormones can cause thromboembolic disorders.
Solution to Question 21:
Essure permanent device is a method of hysteroscopic sterilization. Pomeroy, Parkland, and Irving procedures are methods for tubal ligation via an abdominal approach.
Essure device consists of a micro-inserter with a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel titanium alloy (nitinol).
This device is inserted into the fallopian tube by hysteroscopy. It acts by benign local fibrous tissue growth leading to occlusion of the tube. The failure rate is 3.5%.
Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and the procedure can be done under local anaesthesia.
Disadvantages of Essure:
Hysteroscopy required for the procedure and to confirm the blockage
Expensive procedure
Expertise required
Irreversible - tuboplasty for reversal not possible

Solution to Question 22:
Isthmus of the fallopian tube is ligated in Pomeroy technique. It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation.
Midline, paramedian or transverse abdominal incision is made 2 inches above the pubic symphysis (1 inch in puerperal sterilisation). The fallopian tube is identified, made into a loop and tied at the base. The loop is then excised.
The operation is simple and requires a short period of hospitalization. The failure rate is only 0.4% and it is mainly due to spontaneous canalization. It is surgically reversible.
The below image shows Pomeroy’s method of tubal ligation.

Solution to Question 23:
Fimbriectomy is also known as Kroener's procedure. This procedure involves ligation of the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures. Then, resection of the infundibulum of the tube is done.

Some more techniques of permanent sterilization include:
Pomeroy method - The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision. The middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. This is the most commonly used technique.

Uchida's method - The tubal serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube. The muscle layer is excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. This minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

Irving's procedure - The mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the intervening portion is excised. The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament. It is a reliable method but irreversible and may require a laparotomy incision.

Madlener's procedure - A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.

Solution to Question 24:
The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15%
This procedure is done under local anaesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens are divided on both sides which disrupts the passage of sperms.
The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps and skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting.
The sperms can remain in the reproductive tract for up to 3 months. Hence, sterility is not immediate. The couple must abstain from intercourse during this period or use other methods of contraception.
Approximately, 20 ejaculates clear the semen of all sperms. Two semen analysis reports must confirm the absence of sperms before the man can be declared sterile.

Solution to Question 25:
Emergency contraceptives do not interrupt early pregnancy, once conception has occured. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. Hence, they are also
called interceptives.
The main action of emergency contraceptives is to make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg by sperms.
Methods of emergency contraception:
Drug

Solution to Question 26:
Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg can be used as a single dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.
Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. The tablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in interval between coitus and drug intake.
LNG prevents ovulation and makes endometrium unsuitable for implantation. The failure rate is 1.1%. If pregnancy occurs as a result of contraceptive failure, the risk of ectopic pregnancy increases but it is not teratogenic.
Advantages of LNG:
No oestrogen and its associated side effects
Can be used in hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic patients
Suitable for lactating woman
Can be given up to 120 hours after the unprotected intercourse
Single-dose therapy Contraindications of LNG:
Liver disease
Thrombophlebitis
Migraine
Galactose allergy - as the tablet contains lactose
Solution to Question 27:
The dose of ulipristal is 30 mg tablet and it should be taken within 5 days of intercourse.
Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor and acts by:
Preventing/delaying ovulation
Suppressing endometrial and follicular growth
Inhibiting implantation
Side effects are headaches and mood changes. It is contraindicated in women with severe hepatic dysfunction and severe asthma.
Note: The use of ulipristal for the treatment of fibroids has been discontinued due to the increased incidence of severe liver injury.

Solution to Question 1:
Caucasian race is not a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis. The risk factors for bacterial vaginosis are:
Oral sex
Vaginal douching
African race
Cigarette smoking
Sex during menses
Intrauterine device
Early age of sexual intercourse
New or multiple sexual partners
Sexual activity with other women
Note: Bacterial vaginosis is not an infection. It most commonly affects young women. Although it is not a sexually transmitted disease, the chances of developing bacterial vaginosis seem to increase with the number of sexual partners that a woman has had.
Solution to Question 2:
Vaginal itching is not seen in bacterial vaginosis. It is a symptom of Trichomonas vaginitis.
About half of the women having bacterial vaginosis are asymptomatic. Symptomatic women mostly present with a profuse, fishy vaginal discharge. It does not cause pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia.
Option A: Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the absence of lactobacilli. This causes an increase in the growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Myco- plasma□ hominis.
Option B: Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. 3 out of 4 criteria are needed to make a positive diagnosis.
Option D: Oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or oral clindamycin 300 mg twice daily for 7 days is given for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. Treatment remains the same in pregnancy.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella.
Patients with BV have profuse and yellowish vaginal discharge with a fishy odour. It is adherent to the vaginal mucosa. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are absent. On microscopy, clue cells are visible.
Option A: In trichomonas vaginitis, the vaginal discharge is frothy, greenish-yellow and has an offensive smell. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are generally present.
Option B: In candidal vaginitis, the discharge is thick and curdy white.
Option D: In chlamydial infection, the vaginal discharge is generally scanty.
Solution to Question 4:
An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is not an inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora.
A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organisms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen.
Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

Solution to Question 5:
The presence of clue cells on microscopy is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis.
A swab of the vaginal discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation of the smear is done on a gram stained smear. It would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organisms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen.
Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

A homogeneous, thin, greyish-white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.

Urethra

Non-gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is:

The most sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis of chlamydial cervicitis is the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It is fast, highly sensitive and specific (96%).
Solution to Question 21:
Chlamydia trachomatis is the most likely causative organism. This is suggested by the presence of characteristic iodine-stained inclusion bodies in the McCoy cell culture of the patient's endocervical sample.
Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus. The gram stain of the cervical smear would show abundant leucocytes but no organisms.
The nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is currently done for the diagnosis of lymphogranuloma venereum.
Solution to Question 22:
A single dose of 1 g of azithromycin is given and contact tracing is done to treat a patient diagnosed with a chlamydial infection.
Treatment of chlamydial infection:
Azithromycin 1 g single dose (or)
Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID × 7 days (or)
Ofloxacin 200 mg orally BID × 7 days (or)
Erythromycin 500 mg orally BID × 7 days
Contact tracing should always be done. The sexual partner should also be treated with the same regimen.
Solution to Question 23:
The clinical history of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The first and the only non-azole antifungal approved for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis is Ibrexafungerp. The route of administration of this drug is oral.
Ibrexafungerp is a triterpenoid antifungal agent that acts by inhibiting glucan synthase. Glucan synthase is an enzyme involved in the formation of 1,3-beta-D-glucan which is an essential component of the fungal cell wall.
The recommended dosage is 600 mg orally as 2 divided doses 12 hrs apart. Contraindications include pregnancy and hypersensitivity to ibrexafungerp. The most frequent adverse reactions are diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, dizziness, and vomiting.

Solution to Question 1:
The causative agent of vulval warts is the human papillomavirus (HPV).
Genital warts/venereal warts/condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favoured by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.
HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, as shown below.

The diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The abnormal areas of the skin retain the blue dye. These areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.
The given image below shows condyloma acuminata:

Solution to Question 2:
The given image is suggestive of condyloma acuminata that shows cauliflower-like masses of tissue on and around the female anogenital region.
Condyloma acuminatum is an epidermal manifestation of the human papillomavirus (HPV).
HPV is transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosa. The virus invades the cells of the epidermal basal layer through microabrasions. However, anogenital HPV infection is almost always acquired through sexual contact.
Warts are not required for transmission but are highly infectious because of their high viral load.
Option B: The image given below shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with a characteristic dimple at the centre. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum caused by the pox virus.

Option C: The image given below shows firm papules with a rough horny surface. These are seen in verruca vulgaris caused by the human papillomavirus type 2.

Option D: The image given below shows condyloma lata which is the characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum.

Solution to Question 3:
The given image shows koilocytes, a characteristic feature of infection with human papillomavirus
(HPV).
Other features that can also be seen on histology are:
Perinuclear halo
Multinucleation
Orangeophilic cytoplasm
Acanthosis
Chronic inflammatory infiltrate
Option A: Henderson-Paterson bodies are seen in molluscum contagiosum, caused by poxvirus. Option C and D: Cowdry bodies are seen in herpes infection.

It is called Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months.
Gardasil/Silgard is the quadrivalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16 and 18 and is given at 0, 2 and 6 months.
Gardasil 9 is the nonavalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and

Solution to Question 6:
The characteristic feature associated with primary syphilis is firm, shotty, painless nodes that do not suppurate.
Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the motile spirochete, Treponema pallidum. In primary syphilis, the classical lesion i.e., chancre appears within 9–90 days from the first exposure.
The macular lesion becomes papular and then ulcerates. The ulcer(s) is painless and firm, with a punched out base and rolled edges. If left unattended, these heal within 3–9 weeks. It is accompanied by painless inguinal discrete lymphadenopathy.

The given image shows condyloma lata, a classic finding of secondary syphilis.
Multiple moist well-demarcated papules and plaques are seen in condyloma lata. They are highly contagious, exophytic broad excrescences that ulcerate and are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area and upper thighs.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rectal stricture which is a complication of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).
LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1/L2/L3). Rectal involvement is commonly seen in women as the primary disease often goes unnoticed and untreated. Anorectal involvement causes proctocolitis and causes rectal strictures. This occurs due to the contiguous spread of the primary infection from the perirectal nodes leading to scar tissue formation.
The complications of lymphogranuloma venereum include:

Rectovaginal fistulae
Proctitis
Vulvar cancer.
Solution to Question 12:
The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calymmatobacterium granulomatis. It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causing chronic ulcerative infection of the vulva.
It is highly contagious and transmitted through repeated sexual or non-sexual contact. The incubation period is 1-12 weeks.
Clinical features:
It begins as a painless nodule which later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers that tend to coalesce; the vulva is progressively destroyed, and minimal adenopathy may occur.
Diagnosis:
Microscopic examination of smears from the lesion/ biopsy specimens reveals pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies and clusters of bacteria with a bipolar (safety pin) appearance.
B ue-black stained organisms are seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear cells. Management:
Azithromycin 1 g orally once per week or 500 mg daily for at least 3 weeks and until all lesions have completely healed.
The given image below shows the donovanosis in a female patient with a beefy red ulcer:

Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granuloma inguinale which is caused by a gram-negative bacteria, Klebsiella granulomatis.
Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce and bleed easily on contact. If secondarily infected, they may become painful. The ulcers heal by fibrosis, which can result in scarring resembling keloids.
The lymph nodes are usually uninvolved but can become enlarged. New lesions can appear along the lymphatic drainage channels.
The gross image below shows granuloma inguinale of the cervix with a beefy red appearance of the hypervascular intravaginal tissues.

The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.

Solution to Question 1:
The organism seen in the given image of a Pap smear is the Doderlien’s bacillus, also known as Lactobacillus. This is a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus that grows in anaerobic conditions.
It is a part of the normal vaginal flora that is responsible for the vaginal defence mechanism. It is an estrogen-dependent bacillus and appears at puberty and disappears after menopause.
It converts glycogen into lactic acid and maintains the acidic ph in the vagina. This prevents the growth of pathogenic bacteria in the vagina. Its absence causes a condition called bacterial vaginosis where pathogenic organisms replaces the normal flora of the vagina. In this condition, clue cells are visible.
Option B: Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common organism involved in bacterial vaginosis. As the patient in the given question is healthy, this is not the correct option.
Option C: Trichomonas vaginalis is flagellated protozoa that causes trichomonas vaginitis. The organism and the nucleus of epithelial cells appear equal in size on the pap smear. This criterion is used for the identification of trichomonas as flagella are not visible on a pap smear.
Option D: Frisch bacillus is another name for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It is not seen on Pap smears.
Solution to Question 2:
Pregnancy is not a risk factor for PID. Instead, it plays a protective role in this condition.
The risk factors for developing PID are:
Unprotected sexual intercourse
Having multiple sex partners
Previous history of PID
IUD insertion
Early age of sexual intercourse (<18years)
The protective factors for PID are:
Pregnancy
Using barrier contraception like condoms, diaphragms
Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
Menopause
Solution to Question 3:
Cervicitis is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
Pelvic inflammatory disease is a spectrum of infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, typically causing:
Endometritis
Salpingitis
Oophoritis
Peritonitis
The minimum criteria for diagnosis of PID are:
Pain in the lower abdomen + any one of the following:
Uterine tenderness
Cervical motion tenderness
Adnexal tenderness
Cervicitis and vaginitis are lower genital tract infections.
Solution to Question 4:
The most common symptom of acute PID is bilateral lower abdominal pain.
The pain is severe in acute stages and it may or may not be accompanied by a high temperature ( >38.3 degrees C). It may be followed by vomiting.
Some patients with PID can present with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. This is seen in Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome which is a form of perihepatitis.
If PID occurs due to sexually transmitted organisms, dysuria and vaginal discharge may be seen.
Solution to Question 5:
Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of PID.
PID is an infection of the upper genital tract. It is generally transmitted sexually as an ascending infection along with sperms. It is usually a polymicrobial infection,
Organisms causing PID include:
Sexually transmitted:
Chlamydia (most common)
Gonococcus
Mycoplasma
Trichomonas Pyogenic Aerobes:
Staphylococci
Streptococci
E Coli Anaerobes:
Bacteroides fragilis
Peptostreptococcus
Clostridium
Actinomyces (most common in IUD users) Other:
Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Note: Genital tuberculosis is the only PID that does not spread sexually. It has a hematogenous spread. Thus, it is the most common PID in virgin girls.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of PID in an IUCD user. The most common organism causing this condition is Actinomyces. It has been reported in 7% of IUCD users if the device is worn for more than 2 years.
This emphasizes the need for strict asepsis during insertion of the device and the need for strict follow up of women wearing these devices.

Clostridium
