Solution to Question 7:
The mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatory disease is mucosal.
Gonococci ascend to the tubes mainly through mucosal continuity. This is facilitated by sexually transmitted vectors such as sperms and Trichomonas.
The mucous membranes of the fallopian tubes are affected first. They become edematous and are infiltrated with leukocytes and plasma cells. Another route of spread is through the reflux of mucosal blood.
Option A: Hematogenous spread is seen in genital tuberculosis.
Option B: Lymphatics are involved in the spread of secondary organisms and in PID following post-abortal and puerperal infection.
Option C: Parametrium facilitates the spread of Mycoplasma. The gut flora can directly spread to tubes.
Solution to Question 8:
Among the given options, chlamydial infection causes the most amount of damage to the mucosa and the wall of the fallopian tubes leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage.
Chlamydial infection can remain asymptomatic in the endo-cervix. Hence, the infection goes unnoticed and untreated. Thus, it can lead to more damage and complications.
Gonococcal infection is more symptomatic than chlamydial infection. Hence, it is diagnosed early and causes less damage to the tubes than chlamydial infection.
Mycoplasma and Mobiluncus generally cause lower genital tract infections like cervicitis and vaginitis.
Solution to Question 9:
Pelvic endometriosis is not a differential diagnosis of acute PID. It is a differential diagnosis of chronic PID.
Differential diagnosis of acute PID:
Acute appendicitis
Septic abortion
Cholecystitis
Twisted ovarian cyst
Ectopic pregnancy
Diverticulitis
Ruptured endometriotic cyst Differential diagnosis of chronic PID:
Uterine fibroids
Pelvic endometriosis
Ovarian tumou
Tubercular tubo-ovarian mass
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario of development of a chronic tubo-ovarian mass following acute PID points towards a diagnosis of chronic PID. A chronic tubo-ovarian mass can manifest as a tubo-ovarian cyst, hydrosalpinx or even a chronic pyosalpinx.
Failure to complete treatment of acute PID or drug resistance can lead to the development of chronic PID. This can lead to the development of chronic tubo-ovarian masses which may manifest as:
Hydrosalpinx
Chronic pyosalpinx
Chronic interstitial salpingitis
Tubo-ovarian cyst
Tuberculous form
A twisted ovarian cyst and a ruptured endometriotic cyst are differential diagnoses of acute PID.
Solution to Question 11:
The above image depicts a hydrosalpinx. Its wall is not opaque but translucent.
If a pyosalpinx responds to antibiotics, the pus present inside becomes sterile within 6 weeks of the initial attack. However, the damage to the tube remains as chronic pyosalpinx or hydrosalpinx. A hydrosalpinx represents the end result of previous acute salpingitis and is often bilateral.
The tube becomes retort shaped due to the enormous dilatation of the ampullary region that is filled with clear fluid.
Histological examination shows a flattening of the tubal plicae and exfoliation of the lining epithelium.
Solution to Question 12:
Bilateral abdominal pain is not included in the criteria to diagnose PID. Bilateral abdominal pain is a clinical symptom of PID.
Lower abdominal tenderness is included in the criteria to diagnose PID. CDC criteria for the diagnosis of PID:
Definitive criteria:
Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy
Imaging study (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess)
Laparoscopic evidence of PID Minimum criteria:
Cervical motion tenderness
Uterine tenderness
Adnexal tenderness Additional criteria:
Oral temperature >38.3 oC
Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge, cervical friability
Raised ESR or CRP
Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia
Solution to Question 13:
A temperature of more than 38.3°C is an additional criterion and not a definitive criterion for the diagnosis of PID.
CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID:
Definitive criteria:
Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy
Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (Tubo-ovarian abscess)
Laparoscopic evidence of PID Minimum criteria:
Lower abdominal tenderness
Adnexal tenderness
Cervical motion tenderness Additional criteria:
Oral temperature>38.3C
Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
Raised ESR or CRP
Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario is likely to be acute PID. Laparoscopy is the gold standard to confirm acute PID.
Laparoscopy is not done routinely as it is an invasive procedure. It is reserved for only cases where the differential diagnosis is salpingitis, appendicitis, ectopic pregnancy or a case of a non-responding pelvic mass.
The diagnosis of PID is mostly clinical. If diagnosis is unclear, the investigation of choice for PID is USG and culdocentesis.
CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID:
Definitive criteria:
Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy
Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess)

Adnexal tenderness
Cervical motion tenderness Additional criteria:
Oral temperature>38.3C
Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
Raised ESR or CRP
Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia
Solution to Question 15:
Gainesville stage III includes two forms of PID - acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex.
Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage as follows:
Stage
Condition
Stage I
Acute salpingitis without peri tonitis - no adhesions
Stage I I
Acute salpingitis with periton itis - purulent discharge
Stage I II
Acute salpingitis with superi mposed tubal occlusion or tu bo-ovarian complex
Stage I V

Solution to Question 16:
The image shows the laparoscopic finding of violin string adhesions that are characteristic of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. It is a form of perihepatitis that occurs in the setting of PID.
It is characterized by right upper quadrant pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder. It rarely occurs in women with acute PID. The pathological mechanism is as follows:
Gonococcal / Chlamydial infection  transperitoneal/vascular spread  inflammation of the liver capsule and peritoneal surfaces  adhesions and fibrosis in the perihepatic region 
Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome
Cholecystitis and ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess are the differential diagnoses of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. Violin string adhesions would not be seen in these conditions.
Solution to Question 17:
Dysmenorrhea rarely occurs in PID. Pain is uncommon and is a result of subacute PID.
Silent PID is thought to follow multiple or continuous low-grade infections in asymptomatic women. It is not a clinical diagnosis. Rather, it is an ultimate diagnosis given to women with tubal-factor infertility who lack a history of upper genital tract infection.
On laparoscopy or laparotomy, these women may have evidence of prior tubal infection such as adhesions, but for the most part, the fallopian tubes are grossly normal. They can have ectopic pregnancies due to tubal dysmotility. Silent PID can occur following infection with M. tuberculosis.
Solution to Question 18:
Administration of cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours forms the crux of the treatment regimen for PID. This is followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg
+/-metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days in all hospitalized patients having PID. Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients:
Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours is given followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days
Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route.
Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia. Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines):
A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/-
metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days
A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks.
IUD is not removed in a woman who responds to antibiotics. It is removed only in case of a failed antibiotic response. Barrier contraceptives and OCPs are recommended only in women unresponsive to antibiotics.
The use of Placentrex (aqueous extract of the placenta) is outdated and is not recommended currently.
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical scenario of fever and lower abdominal pain associated with lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of PID. The best treatment option for this patient is
outpatient treatment with a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD
+/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days.
Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines):
A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days
A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks. Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients:
Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours is given followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days
Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route.
Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.
Solution to Question 20:
Intestinal obstruction would be an indication for surgery in a patient diagnosed with PID. Criteria for surgery in PID include:
Drainage of pelvic abscess by colpotomy.
Dilatation and evacuation of septic products of conception or for haemorrhage in the postabortal period.
Acute spreading peritonitis resistant to a full course of chemotherapy. Presence of pyoperitoneum mandates laparotomy.
Intestinal obstruction
Suspected intestinal injury as diagnosed in criminal abortion.
Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
A tubo-ovarian abscess of 2 cm is not an indication for surgery. Minimally invasive surgery is done in a tubo-ovarian abscess measuring more than 10 cm, that fails to respond to antibiotics in 48-72 hours.
Peritonitis and sepsis are not an indication for surgery. They should be managed medically first. If they do not respond to antibiotic treatment then surgical management should be done.
Solution to Question 21:
If the abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48–72 h, minimally invasive surgery is indicated. Criteria for minimally invasive surgery in PID:
The size of the abscess is more than 10 cm
The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48-72 hours
The abscess ruptures
Pyoperitoneum
Minimal invasive surgery includes laparoscopic drainage of the tubo ovarian abscess or posterior colpotomy.
Solution to Question 22:
The treatment of choice for an old multiparous woman with chronic PID is abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
A radical hysterectomy involves the removal of the whole uterus, tissue from the sides of the uterus, the cervix, and the upper part of the vagina. It is generally done only in cancer patients.
A supracervical hysterectomy involves the removal of only the body of the uterus and is not done in chronic PID. It is done for the treatment of endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and uterine prolapse.
Solution to Question 23:
Boer-Meisel has described the prognostic evaluation for PID. It depends upon the following:
Extent of adhesions
Nature of adhesions such as flimsy or dense.
Size of hydrosalpinx
Macroscopic condition of hydrosalpinx.
The thickness of the tubal wall.
Boer-Meisel system is specifically used for predicting pregnancy outcomes in patients treated for PID.
Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage.
Westrom has reported that women with one previous attack of PID have a predisposition to another attack.
Stages of PID
Stage I
Acute salpingitis without peri tonitis - no adhesions
Stage I I
Acute salpingitis with periton itis- purulent discharge
Stage I II
Acute salpingitis with superi mposed tubal occlusion or tu bo-ovarian complex
Stages of PID
Stages of PID
Stage I V
Ruptured tubo-ovarian absce ss
Stage V
Tuberculous salpingitis
Solution to Question 24:
Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to pyometra. This refers to the collection of pus in the uterine cavity.
The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. Unilateral pain and swelling over the labia may be caused by the inflammation of the Bartholin glands.
Depending on the extent of tissue involved, PID can be classified into five stages
Stage I - Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - No adhesions
Stage II - Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent discharge
Stage III - Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo ovarian complex
Stage IV - Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
Stage V - Tubercular salpingitis
Long-standing pelvic inflammation may also lead to:
Dyspareunia
Infertility
Ectopic pregnancy
Formation of adhesions like hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, tubo-ovarian abscess
Chronic pelvic pain
Note: Chronic pelvic inflammation leads to dense adhesions between the uterus and the appendages. Thus, it becomes difficult to define the uterus from the pelvic masses. They form a hard mass which is called the frozen pelvis.
The most common cause of the spread of PID: Ascending infection along with sperms
The only PID that does not spread with the sexual route is genital TB. It has a hematogenous spread.
The most common PID in virgin females is genital TB. Investigation of choice in PID: Abdominal USG
The surest sign of salpingitis is pus extruding from the fimbrial end of the tube.

Solution to Question 2:
Endometrial tuberculosis is most commonly acquired by direct spread from the fallopian tubes. Hematogenous spread is thought to be the process by which the tubercle bacilli implant into the mucosa of the fallopian tubes and subsequently affect the endometrium by direct extension.
Female genital tuberculosis is an important cause of significant morbidity, short and long-term sequelae especially infertility. Genital tuberculosis usually occurs secondary to pulmonary (commonest) or extrapulmonary TB like gastrointestinal, renal, skeletal, and miliary TB. However, primary genital TB can rarely occur in women whose male partners have active genitourinary TB
(e.g., tuberculosis epididymitis) by transmission through infected semen
Most common site involved in secondary genital TB is fallopian tube (90-100%) >endometrium (50-80%) >ovaries (20-30%) >cervix 5-15%) >vulva. The most common symptom of genital TB is infertility.
Causes of infertility in genital TB:
Tubal blockage
If tubes are patent, then also infertility occurs due to loss of tubal function.
Tubercular endometritis causes uterine scarring resulting in the destruction of the endometrium.
Ovarian damage with poor ovarian reserve and volume
A laparoscopy and dye hydrotubation (lap and dye test) is the most reliable tool to diagnose genital TB, especially for tubal, ovarian and peritoneal disease. The test can be combined with hysteroscopy.
Multiple drug therapy ( ATT regimen provided by DOTS) in adequate doses and for sufficient duration is the mainstay in the treatment of TB including genital tuberculosis.
Solution to Question 3:
Genital tuberculosis is a bilateral condition.
It can be caused by both Mycobacterium tuberculosis (95% cases) and Mycobacterium bovis (5% cases). It almost always occurs secondary to a primary focus elsewhere in the body. The most common primary focus is lungs > lymph nodes > abdomen > generalised miliary infection.
It mostly spreads hematogenously. Lymphatic spread is also seen sometimes. It can rarely spread by direct contact with the affected intraabdominal organs or peritoneum.
The fallopian tubes are the first to be affected. The disease subsequently spreads to other genital organs and the peritoneum. This is followed by the involvement of bilateral pelvic lymph nodes. Vulvovaginal involvement is usually secondary to uterine involvement.
The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility.
Solution to Question 4:
The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility.
Genital tuberculosis mostly presents in young women in the reproductive age group. It can present as:
Infertility is the only complaint in 35-60 % of cases. Of these, 75% of women present with primary infertility.
Menstrual abnormalities are seen in 10-40% of cases.
Asymptomatic in 10% of cases.
Other symptoms like fever and malaise can be seen.
The treatment of infertility in women with genital TB depends on the condition of the endometrium. If the endometrium is receptive and the uterus is normal, then assisted reproductive techniques such as in-vitro fertilisation can be tried. If the endometrium is unfavourable then surrogacy may be considered.
Solution to Question 5:
The fimbriae are often spared even in advanced forms of tubercular salpingitis.
The involvement of fallopian tubes is 100% and bilateral, secondary to hematogenous spread. The ampullary part of the tube appears dilated with the fimbrial end open and pouting. This gives the characteristic tobacco-pouch appearance as seen in the image below.

The external surface of the tubes are enlarged, roughened, and may show the presence of greyish tubercles. The cut section shows yellowish-grey caseous matter in the lumen. Sometimes, serosanguinous fluid can also be seen in the lumen of the fallopian tube. This is called tuberculous hematosalpinx.
On histopathological examination of the tubes, granulomas and chronic inflammatory infiltrate with hyperplasia is seen. This could be mistaken for malignancy as it also produces a similar histological image.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario with abdominal pain, amenorrhoea, pelvic mass and ascites is suggestive of genital tuberculosis.
Genital tuberculosis:
It is caused by M. tuberculosis and almost always occurs secondary to primary infection elsewhere in the extragenital states. The sites and frequency of involvement are as follows:
Fallopian tubes (90-100%)
Endometrium (50-60%)
Ovaries (20-30%)
Cervix (5-15%)
Vulva and vagina (< 1%)
Presentation is variable and it can be asymptomatic in 10-20% of cases, infertility, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain and mass, vaginal discharge, fistula formation, ectopic pregnancy and ascites. The mass is made up of rolled-up omentum that is adherent to the uterus and adnexa.
Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weakness, anorexia or night sweats may be present. Investigations:
CBC, ESR and Mantoux test
Hysterosalpingography shows a lead-pipe appearance of the fallopian tube, calcification of the tube, beading and variation in the filling, cornual block, jagged fluffiness of tubal outline and tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx.
Laparoscopy establishes the diagnosis of genital TB. It shows tuberculous lesions and perihepatic adhesions (if present).
Differential diagnosis:
Ovarian cyst, broad ligament cyst or encysted fluid
Pelvic inflammatory disease
Ectopic pregnancy
Carcinoma cervix
Elephantiasis of the vulva
Pregnancy
Puberty menorrhagia and postmenopausal bleeding
Fungal infection and sarcoidosis Management:
It is treated with anti-tubercular therapy for 6 months (DOT strategy): Indications and contraindications for surgery:
Types of surgery include vulvectomy (if vulval hypertrophy is present), removal of the adnexal mass, drainage of pyometra and fistula repair.
TAH+BSO is rarely required nowadays. Tuboplasty is contraindicated.
Option B: Ovarian tumors usually don't affect menstrual cycles. Though virilizing tumors can cause amenorrhoea, other features of virilization such as hirsutism, flattening of breasts, and enlargement of the clitoris are generally present.
Option C: Though ectopic pregnancy may be suspected here, the tube is likely to rupture with exacerbation of pain, bleeding, and peritonitis before six months of gestation. Additionally, the absence of vaginal bleeding/spotting, and the presence of weight loss makes the diagnosis unlikely.
Option D: Submucous fibroid is associated with menorrhagia.

Solution to Question 7:
The Quantiferon test will be positive in patients having genital TB. It is an indicator of latent tuberculosis. The Quantiferon test measures the release of interferon-gamma by T cells following stimulation by antigens unique to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
A differential WBC count shows lymphocytosis at all stages of genital tuberculosis. The ESR is frequently raised and is a non-specific investigation at any stage of the disease. None of these tests can be used for confirmation as these markers are raised in many infections.
The Mantoux test is positive in 90% of cases of genital TB. It is indicative of past exposure to the tubercle bacilli. It is not a confirmatory investigation but a negative result indicates tuberculosis to be unlikely.
Solution to Question 8:
A wedge-shaped defect is not suggestive of tubercular salpingitis. It is seen at the uterine isthmus in patients with a history of Cesarean section with a uterine scar.
Hysterosalpingography (HSG) features of genital tuberculosis are:
Lead pipe appearance due to rigid nonperistaltic pipe-like tube
Beading and variation in filling defect
Calcification of the tube
Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
Rosette type appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular like outpouching surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration.
HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes.
The investigation of choice in genital tuberculosis is an endometrial biopsy. The tubercle bacilli are present in the deeper layers of the endometrium. They come to the surface just before menstruation. Hence, an endometrial biopsy is done 1 or 2 days before menstruation.
Menstrual blood can also be used for detecting mycobacteria.
An HSG showing the features of tuberculous salpingitis is given below.

Solution to Question 9:
The given image shows bilateral hydrosalpinx. It appears as a thin-walled structure.
A hydrosalpinx is a chronic cystic swelling of the fallopian tube that forms after a distal tubal obstruction. The tubes are enormously distended due to filling with clear serous fluid and become retort-shaped. On histology, the tubal plicae appear flattened. The interstitial end of the
tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during HSG.
It is caused due to:
Pelvic inflammatory disease
Endometriosis
Tuberculosis - tubercular salpingitis may also cause tobacco-pouch appearance, lead pipe appearance and pyosalpinx
Fallopian tube neoplasms (rare)
It can be an incidental finding during a pelvic exam or ultrasound. The patient may be asymptomatic, or present with infertility or chronic pelvic pain.
On HSG, it appears as terminal sacculation and occlusion of both fallopian tubes with a normal uterine cavity. Usually, a thin-walled, hypoechoic, cystic structure is seen. However, it may appear as multiple hyperechoic mural nodules around the inner circumference of the tube creating a 'beads on a string' appearance.
Treatment:
Treat the underlying cause
Laparoscopic salpingostomy - in mild disease
IVF recommended for women with infertility and severe hydrosalpinx

Solution to Question 1:
The accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation to establish the diagnosis of infertility in a couple is one year of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse.
Infertility is an apparent failure of a couple to conceive while sterility is an absolute inability to conceive. Infertility is of two types:
Primary infertility - when there have been no previous pregnancies.
Secondary infertility - when there has been a prior pregnancy (although not necessarily a live birth).
Solution to Question 2:
The most common cause of male infertility is disorders of spermatogenesis.
Male factor is the cause of infertility in about 20% of infertile couples. However, it is a contributing factor for infertility in 50% of cases.
Solution to Question 3:
The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of inhibin secreted by Sertoli cells.
GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to secrete FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and LH (luteinizing hormone). FSH acts on Sertoli cells while LH triggers testosterone secretion by the Leydig cells. Sertoli cells secrete inhibin B which in turn inhibits FSH but stimulate LH secretion.

Solution to Question 4:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is normospermia. Different types of disorders of sperms are as follows:
Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen.
Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL.
Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL.
Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology.
Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility.
Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.
Note: Morphology > motility is the most important marker in sperm analysis.
Solution to Question 5:
The normal leucocyte level in human semen is approximately 1 million/ml.
The semen sample should be collected after 2-7 days of ejaculatory abstinence. The patient should collect the sample by masturbation at the doctor's office. If not possible, then the sample may be collected at home and delivered to the laboratory within an hour of collection.
Solution to Question 6:
Azoospermia is defined as the complete absence of sperm in semen. Other types of sperm disorders are as follows:
Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen.
Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL.
Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL.
Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology.
Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility.
Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.
Solution to Question 7:
Artificial insemination with donor semen is done in cases of infertility where the husband has azoospermia.
Azoospermia is defined as a complete absence of sperms. Hence artificial insemination with the husband's/partner's semen cannot be performed.
Indications for artificial insemination with husband's/partner's semen are:
Chronic medical disorder
Oligospermia after sperm washout
Impotence
Premature and retrograde ejaculation
Hypospadias
Antisperm antibodies in cervical mucus
Unexplained infertility- direct intraperitoneal insemination (DIPI) is done
HIV-positive male or female
X-Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection in cases of genetic and chromosomal abnormalities Indications for artificial insemination with donor semen are:
Azoospermia
Uncorrectable immunological factors
Genetic disease in husband/partner
Chronic ill health
Sperms can be frozen and used later for artificial insemination e.g. if the husband requires to undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy, or if the husband is a frequent traveler and is not available at the time of ovulation.
Artificial insemination techniques include:
Intrauterine Insemination (IUI)
Intrafallopian-tube Insemination
Intracervical Insemination
Direct Intraperitoneal Insemination (DIPI)
Steps required to do artificial insemination are:
The semen is washed to remove abnormal sperms, debris, and seminal plasma containing antibodies. It is concentrated, and its quality is improved by the 'swim up technique' or by the use of the Percoll gradient.
Semen with normal sperms and good motility is obtained.
Around the time of ovulation, semen obtained is inseminated into the female genital tract. About
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
5 ml of semen is injected 36 hours after hCG injection when the ovarian follicle reaches 20 mm.
Solution to Question 8:
Artificial insemination with donor's semen is not indicated in idiopathic male infertility. The preferred treatment in such cases is in vitro fertilization (IVF).
Solution to Question 9:
Pulmonary hypertension is an indication for the use of sildenafil. The contraindications for the use of sildenafil are:
Retinitis pigmentosa
Diabetic retinopathy
Patient on antihypertensive drugs, nitrates
Cardiac disease, previous myocardial infarct, stroke
In the treatment of erectile dysfunction, sildenafil in the dose of 25–100 mg is given 1 hour before intercourse. However, it does not improve libido.
Solution to Question 10:
The most common cause for infertility in women is due to ovarian causes.
According to WHO, female factor infertility was reported in 37% of infertile couples in developed countries. Male factor infertility was reported in 8% of infertile couples while 35% of couples had both male and female factor infertility.
The major ovarian causes of infertility are:
Anovulation (PCOS)
Decreased ovarian reserve, e.g., premature menopause
In women with ovulatory disorders, clomifene and metformin increase ovulation and pregnancy rates.
Less common factors responsible for female infertility are:
Endometriosis
Pelvic adhesions
Tubal blockage
Other tubal abnormalities
Hyperprolactinemia
Solution to Question 11:
Among the given options, the level of follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) is the best indicator of ovarian reserve.
Ovarian reserve is the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase on day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle.
A high FSH level indicates that the ovarian reserve is getting depleted and fewer oocytes are present in the ovary. FSH is high in ovarian hypofunction and postmenopausal women.
Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a better marker than FSH for ovarian reserve. Unlike FSH, its levels can be estimated at any time of the cycle. AMH is produced by the granulosa cells in ovarian follicles.
Note: Studies show that AMH levels decrease under the current use of oral contraceptive pills and tobacco smoking.
Solution to Question 12:
In low ovarian reserve, the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) will be <1 ng/ml.
AMH is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of the primordial follicle of the ovary. It helps in oocyte maturation and mono-follicular development. AMH is also used in assessing ovarian reserve.
In women, AMH is always absent during embryogenesis and is secreted by the granulosa cells after puberty. It helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation. Estimation of serum AMH is used in the study of ovarian reserve in female infertility and secondary amenorrhoea.
In men, AMH starts to be secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testes by the 7th week of intrauterine life. It continues until puberty. It inhibits the development of the Müllerian system. The absence of AMH results in the development of hermaphroditism.

Solution to Question 14:
The image depicts the proliferative phase of the endometrium.
During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely; proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:
Proliferative phase
The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
Arteries become more coiled and spiralled.
The endometrium is thick, the stoma is compact and short straight glands are present. The image below shows proliferative endometrium

Secretory phase
The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of menstruation.
Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity)
Corkscrew-shaped glands
The image below shows secretory endometrium

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.
Solution to Question 15:
The image shows the characteristic ferning pattern of cervical mucus which is seen in the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle.
A specimen of cervical mucus is obtained using a platinum loop or pipette. This is spread on a clean glass slide and allowed to dry. When viewed under the low-power microscope, a palm leaf or fern type pattern is seen in the follicular phase. The ferning is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the effect of estrogen.
This pattern disappears after ovulation. If it was previously present, its disappearance is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity. Under the influence of progesterone, the cervical mucus becomes thick and tenacious and impenetrable to sperms and bacteria.
The below image shows the microscopic appearance of dried cervical mucus showing the fern appearance.

Solution to Question 16:
In the Miller–Kurzrok test, sperm acquiring jerky motility after penetrating cervical mucus is considered abnormal.
The Miller-Kurzrok test is a special test done in semen analysis to diagnose the cause of infertility. It is an in vitro test of sperm–mucus interaction.
It is based on the basic principle that a normal cervical mucus permits invasion by motile sperms. It is done at the time of ovulation. The test consists of placing cervical mucus on a glass slide alongside the specimen of the husband's semen and studying the penetration of sperms under the microscope. The penetration of sperm > 3 cm into the mucus at 30 minutes is considered normal.
Other special tests in semen analysis include:
Sperm penetration test
Semen–cervical mucus contact test
Postcoital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test)
Solution to Question 17:
The post-coital test can not detect a fallopian tube block. It can evaluate the following conditions:
Sperm count
Sperm morphology
Ferning during the estrogenic effect
Ovulation
The ability of the cervical mucous to allow sperm penetration
Detection of anti-sperm antibodies in the cervical mucous
In the post-coital test, the couple is advised to have intercourse early in the morning close to the ovulation phase. The woman is asked to visit the clinic within 2 hours of having intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control.
On microscopy, 10–50 motile sperms are normally seen per high-power field. The cervical mucus is also examined for its quantity and viscosity. The post-coital test is useless in the presence of cervical infection.
An immunological factor causing infertility is encountered in around 5% of infertile couples.
Solution to Question 18:
The instrument in the given image is Rubin's cannula.
It is used while performing a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). The cone prevents the retrograde spillage of the dye into the vagina, while the dye is instilled into the uterine cavity. This investigation is performed to study tubal patency in women.
Another cannula that can be used to perform HSG is Spackman cannula. It allows for the intra-operative manipulation of both anteverted and retroverted uterus.
Solution to Question 19:
This patient would be classified as a case of moderate Asherman syndrome as 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces are present.
Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:
Minimal: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions. Asherman syndrome can present in the following ways:
Secondary amenorrhea
Oligomenorrhoea
Dysmenorrhoea
Habitual abortions
Infertility
The causes of Asherman syndrome are:
Dilatation and curettage (D&C)
Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions
Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage
Uterine infection
Tubercular endometritis
Solution to Question 20:
The given image shows a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis.
Procedure of HSG:
It is best performed in the period between the last day of menses to ovulation, usually on the 9th/10th day of the cycle.

question_text:
15ml radioopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity via Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter.
Fluoroscopy is performed as the dye passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.
If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia into the peritoneum, and smear the adjacent bowel.
It is used for the detection of:
Tubal block - It can be due to:
Strictures - fibrotic block
Inspissated amorphous material
Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia.
Uterine anomalies
Uterine polyps
Uterine synechiae
The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology. Contraindications:
Genital tract infections, such as genital tuberculosis. This is due to the risk of spreading infection.
Bleeding
Suspected pregnancy
Allergy to the dye
Premenstrual phase:
If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.
Solution to Question 21:
The given image shows a normal hysterosalpingogram (HSG). Both fallopian tubes are patent with a spill into the peritoneal cavity.
The following images show the findings of an abnormal hysterosalpingogram:
The hysterosalpingogram given below shows bilateral dilated fallopian tubes with no free spill suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx:

The hysterosalpingogram given below shows a unicornuate uterus:

The hysterosalpingogram given below shows a bicornuate uterus/septate uterus:
There is an overlap in the appearance of the bicornuate uterus and septate/sub-septate uterus on HSG. The distinction lies in the shape of the uterine fundus, which is usually not visible on HSG. An ultrasound or MRI should be done to differentiate between these conditions if intervention is planned.

Solution to Question 22:
Fertiloscopy helps in obtaining a good view of the posterior surface (and not the anterior surface) of the ovary and genital organs. This is an advantage of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy.
The other advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy are:
The Trendelenburg position is not needed. The procedure can be done in a lithotomy position
Trauma can be avoided as no trocar is needed
No CO2: Hydroperitoneum with saline
Peritoneal spill can be seen
Fertiloscopy is a new mini-invasive diagnostic technique that allows the visualization of the posterior pelvis. In this technique, an optical device is introduced into the pouch of Douglas, through the posterior vaginal fornix, under general/local anaesthesia.
It can also be used for small interventions, such as adhesiolysis, ovarian drilling, coagulation of endometriosis spots and to perform chromosalpingoscopy and salpingoscopy. With fertiloscopy, surgical intervention can be avoided and it is a good alternative to diagnostic laparoscopy.

Solution to Question 23:
In the given clinical scenario, the next step in management will be hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery.
Tubal contractions, particularly cornual spasms, can give an incorrect impression of proximal fallopian tube obstruction (a false-positive result) on hysterosalpingography. Laparoscopy with chromotubation is therefore considered to confirm the diagnosis of cornual spasm. Laparoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic in this condition.
Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure that provides an endoscopic view of the endometrial cavity and tubal ostia via the cervix, performed in the preovulatory phase. It can
be diagnostic or therapeutic. It is the gold standard investigation for visualizing the uterine cavity and tubal ostia.
Contraindications to hysteroscopy are as follows:
Acute genital tract infection (Eg: genital herpes infection)
Viable intrauterine pregnancy
During menstruation, the view is obscured, and the infection rate is high.
Scarred uterus and enlarged uterus of size  12 weeks are relative contraindications.
Cervical stenosis can cause cervical tears and uterine perforation.
Cardiopulmonary disorder due to increased risk of fluid overload and pulmonary edema.
Known cases of cervical cancer
Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the evaluation of tubal factors in infertility, commonly done in the proliferative phase. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic.
Benefits of laparoscopic evaluation:
Tubes: For detection of tubal patency, block (site and side), motility, hydrosalpinx change, eritubal adhesions, fimbrial agglutination
Ovaries: PCOS changes, endometriosis, PID, adhesions
Uterus: Anomalies, fibroids
Peritoneal factors: Adhesions, PID, endometriosis, tuberculosis
Therapy at the same sitting (as appropriate)

Solution to Question 24:
The best line of management for the given patient is human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG)
followed by hCG.
The patients who have undergone hypophysectomy i.e. removal of the pituitary gland, can not produce endogenous gonadotropins. Exogenous gonadotropins such as hMG are given to such patients. Timed administration of hCG is needed to induce ovulation after the follicle has matured.
The human menopausal gonadotropin is an extract of urine from postmenopausal women. It contains FSH and LH in the required ratio for follicular growth.
Clomiphene, letrozole, and GnRH analogs stimulate the release of gonadotropins from the pituitary gland. These are not helpful in a patient whose pituitary gland has been removed.

Solution to Question 1:
Menopause is defined as cessation of ovarian function for 12 months resulting in permanent amenorrhoea. It is a retrospective diagnosis.
Solution to Question 2:
The follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) level is studied on day 2–5 after the last menstrual period to detect the premenopausal stage.
It is a period of 3–4 years before menopause and is associated with mild ovarian hormonal deficiency leading to menstrual disorders, especially menorrhagia.
The climacteric phase is the phase of waning of ovarian activity. It begins 2 to 3 years before menopause and may continue 2-5 years after menopause. It marks the transition from active to inactive ovarian function and involves physical, sexual, and psychological adjustments.
The predictors of approaching menopause include:
A fall in the level of inhibin B and a corresponding rise in FSH level
A fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) - This is a better marker of ovarian reserve and can be tested on any day of the cycle.

Solution to Question 4:
The average age of menopause in India is 47 years, and ranges from 45 to 50 years.
Menopause sets in when the follicle number falls below 1000. If this happens before 40 years, it is termed premature menopause while attaining it after 55 years is delayed menopause.
The age at which menopause is attained is not related to age at menarche, race, number of pregnancies, socio-economic status, or oral contraceptive pills usage. However, it is directly influenced by smoking and genetic disposition.
Solution to Question 5:
Norepinephrine and serotonin are responsible for hot flushes in menopausal women.
A fall in the level of estrogen causes a reduction in hypothalamic endorphins. This causes a release of more norepinephrine and serotonin, which lower the set point in the thermoregulatory nucleus. As a result, the heat-loss mechanism is triggered by even subtle changes in core body temperature.
Risk factors for hot flushes:
Low estradiol levels
High BMI
Sedentary lifestyle
Surgical menopause has increased risk
Low socioeconomic status
History of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)
Depression.
Solution to Question 6:
The clinical features are suggestive of vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in a menopausal woman for which the most effective treatment is estrogen therapy.
Treatment options include:
Hormonal
Estrogen therapy - most effective
Combined OC pills - given when estrogen is contraindicated
Tibolone
Non-hormonal
Clonidine
SSRIs (eg: fluoxetine)
Dopamine antagonist
Non-prescriptive
Vitamin E
Soya
Isoflavones
Hormone therapy is only indicated for the treatment of vasomotor symptoms, osteoporosis
(prevention and treatment), and vaginal atrophy.
Endometrial hyperplasia can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. Hence, for patients with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone. This is not necessary for women who have undergone hysterectomy.
Note: Even though OCPs contain both estrogen and progesterone, a lesser dosage of each component is given for the treatment of hot flushes.
Solution to Question 7:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic vaginitis. The next step in management should be topical estrogen therapy such as the estradiol-releasing vaginal ring.
Atrophic vaginitis is a common cause of post-menopausal bleeding due to low estradiol levels. Patients may present with dry vagina, dyspareunia and a purulent or blood-tinged discharge. The vagina appears pale, dry, and may show petechiae.
Treatment of atrophic vaginitis involves topical estrogens in the form of creams, tablets, or rings. Estrogen replacement restores vaginal mucosal elasticity, vaginal fluid secretion levels, blood flow, and sensorimotor responses.
Systemic therapy may help prevent recurrence. Vaginal lubricants and moisturizers can be given for symptomatic relief.

The reduction in breast size in postmenopausal women is due to the withdrawal of estrogen and progesterone.
Estrogen exerts proliferative effects on the ductal component, while progesterone exerts a proliferative effect on the glandular component.
Solution to Question 9:
Early rapid bone loss can be determined from a dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan of the hip and lumbar vertebra.
The risk for most fractures is inversely proportional to bone density. The reference standard for the diagnostic purpose is DEXA at the hip (femoral neck or total hip). These sites are superior to the spine in predicting hip as well as an overall osteoporotic fracture.
DEXA is used to assess bone mineral density (BMD). It is interpreted as follows:

HRT is no longer recommended for the management of menopausal women with ischemic heart disease.
Indications for HRT is as follows:
Severe hot flushes
Premature menopause
Surgical oophorectomy
Turner syndrome (gonadal dysgenesis).
Solution to Question 11:
Hypertension is not a contraindication for hormone replacement therapy (HRT). HRT can be initiated in patients with a history of hypertension, diabetes, or smoking; provided they are regularly monitored.
Contraindications of estrogen therapy:
Breast cancer, uterine cancer, or family history of cancer
Previous history of thromboembolic episode
Liver and gall bladder diseases
Uterine fibroids - as the fibroids may enlarge in size.
Solution to Question 12:
Breast cancer developing subsequent to HRT is of low grade and has a good prognosis.
The risk of breast cancer is not increased up to 3 years of HRT and 5 years of estrogen-only replacement therapy. Lower risk is seen with the use of dydrogesterone in HRT.
HRT can cause recurrence of breast cancer and is, therefore, contraindicated in a woman who has been treated for breast cancer.
HRT increases the density of breast tissue and subsequently impedes the screening for breast cancer with mammography.
Solution to Question 13:
A minimum of 12 days (in a month) of progesterone must be added to estrogen therapy. This reduces the risk of endometrial cancer to 2%.
The risk of cancer with estrogen therapy is dose and duration-dependent. Combined estrogen and progesterone provides better protection against endometrial cancer.
Tibolone is a safe drug and does not cause endometrial hyperplasia.
Solution to Question 14:
Vaginal bleeding occurring after 6 months of amenorrhoea in women of menopausal age group should be considered as postmenopausal bleeding and investigated. This must be done irrespective of a previous diagnosis of menopause.
All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma. Even in those women who are perimenopausal, endometrial carcinoma must be suspected if they fall under the above-mentioned clinical category.
Solution to Question 15:
Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high.
For those who undergo TVUS and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.
Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:
Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation in abnormal uterine bleeding, especially n females >35 years.
Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
Hysteroscopy and biopsy is the investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.
If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or
hysteroscopy.
Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.
Solution to Question 16:
Visualization of a mass with a single feeding vessel on a color Doppler is characteristic of
an endometrial polyp. In contrast, submucous leiomyomas often receive blood flow from multiple vessels (option A).
Endometrial polyps are soft, fleshy growths within the uterus that consist of endometrial glands, fibrous stroma, and surface epithelium. Risk factors for endometrial polyps include increasing age, obesity, and tamoxifen use.
They are usually asymptomatic. When symptomatic, they present with heavy menstrual bleeding, prolonged bleeding, intermenstrual bleeding, or infertility.
The main diagnostic tools for endometrial polyps include transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) with applied color Doppler, saline infusion sonography, and hysteroscopy.
The risk factors for the malignant transformation include postmenopausal status, age older than 60, and abnormal bleeding. Other factors such as larger polyp size (>1.5 cm), tamoxifen use, diabetes, and obesity may also contribute to a higher risk.
Hysteroscopic polypectomy may be considered most effective for symptomatic women or those with risk factors for malignant transformation.
Solution to Question 17:
Normal saline is the ideal fluid media used for bipolar electrocautery as it can function regardless of the fluid electrolyte content.
Normal saline and lactated Ringer solutions are commonly used isotonic, electrolyte-containing fluids in operating rooms for diagnostic hysteroscopy procedures. These solutions can cause volume overload and, if rapidly absorbed in large volumes, may lead to pulmonary edema.
Isotonic, electrolyte-containing fluids are contraindicated for use with monopolar electrosurgical devices because they conduct electrical current, dissipate instrument energy and render the instrument ineffective. Low-viscosity, electrolyte-poor fluids such as 1.5-percent glycine, 3-percent sorbitol, and 5-percent mannitol are preferred as they are non-conductive and can be safely used with monopolar electrosurgical energy devices.
The primary risk of using hypotonic, hypoosmolar solutions is the intravascular absorption of these fluids, which can lead to acute hyponatremia and hypo osmolality.
The criteria for terminating the procedure for electrolyte-deficient fluid is a deficit of 1 L and electrolyte-rich fluid is a deficit of 2.5 L.

subject: OBGYN

question_text:
–10% of malignant ovarian tumors are genetic. BRCA 1 is associated with hereditary breast-ovarian cancer syndrome.
BRCA 1 is on chromosome 17q and BRCA 2 is on chromosome 13q.
MSH2 and MLH1 gene mutation is seen in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). It is associated with malignancy of the colon, ovary, and endometrium.
Solution to Question 3:
Bilateral tubectomy and hysterectomy reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.
Some ovarian malignancies originate in the fallopian tubes as dysplastic lesions which later spread to the ovary (dropping down theory). Thus, bilateral tubectomy reduces the risk of ovarian malignancy.
Risk factors for ovarian cancer:
Advancing age
Early menarche and late menopause
Talc exposure to the perineum
Family history of breast / ovarian cancer
Ovulation induction therapy by clomiphene citrate Protective factors against ovarian cancer:
Use of oral contraceptive pills
Multiparity
Breastfeeding
Anovulation.
Solution to Question 4:
Mucinous cystadenoma is the largest benign ovarian tumor.
Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucoid-containing, thick-walled cyst. It is usually multilocular and lined by single columnar epithelium.
It is the third most common epithelial tumor of the ovary. It has a 10% chance of becoming malignant. About 40% of dermoid cysts are found in conjunction with mucinous cystadenomas.

Solution to Question 5:
Stromal invasion is not seen in borderline ovarian tumors.
Borderline tumors of the ovary (also called tumors of low malignant potential) are a heterogeneous group of lesions defined histologically by atypical epithelial proliferation without stromal invasion.
The clinical progression of these tumors is distinct from ovarian carcinoma, so they are considered a distinct clinical entity.
Features of borderline ovarian tumors:
No stromal invasion
Mitotic figures <4/10 high power field
Survival rate is 90%
Usually occurs between 35-55 years of age
Serous type is the most common, followed by mucinous type.
Solution to Question 6:
Follicular cyst is a physiological/functional cyst of the ovary. Physiological/functional cysts of the ovary:
Follicular cyst - Failure of rupture of the follicle during ovulation.
Theca lutein cyst - Stimulation of atretic follicles by abnormal HCG levels. It regresses when hCG levels fall.
Luteoma of pregnancy - Due to prolonged elevation of hCG, like in multiple pregnancies.
Hemorrhagic ovarian cysts usually occur due to bleeding into the corpus luteum or other functional cysts at the time of ovulation. Hemorrhagic cysts are normal findings in ovulatory women, generally resolving within 8 weeks.
Cobweb appearance on USG in a hemorrhagic cyst is shown below.

Solution to Question 7:
In Meig's syndrome, a benign ovarian mass is likely to be seen. Irregular surface and immobility are features of malignant tumors.
Meig’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of:
Benign ovarian tumors
Ascites
Right-sided pleural effusion.
The pleural effusions are usually right-sided, even though the left-sided and bilateral effusions are possible.
Tumors causing Meigs' syndrome include ovarian fibroma, granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor, or thecoma.
However, when the causative factor is ovarian secondaries, leiomyoma, and benign ovarian cysts
(such as teratoma and mucinous cystadenoma), the condition is called Pseudo Meigs' syndrome. Resolution of ascites and pleural effusion is seen after the removal of the tumor.
Management:
Repeated paracentesis for ascites.
Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy in young patients for preserving fertility
Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO) in postmenopausal women.
Note: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients may also have a combination of ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated serum levels of CA-125. This is known as Tjalma syndrome or pseudo-pseudo Meigs’ syndrome.
Solution to Question 8:
Psammoma bodies are a histopathological finding of serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary.
They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Their presence does not denote malignancy.
Psammoma bodies are seen in the following conditions:
Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid
Papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium
Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
Meningioma
The image below shows Psammoma body.

Solution to Question 9:
The above clinical scenario and findings point to a diagnosis of pseudomyxoma peritonei. It is associated with mucinous cystadenoma.
Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare clinical entity characterized by diffuse intra-abdominal gelatinous and mucoid material on peritoneal surfaces. Spontaneous perforation of a mucinous
cystadenoma leads to implantation of low-grade malignant tumor cells in the peritoneum. However, the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei is carcinoma of the appendix.
Diagnosis is by CT, MRI, and laparoscopy. Even after the removal of the ovarian tumor, these cells continue to secrete mucin. Recurrence rates are high.
Solution to Question 10:
The above scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion, especially at the end of the 1st trimester or during puerperium.
Management includes derotation and cystectomy in pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. This is also done in non-pregnant women of reproductive age to preserve ovarian function.
Resection is reserved for patients in whom malignancy is suspected.
Dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases.
Dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones.
Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii. The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.


Solution to Question 11:
The given histopathological image shows Schiller-Duval bodies. It is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor
(endodermal sinus tumor).
It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal areas in young children. It is usually unilateral. These tumors are usually associated with raised AFP and alpha 1 antitrypsin.
The image below depicts Schiller-Duval bodies. It consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. 50% of yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic when present.

Solution to Question 12:
The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. It is a germ cell tumor.
It usually arises in young women or in children. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors.
Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.
Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.
Dysgerminoma was considered to be the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. Recent data indicates that in the past few decades, their incidence has reduced considerably.
Immature teratomas are now the most common type of malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary.
The image below shows the histopathology of a dygerminoma, characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes.

Solution to Question 13:
Germ cell tumors are the most common ovarian tumor in women aged less than 20 years.
Epithelial tumours are the commonest tumours. It accounts for 80% of all ovarian malignant tumours.
Solution to Question 14:
Non-mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the ovary. It has elevated CA- 125 levels.
CA-125 value > 35 U/ml is suggestive of epithelial ovarian cancer. Malignant conditions with raised CA 125 levels:
Ovarian epithelial carcinoma (most common cause)
Endometrial cancer
Pancreatic cancer
Colon cancer
Breast cancer
Lung cancer
Lymphoma
Benign conditions with raised CA 125 levels:
Pregnancy
Pelvic inflammatory disease
Endometriosis
Uterine fibroid
Normally elevated in 1% females
Acute peritonitis
Solution to Question 15:
Lactate dehydrogenase is the tumor marker in dysgerminoma.
Dysgerminomas are primitive neoplasms. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%).
It is seen in young women with an average incidence of 20 years of age. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors.
It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (PALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and -hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.
Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.
Solution to Question 16:
Risk of malignancy index (RMI) score of 200 or more indicates a high risk for ovarian cancer in a patient with an adnexal mass.
Risk of malignancy index (RMI) = U x M x CA125
U = Ultrasound score
The ultrasound result is scored 1 point for each of the following characteristics: multilocular cysts, solid areas, metastases, ascites, and bilateral lesions.
U = 0 (for an ultrasound score of 0)
U = 1 (for an ultrasound score of 1)
U = 3 (for an ultrasound score of 2–5).
M = Menopausal status
M= 1 (for pre-menopausal)
M= 3 (for post-menopausal)
CA-125 = Serum CA-125 level (in IU/ml)
For any post-menopausal woman with an ovarian cyst of size >1cm, RMI should be calculated.
Solution to Question 17:
Brenner tumors are usually benign but rarely they can turn malignant.
Brenner tumor (transitional cell tumor) is a benign, epithelial, unilateral tumor, resembling a fibroma. Histologically, Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei are seen.
Brenner tumor represent only 2-3% of all ovarian neoplasms, and <2% of these tumors are malignant.
It is called Meigs' syndrome if the clinical picture is caused by an ovarian fibroma, granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor, or thecoma.
Meig’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of:
Benign ovarian tumor
Ascites
Right-sided pleural effusion.
Pseudo Meigs' syndrome is when the causative factor is ovarian secondaries, leiomyoma, and benign ovarian cysts such as teratoma and mucinous cystadenoma.
The image given below shows Walthard cell rest.

The image given below shows coffee bean nuclei.

Solution to Question 18:
The above scenario points to a diagnosis of theca lutein cysts in association with molar pregnancy. Theca lutein cysts are not associated with the use of oral contraceptives.
Lutein cysts types :
Granulosa lutein cysts - They occur due to failure of regression of corpus luteum after 14 days of vulation.
Theca lutein cysts - They are found in association with hydatidiform moles, choriocarcinoma, and gonadotropin (hCG), or clomiphene therapy.
Theca lutein cysts occur due to the hyperstimulation of ovaries as a result of high hCG levels in molar pregnancies and other conditions. They are usually bilateral.
These cysts usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2-4 months following the evacuation of a molar pregnancy.
Sometimes they can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such instances, laparoscopic untwisting of the cyst has to be done.
Solution to Question 19:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of granulosa cell tumor. It is associated with carcinoma endometrium.
Granulosa cell tumors cells are estrogen-secreting ovarian tumors. It is seen in 80% of women over 40 years and 5% of pre-pubertal girls. Precocious puberty is seen due to excess secretion of estrogen.
It is a low-grade malignancy. It is almost always unilateral. Tumor marker inhibin B is frequently elevated more than inhibin A. Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.
On histopathology, it has characteristic Call-Exner bodies. It appears as a rosette arrangement of cells around an eosinophilic fluid space, as shown below.

Solution to Question 20:
Prophylactic oophorectomy is indicated if one ovary has already been removed for benign neoplasm.
Candidates suitable for prophylactic oophorectomy:
Nulliparous aged > 45 years
Any age with a history of ovarian, endometrial, or colon cancer in a 1st-degree relative
Grossly abnormal ovary in the premenopausal age group
One ovary removed for benign neoplasm
Previous history of breast carcinoma
Radiation-induced menopause
Solution to Question 21:
Stage 3 ovarian cancer is a unilateral or bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and/or regional lymph node involvement and liver capsule involvement.
Grading of ovarian cancer:
Grade 1 - well-differentiated cancers have cells that closely resemble normal cells and are less likely to spread or recur.
Grade 2 - moderately differentiated cancer cells.
Grade 3 - poorly differentiated cancers show increasing abnormality of appearance compared t normal cells. They are also more likely to spread and recur.
Solution to Question 22:
Unilateral oophorectomy is preferred in a young woman who has not completed her family in case of early-stage disease.
Solution to Question 23:
Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor. They are highly susceptible to radiotherapy.
Solution to Question 24:
CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for post-menopausal ovarian cysts.
Management includes the following:
Calculation of Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) = U x M x Ca-125, where
U = ultrasound score
M = menopausal status
Ca 125 = serum levels
Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size >5 cm or RMI >200.
Option B - CT scan is not recommended for initial evaluation. It is done only for further evaluation and when RMI > 200.
Solution to Question 25:
Signet ring cells are seen in Krukenberg tumor.
A Krukenberg tumor is an ovarian malignancy that metastasized from a primary site, most commonly from the stomach (70%). Carcinomas of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma) are the next most common primary sites.
The route of spread may be:
Lymphatic
Hematogenous
Transcoelomic
They are usually bilateral and have a smooth surface with a waxy consistency. They retain the shape of a normal ovary.

Solution to Question 2:
Condyloma acuminata is the common differential diagnosis of verrucous carcinoma. It refers to anogenital warts and has a verrucous appearance.
Verrucous carcinoma is a variant of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. It is locally invasive and rarely metastasizes.
Condyloma lata is a benign and painless cutaneous manifestation of secondary syphilis. It is characterized by gray to white lesions, typically located in the oro-genital region.
Chancre is a painless genital ulcer most commonly formed during the primary stage of syphilis.

Solution to Question 7:
Among the given gynecological malignancies, sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is most useful in vulval carcinomas.
This is because women with earlier stages of vulval cancer can have diseased lymph nodes even without palpable enlargement of nodes. Hence, sentinel lymph node biopsy helps in early diagnosis lymph node spread which can be managed by lymph node dissection.
A sentinel lymph node is a physiologically, the first lymph node to receive tumor lymphatic drainage.
Malignancies where sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly done are :
Vulval carcinoma
Breast carcinoma
Penile carcinoma
Malignant melanoma
Lymphatic mapping is similar technique to SLNB that can also be used in vulval cancers.

Solution to Question 9:
Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is commonly seen in adoloscent girls with a history of intrauterine DES exposure.
It involves the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Radical hysterectomy, vaginectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy is the treatment of choice.
The most common lesion due to DES exposure is vaginal adenosis and not clear cell adenocarcinoma. It is a benign condition.
Solution to Question 10:
The most common site of vulval cancer is labia majora > clitoris > labia minora.
Solution to Question 11:
According to FIGO staging, tumor with positive inguinal lymph node is classified as stage III.
Solution to Question 12:
Vascular route of spread is rare in vulval cancer. Lymphatic is the most common route of spread in vulval cancer.
Lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor. The sentinel lymph node biopsy is helpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer. Lymph nodes involved are, superficial inguinal nodes (sentinel node) > deep inguinal nodes > femoral group of nodes.
Solution to Question 13:
Vaginal cancer extending up to the pelvic wall is stage III.
Vaginal cancer commonly affects females >70 years of age. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histologic type. It commonly involves the upper third of the posterior wall of the vagina.
Patients are mostly asymptomatic. They may present with painless abnormal vaginal bleeding, post-coital bleed, and foul-smelling discharge per vagina.
Vaginal cancer staging:
Stage 0 - Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
Stage I - Carcinoma limited to the vaginal wall
Stage II - Carcinoma extending beyond the vagina, but not extending to the pelvic walls
Stage III - Carcinoma extends up to the pelvic walls
Stage IVA - Carcinoma extending beyond the true pelvis/or involving the bladder and/or rectum, or evidence of distant metastasis
Stage IVB - Spread to the distant metastasis
Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario is suggestive of vulval melanoma. The most commonly involved site is labia majora followed by labia minora and clitoris.
Vulval melanoma is the second most common vulval cancer. It may arise from junctional naevus. It has a high propensity for local and distant recurrence and has a poor prognosis.
Radical vulvectomy and bilateral regional lymphadenectomy is the preferred treatment.

Solution to Question 6:
A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. It is not a diagnostic test (option C). The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.
If trichomonas is reported from Pap testing, it should be confirmed by saline microscopic preparation (option B).
Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a Pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and Pap co-test every 5
years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years. HIV+ women should have annual checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation.
Procedure:
The patient is put in a dorsal position, and the labia are parted
Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced
The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayer’s spatula:
Bifid end - ectocervical sample
Blunt end - vaginal cytology
Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush
The sample is spread on a glass slide
The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol
Stained with Papanicolau stain or short-duration Papanicolau stain (SPS).
