Solution to Question 9:
The appropriate management of a 45-year-old with a positive pap smear and post-coital bleeding is a colposcopy-directed biopsy.
A per speculum examination must be done whenever a female comes with post-coital bleeding in order to evaluate for carcinoma of the cervix. If growth is visible, a punch biopsy should be done, and else if no growth is visible, then a pap smear is done. A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.
Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and pap co-test every 5
years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If a pap smear is suspicious, then screening is continued till 75 years. HIV+ve women should have annual checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation.
Solution to Question 10:
The given case scenario is suggestive of cervical carcinoma. The best time to do a Pap smear is around ovulation, but it can be performed at any other time as well.
Prerequisites of doing a Pap smear:
It should be done prior to vaginal examination
Lubricants should not be used
The patient should not be menstruating during the pap tes
The ideal time is around ovulation
The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test.
Based on Pap smear findings, dysplasia of cervical cells is graded using various classification systems such as WHO grading, CIN grading, and the Bethesda system.

Solution to Question 11:
The abnormal cells remain unstained on performing Schiller's test.
Schiller's test, also known as VILI (visual inspection with Lugol's iodine), involves painting the cervix with Lugol's iodine. It is used to detect any abnormal cytology in the cervix and vagina, such as in cases of carcinoma cervix.
The normal vaginal and cervical epithelium contains glycogen, therefore stains mahogany brown on being painted with Lugol's iodine. The abnormal cells remain unstained. These areas need to be biopsied and sent for histopathological examination.
Solution to Question 12:
The basement membrane is intact in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).
Features of CIN:
Varying degree of dysplasia
Altered nuclear-cytoplasmic (N:C) ratio
Hyperchromatic nuclei
Mitotic figures
Intact basement membrane.
Solution to Question 13:
Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) is the most commonly used treatment option for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). It is also known as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP).
It is applicable for the treatment of CIN anywhere in the lower genital tract. This uses electric current through a monopolar wire electrode to either cut or coagulate cervical lesions. Like other excisional procedures, it is done in the immediate post menstrual phase.
The procedure involves minimal patient discomfort, cost, and complications. Since it can be performed using local anesthesia, it has become the primary outpatient treatment modality for high-grade cervical lesions.
Solution to Question 14:
Conization is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is suspected.
Indications of conization
Endocervical dysplasia
Transformation zone is not completely visualized
When there is discrepancy of findings between cytolology, colposcopy & biopsy
Microinvasion is suspected
Indications of hysterectomy
Older & parous women
Uterus is associated with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed
Recurrence or persistent lesion
In-situ adenocarcinoma cervix
Solution to Question 15:
Colposcopy with LEEP would be appropriate management for CIN III.
Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) is an opd procedure done under colposcopic view and local anesthesia.Here, a low voltage current is passed through the loop and a cone of tissue is removed from the cervix. This procedure causes minimal bleeding and the tissue removed is sent for histopathological examination (HPE). This is the treatment of choice for CIN 2&3 of any age and parity.
Solution to Question 16:
Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women in India as well as globally. Cervical cancer is the most common genital cancer in India.
Lip and oral cavity cancer is the most common malignancy in men. Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include:
Human Papilloma virus (most important)
Sexual intercourse before 18 years
Multiple sexual partners
Multiparity
Poor personal hygiene
Smoking and drug abuse
Women with STD, HIV, HSV
Immune suppression
Solution to Question 17:
The transitional zone or squamocolumnar junction is well outside the external os during the reproductive period.
It is the site where the squamous epithelium lining the vagina merges with the columnar epithelium of the endocervix. The original squamocolumnar junction is marked by the presence of Nabothian cysts and glandular openings.
It is a dynamic part and moves with age and hormonal influence:
During pregnancy and with oral contraceptives, it pouts out of os.
Following menopause, it gets indrawn inside the os.
The cells here are highly sensitive to irritants, mutagens and viral agents such as HPV. Cancer screening using Pap smear involves scraping this area and studying the cells for nuclear changes.
Solution to Question 18:
The most common site of adenocarcinoma is endocervix.
It commonly occurs in young females and OCP users, and is associated with HPV 18.
Solution to Question 19:
Patients with carcinoma cervix most commonly present with metrorrhagia, now known as intermenstrual bleeding.
Post-coital bleeding is the most specific symptom of carcinoma cervix.
Solution to Question 20:
The most common site of hematogenous metastasis of cervical cancer is the lung.
About 1-2% of patients with cervical carcinomas present with lung metastases, and 5-35% eventually develop lung metastases.
Other common sites of blood-borne metastases include bone, liver and bowel.
Solution to Question 21:
A recurrent tumor with the largest diameter of <3cm is associated with a good prognosis.
The extent of recurrent disease and involvement of pelvic lymph nodes are prognostic factors for survival. An isolated central pelvic tumour with no involvement of the pelvic sidewall also has a good prognosis.
Most recurrences are seen within 3 years and the prognosis is poor with uremia being the most common terminal event. Recurrences most commonly involve the pelvis than the para-aortic or pelvic lymph node.
All patients with a suspected recurrence should undergo PET/CT for evaluation and biopsy for confirmation.
Treatment involves either radical chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration. Concurrent chemotherapy with cisplatin and/or 5-fluorouracil may improve the outcome.
Solution to Question 22:
Clinical examination is the first step in staging carcinoma cervix.
Clinical examination was the principal method in staging until the 2018 FIGO guidelines which recommended the use of imaging and histological investigations when available. USG, CT, MRI, and PET-CT can be used to assess the extent of the tumor, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.
MRI is the best method to assess the principal tumor while PET-CT is the best method to assess nodal metastasis.
FIGO no longer mandates biochemical investigations, such as tumor markers, for diagnosis of metastasis.
Solution to Question 23:
The stage of cervical carcinoma is II B as it involves the upper part of the vagina and parametrium.
Solution to Question 24:
Type III hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in carcinoma cervix - stage IB. It involves radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy and para-aortic lymph node evaluation.
Stage IB is defined as a macroscopic lesion still confined to the cervix, with the depth of invasion
5mm. It is the first stage in which lesions become clinically visible. Hysterectomy types include:
Type I - Simple / extrafascial
Type II - Modified radical / Wertheim
Type III - Radical / Meigs-Wertheim
Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy
Type V - Exenteration.
Solution to Question 25:
The woman has stage I A2 cervical cancer and the most appropriate management is radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.
Radical trachelectomy is a fertility-preserving surgical procedure. This involves the removal of the entire cervix and parametrium.
Cervical conization with laparoscopic or extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy is an alternative that also preserves fertility.
Solution to Question 26:
Post-menopausal status is not a contraindication for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix. Contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix include:
Pelvic inflammatory disease
Young patient (to preserve ovarian function)
Associated myoma, prolapse, ovarian tumor, genital fistula
Vaginal stenosis
Adenocarcinoma or adenosquamous carcinoma – surgery preferred.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding all over the world is senile endometrial atrophy.
In a menopausal woman, hypoestrogenism causes atrophy of the endometrium and vagina.The atrophic endometrial surfaces contain little or no fluid to prevent intracavitary friction. This
results in micro-erosions of the surface epithelium and a subsequent chronic inflammatory reaction, making the endometrium prone to light bleeding or spotting.
H rmone replacement therapy is the second most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding all ver the world.
Cervical cancer is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in India, while endometrial cancer is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in developed countries.
Note: Endometrial cancer accounts for only 10 % of cases of post-menopausal bleeding. Still, all postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma, since this is a potentially lethal disease.
Solution to Question 2:
Complex hyperplasia with atypia has a 29% increased risk of progression to endometrial cancer. It has the highest risk of progressing to carcinoma compared to other varieties of endometrial hyperplasia.

Solution to Question 3:
The most common cause of pyometra is senile endometritis.
Pyometra refers the collection of pus in the uterus. The most common cancer that causes pyometra is carcinoma cervix followed by carcinoma endometrium.
Solution to Question 4:
Simple hysterectomy is the best treatment in a case of atypical endometrial hyperplasia in a peri-menopausal and post-menopausal female.
Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia carries 29% risk of developing into endometrial carcinoma and hence, must be treated with total abdominal hysterectomy (simple hysterectomy ).
The presence of any concomitant endometrial cancer must be ruled out by doing fractional curettage (or dilatation and curettage) before doing a hysterectomy.
If a premenopausal woman does not desire to undergo hysterectomy, progesterone can be given and the patient is followed up every 3-6 months. If the atypia persists during the follow-up hysterectomy should be performed.

The most common variety of endometrial cancer is adenocarcinoma.
The other varieties of endometrial cancer are squamous cell, clear cell, and serous. The most malignant varieties are clear cell carcinoma and papillary serous tumor.

Solution to Question 9:
The image depicts saline infusion sonography (SIS), also known as sonohysterography. It is usually done after a transvaginal ultrasound, to assess the detailed anatomy of the uterine cavity.
In this procedure, a balloon catheter is inserted through the cervix and the endometrial cavity is distended with 20-40ml of sterile saline. The balloon is inflated to block the backflow of the infused sterile saline and transvaginal ultrasound is performed to visualize the cavity.
It is used:
To determine the endometrial thickness
To determine the cause in cases of infertility
To identify Mullerian anomalies
To visualize endometrial polyps and pedunculated fibroids
The image given below shows the appearance of the uterus on SIS.

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasound is the initial evaluation for postmenopausal bleeding.
Option B: In balloon endometrial ablation, a balloon is inserted into the uterus and inflated with glycine or 5% glucose. It is then heated up, and the endometrium is ablated by the tamponade effect.
Option D: In hysterosalpingography, contrast dye is inserted into the uterus via a catheter, and the uterine and fallopian tube anatomy is visualized.
Solution to Question 10:
Decreased vascular resistance with increased tumor vascularity is seen in carcinoma endometrium.
USG findings in carcinoma endometrium include:
Endometrial thickness >4 mm in postmenopausal women and >10 mm in perimenopausal women
Hyperechoic endometrium with irregular outlines
Increased tumor vascularity with low vascular resistance
Fluid in uterine cavity
Solution to Question 11:
The next line of management in a patient with increased endometrial thickness is an endometrial biopsy.
In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness. If it exceeds 4 mm, then histopathological examination (HPE) of the endometrium is mandatory, irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms. In a perimenopausal woman, the cutoff for normal endometrial thickness is 10mm.
Hysteroscopy and biopsy is preferred over other blind curettage methods for HPE. A biopsy is made from suspicious areas after visualization so chances of missing the lesion are reduced.
Solution to Question 12:
Hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy is now considered the gold standard in the diagnosis of an endometrial lesion. It is preferred for the initial evaluation of women with bleeding suspicious for malignancy.
Endometrial sampling can be done by hysteroscopic biopsy. It is more sensitive for focal endometrial lesions. Dilatation and curettage may also aid the sampling of endometrial lesions.
Ultrasound, CT, and MRI are adjuvant to other investigations. Diagnostic laparoscopy will be required to study the nature of the tumor and its spread if ultrasound picks up a pelvic tumor.
The image given below shows the procedure of hysteroscopy.

Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario depicts endometrial carcinoma and the gold standard method for staging this condition is surgery.
According to FIGO/TNM classification system, a total hysterectomy with bilateral
salpingo-oophorectomy and pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection is the standard staging procedure for endometrial cancer.
Option A: Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) appears to be the best radiographic modality for detecting myometrial invasion or cervical involvement.
Option C: Hysteroscopy visualizes the entire uterine lining and a biopsy is taken from suspicious areas. This is not 100% predictive, as an early lesion can be missed. Recently, the concern has been raised regarding the spilling of cancer cells into the peritoneal cavity during hysteroscopy.
Option D: PET–CT reveals metabolic activity in the tissue and is highly sensitive and specific for detecting positive pelvic and/or para-aortic lymphadenopathy as well as distant metastases in selected high-risk patients with endometrial cancer.
Solution to Question 14:
Pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes are commonly involved in endometrial cancer. The spread is through the infundibulopelvic ligament.
Rarely, inguinal & femoral lymph nodes are involved.
Solution to Question 15:
Carcinoma endometrium involving the vagina but having no lymph node involvement is classified as stage IIIB.
Solution to Question 16:
Early endometrial cancer (stages I & II) is primarily managed surgically. The surgery performed here is abdominal hysterectomy, B/L salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy and pelvic & para-aortic lymph node sampling.
Postoperative management of endometrial cancer:
In low-risk endometrial cancer, no further treatment is required. In intermediate-risk, radiotherapy is done.
In high risk, chemotherapy + radiotherapy is done.
Solution to Question 17:
The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance. This is known as the inverse square law in radiotherapy.
Chemoradiation is the mainstay of treatment of stage III and IV endometrial cancers. They are treated with brachytherapy followed by external radiation. Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor.
Other options:
Option B: Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature.
Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells.
Option D: Small intestinal epithelial cells (intestinal crypts), which divide rapidly with no differentiation are the most radiosensitive.
Solution to Question 18:
Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment in Stage III endometrial cancer.
In order to stage carcinoma endometrium, total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and lymphadenectomy is done (surgical staging).
Thus the management, once staging is done, is mainly postoperative. Up to stage II, radiotherapy can be given. Stages III & IV are managed by chemotherapy such as doxorubicin,
cisplatin, and paclitaxel.
Note: Stage III is said to be inoperable but debulking surgery is sometimes attempted. However, the mainstay of treatment for stage III disease remains chemotherapy.

Solution to Question 1:
The image shows a cardiotocograph (electronic fetal monitor) that is used to perform cardiotocography in labor.
It can be used in both antenatal and intranatal mothers. It measures fetal heart rate and uterine contractions. It is used to perform the non-stress test (NST) in the antenatal period and cardiotocography during labor.
Solution to Question 2:
This is an image of cervidil vaginal insert. It is used for cervical ripening and improves the Bishop's score.
It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone designed to release at a rate of approximately 0.3 mg/hr over 10-hours.
Solution to Question 3:
The given instrument is Kocher's artery forceps and is identified by the presence of a single tooth at the tip.
Kocher's artery forceps are used to achieve hemostasis by holding bleeding vessels. They are also used in low rupture of membranes to augment labour or for the surgical induction of labour.
The difference between artery forceps and needle holders is in the edge and smoothness of corrugations. Artery forceps have smooth edges and single lined corrugations whereas, needle holders have rough edges and crossed lines forming square to diamond shaped corrugations.
Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario of prolonged second stage of labor can be managed by performing an episiotomy. In the given figure, the instrument marked as "D" corresponds to episiotomy scissors.
An episiotomy is done to prevent posterior extention leading to obstetric anal sphincteric injuries.

Solution to Question 5:
The given image shows Wrigley's forceps.
These are used as outlet forceps for the extraction of the fetal head. It is used to provide traction force. It can also be used in C-section for delivery of the baby.
The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve.
Conditions that require to be fulfilled for the use of outlet forceps are:
The fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia (crowning)
The fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, or is on the perineum
The sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°)
Note: Delivery of aftercoming head in breech is done with Pipers forceps.
Solution to Question 6:
The given instrument is Green-Armytage forceps.
Its tips are broad and hence can compress a wide area. During lower segment caesarean section
(LSCS), these forceps are applied at the bleeding cut uterine edges for hemostasis.
Solution to Question 7:
The instrument is Karman’s cannula and syringe, which is also used for menstrual regulation.
Menstrual regulation is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity within 14 days of a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.
Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators. Then

6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction. The cannula is rotated, and pushed in and out with gentle strokes.
This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation. The drawbacks of the procedure include a missed implanted zygote or an unrecognized ectopic pregnancy.
This procedure is not commonly done anymore.
Solution to Question 8:
The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe.
Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done upto 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only upto 10 weeks of gestation .
The indications of this procedure are given as follows:
Medical termination of pregnancy
Incomplete abortion or missed abortion
Molar pregnancy
Endometrial aspiration

Solution to Question 9:
The given image shows Hegar's double-ended dilator which is used to dilate the cervix in dilation and curettage procedure.
Pratt dilator is also a double-ended dilator but has a more linear shape as compared to the curved Hegar's dilators. The image given below shows a Pratt dilator.

Option A: Hawkin dilator is a single-ended dilator. The image given below shows a Hawkin dilator.

Option C: Bakes rosebud dilator is a single-ended dilator used to dilate the urethra. It is called so since its tip is similar to a rosebud. The image given below shows a Bakes dilator.

Solution to Question 10:
The image shows a Fenton dilator. These can be identified by the neck/notch at the centre.
Fenton's or modified Fenton's procedure is performed to widen the introitus in women with superficial dyspareunia secondary to scarring. The narrowing of introitus could be due to scarring secondary to perineal tears during childbirth or from conditions such as lichen sclerosus or vestibulitis.
Fenton dilators come in sizes numbered from 3-10 and the sizes of the dilators range from 3mm to 26mm.
Option B: Hawkins dilator is single-ended.
Options A and C: Hegar and Pratt dilators are also double-ended dilators but they do not have a notch at the centre. Pratt dilator is more linear in appearance compared to Hegar dilator.
Solution to Question 11:
The instrument shown in the image is Sim's curette. It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.
It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of the uterine tissue.

Solution to Question 12:
The image shows a double-ended uterine curette with a sharp and a blunt end. It is not used in uterine length measurement.
Uterine length measurement is done with a uterine sound which is given below.

Solution to Question 13:
The given instrument is Simpson’s uterine sound. It is not used to retract the vagina for cervical examination. This is done using Sim's speculum.
The instrument is held like a pencil with the thumb and the first 2 fingers and introduced into the uterine cavity by keeping it in the midline and ensuring it is not forced.
The uses are given as follows:
To measure uterine cavity and cervical lengt
To diagnose cervical stenosis
To sound a polyp, IUCD or uterine septum
To break adhesions
To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
Solution to Question 14:
The image shows vulsellum forceps. It is used to grasp the cervical lip and steady the cervix during vaginal surgery. It is a long instrument with a gentle curve so that the line of vision is not obstructed.
Option A: Allis forceps can be identified by continuous teeth, equal on both ends. It is used to hold structures with a firm grip.

Option C: Kocher's artery forceps are non-traumatic with a single tooth at the tip. They help in achieving hemostasis by firm pressure.
Option D: Lahey's tissue grasping forceps has teeth similar to dinner forks. They are used to hold fibrous tissue and they give a firm grip without slippage.
Solution to Question 15:
The given instrument is a towel-holding clip. It is used to secure drapings and towels during surgery.

Sponge-holding forceps are non-traumatic forceps. They are used for painting and preparation of parts preoperatively.
Filshie clips are used for laparoscopic tubal sterilisation. They are made of titanium on the outer side and sialistic material on the inner side.

The image shown is that of a Simon vaginal retractor, used to retract vaginal walls during examination and vaginal procedures.
The below image is of Doyen's retractor. It is used during abdominal procedures like C-section.

Solution to Question 18:
The image shows an endocervical brush. It is used to collect samples from the endocervix cervix, especially from deep lesions.
Option A: Cervex brush is ideal for collecting samples for liquid-based cytological studies.
Option C: Ayres spatula is used to collect samples from the ectocervix and the endocervix for cytological studies.
Option D: Aylesbury spatula has a sharper and longer tip than Ayers spatula.
Solution to Question 19:
The given instrument used in the patient's pap smear preparation is Ayre's spatula.
Sharpness on the end can differentiate between Ayre's and Aylesbury spatula. Aylesbury spatula has a more sharp and longer tip than Ayer's spatula. So, Aylesbury spatula is superior to Ayre's in collecting endocervical samples.
The image given below shows a slide holding bottle i.e. Kopliks jar with Ayre's spatula.

Solution to Question 20:
The device shown in the image is a colposcope. It is used to perform colposcopy where the cervix is visualized at a distance of around 20 cm with the patient in the lithotomy position.
This instrument provides binocular vision with a magnification of 6x-15x. A green filter is used to study vascular pattern as the vessels appear black. Abnormal areas can be identified by their peculiar vascular pattern such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate.
Solution to Question 21:
The given image shows a Doyen myoma screw.
It is used to perform an open myomectomy. The handle present in this can be used to distinguish it from a laparoscopic myoma screw which also has a similar tip.
Solution to Question 22:
The given instrument is a fallope ring applicator. It is used in tubal ligation.
Falope ring sterilization is accomplished by applying silicone rubber bands to the fallopian tubes. The major advantage is the elimination of thermocoagulation. The occlusion is only in a short segment and can allow for tubal reconstruction.
